Title: Haters are also your fans in some way: Ananya Panday
Content:
Ananya

Panday

Pandey

Student of the Year 2

Dealing with trolls

Embracing sadness

On ‘me’ time



On celebrating confusion

‘Digital detox is necessary’



Her bestie, Suhana Khan

Being in Bengaluru

might have just made her debut in Bollywood , but the young actress has already been a troll-favourite – either for her comments on her father, actor Chunky’s, struggle in the industry, or her take on nepotism. During a recent youth summit in Bengaluru, however, theactress won the hearts of the audience as she took on a volley of questions on stage quite spiritedly. Excerpts…People say harsh things online - there was even an instance where people had said that I feigned my college admission, and actually did not have to choose between my college and my career. I know I didn't lie, and I did not know why people wrote what they did. So, things like that do hurt. But I have learnt to let go of things I cannot control and believe that change starts from within. Kindness is underrated, so I always focus on how I can remain kind. Actor Tiger Shroff, my co-star from Student of the year 2, would say, "the bigger the target, the easier it is, to shoot." So, in that sense, all my haters are my fans too, in some way, because they are giving me that much importance, taking time out to post about something and write out a negative comment. And kindness is the way to resolve issues because I think that those that spread hate are the ones that need love the most.I'd be lying if I said that the negative things people have to say hasn't not taken a toll on me and everything is hunky-dory. I am happy and positive for the most part. But it is normal when the one-odd comment does hurt you and you get upset about it.My work keeps me motivated. I love acting and being a part of the industry. And I am surrounded by such lovely people who are looking out for me and truly care for me - my family, my team. The love that's around me, keeps me going and it completely outweighs the hate. That's what others who feel bogged down should do too - spend time with the people that you love and things instantly get better. It's the best medicine.I too feel bogged down at times, but I try to focus on the good things in life. I believe it is important to go through sadness and get through negativity. I try to focus on one positive moment every day, and I'd encourage everyone else to do the same too. In case you don't have a happy moment, I suggest you create a happy moment for someone else, and that becomes your happy moment too!I take time out for myself and beat the stress by chilling with my family. I used to be an annoying teenager who wouldn't engage in conversations with family, and go off into my room to be by myself. But I grew out of it and I'm glad I did. I realised that the way we believe our parents are not understanding us, they might be thinking the same about us too.The theme of this year’s summit, celebrating confusion, is so appropriate to me. It’s natural to be confused about making decisions and one should embrace it. Only when you think of all the different options available, and the repercussions of choosing each of them, that confusion begins. And I think it’s necessary too.Also, I love interacting with people and if there is any chance to talk, I'm game, because I love talking. And the fact that I get to do it, especially with youngsters, and being around people who are so passionate about what they do is amazing. The opportunity to meet interesting people always excites me - it's what I love about my job too.I feel like every time I open my phone, when I see troubling news updates – it’s a very sad and scary to read about them, and it might get overwhelming to a point where I wish to detach from my phone. But, having said that, I also believe that one needs to be cued in and aware of what's going in the world, so I do not detach completely. I find my peace in going back to family, the people I love, and in counting my blessings.When asked, which of her best friends doesn’t respond to her calls or chats immediately, Ananya says, “I always try to reach out to Suhana, on various social networking platforms, but she almost never responds immediately.” (Laughs)I love Bengaluru. It is a lovely, creative, clean city to be in. I'm excited to be here and I hope that I come back soon.In Video: Ananya Panday in Bengaluru

Title: A night of dazzling talent and glamour in Bengaluru
Content: Saturday night saw Bengaluru play host to a stellar night of talent and high fashion. The contestants of LIVA Miss Diva 2020 took to the stage and showcased their talents. The night saw the Divas compete for the ‘most talented’ title. The competition saw the girls showcase their talent that ranged from poetry recitation and singing to belly dancing and even some graceful Indian classical dance. To judge the competition was a jury that comprised actress Ragini Dwivedi , singer Behram Siganporia , actor and Mr India 2015 1st Runner-up Rahul Rajasekharan Nair and designer Abhishek Sharma . The talented contestants had the crowd and judges cheering loudly for them. The sub-contest was followed by a scintillating party. Singer Anushka Manchanda regaled everyone with her unique set that included some popular Bollywood songs too. The night also had actress and Miss Supranational 2016 Srinidhi Shetty walk the ramp as the showstopper, as the young aspirants cheered her on. The Oterra Hotel played the perfect host for the night as the hospitality and venue partner.

Title: I did Gentleman because it has a story that needs to be told: Nishvika Naidu
Content: In the two years that she’s been a part of the Kannada film industry, Nishvika Naidu has ensured that she is a force to reckon with, which should explain why filmmakers choose to collaborate with her on multiple projects. Her release this week, Gentleman, is a case in point, given that she was made the offer after working with filmmaker Guru Deshpande , who has backed this one, on his directorial, Paddehuli . Interestingly, Guru has given Nishvika a rather serious role this time around. Apart from the fact that she plays lead hero Prajwal Devaraj ’s love interest, Nishvika also gets to get into the skin of a nutritionist, Tapaswini, who is extremely health conscious. “Since my debut, the roles I have done have always been of bubbly, hyperactive girl, which is pretty much in sync with how I am in real life. In Gentleman, though, Tapaswini is more serious and mature; she is the responsible member of the household, who, on account of what she does in her career, is also very conscious about the food choices her family makes. Given that this is in stark contrast to my personality, it was difficult to play this character at first. Director Jadesh Kumar would ask me to ‘tone down’ during sequences. I had to be constantly reminded that I was Tapaswini,”she laughs.”Although Nishvika is the romantic interest in the film, it also has a serious undertone, given that it deals with the protagonist’s medical condition and a hitherto unexplored human egg trafficking angle. So, what was it about Gentleman that appealed to her? “As actors, it is important to choose movies that are more than just glitz and glam and have a worthy social message. I took up this movie, not so much for my career prospect, but because it had a story that needed to be told,”explains Nishvika.

Title: Mohammad Ali Baig joins the cast of Vikram’s Cobra
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Haute on the red carpet at this Bengaluru event
Content: Recently, Kareena Kapoor Khan announced the big breaking news of her second pregnancy with hubby Saif Ali Khan. While fans, friends, and family of the gorgeous diva seem to be growing impatient for the upcoming little bundle of joy who’s expected to arrive by late February to March 2021, one must also recall Bebo’s first pregnancy days when she was carrying her munchkin, Taimur Ali Khan. No doubt, she was a complete stunner in her first pregnancy glow, meanwhile, if the actress is looking for some inspiration for her second round, here’s a list of five celebrities from whom Bebo can take fashion inspirations to ace her maternity look once again. From the supermodel, Gigi Hadid to ace singers like Katy Perry and Beyonce, this list covers some of the most fashionable mommies and mummy-to-be.Photo credit: Instagram

Title: Sivakarthikeyan & I bond over cricket: Sharad Kelkar
Content: Hindi film actor Sharad Kelkar , who will be making his Tamil debut with Sivakarthikeyan and Ravikumar ’s upcoming film, assures that it will be a breath of fresh air for audiences. “It is a one-of-a-kind sci-film with a lot of visual effects. It will definitely be one of the most unique films of Tamil cinema,” the Goliyon Ki Raasleela Ram-Leela actor says.The actor, who is currently shooting for the yet-to-be-titled Rakul Preet-starrer in Chennai, adds that his first Tamil film experience is proving to be memorable. “People are extremely sweet and disciplined. I am also enjoying the emotion of Tamil Nadu . It has been a great experience,” Sharad says, adding that he bonded with Sivakarthikeyan over cricket “Siva is a fun, charming guy. We share similar interests and one of them is cricket. Even today, we were sitting and watching the match,” he says with a laugh, “Ravi sir is the most innocent guy I have ever met. He is very hard-working and knows his stuff. He has the potential and vision to become one of the biggest directors in the industry.”

Title: If I’m accepted as Jayalalithaa, I want to do a film on Kannagi next: Kangana Ranaut
Content: For many actors, okaying a shot in a single take is a matter of pride. But for Kangana Ranaut , it’s the satisfaction of getting the scene right that counts. Even if it’s just an expression that comes for a fraction of a second in a whole song sequence! The actress is shooting in Chennai for Vijay ’s Thalaivi , a biopic on former actress and CM of Tamil Nadu, J Jayalalithaa , and we saw her requesting the team for retakes until both she and the director were happy with the outcome. Taking a chair by the side of a beautifully done up stage, she continues to practise her hand movements and expressions for a few minutes before speaking to us about why she was kicked about doing another biopic, the challenges of playing a real-life person, how she reacts to criticism and more. Excerpts:Actually, I’m still processing it. I’m absolutely grateful to people, and those who thought I deserved it. I’m also thankful to every one of them who have loved me. I believe I have been very unconventional in my journey, from when I started to now receiving the Padma. It has been full of very extreme highs and very extreme lows, and I’m glad that people have seen me through all of that. So yes, this has not been something that I expected to start my year with, for sure.Even in Once Upon A Time In Mumbaai, my role was loosely based on Madhubala. But after Manikarnika: The Queen of Jhansi, this is my next proper biopic. It’s not that I choose these roles. I can say I’m only fortunate because I’ve been able to have this opportunity.I’ve also put on a few kilos (smiles). I’d done Dhaam Dhoom long ago, and I never had the opportunity to tap into this region, especially Tamil Nadu, after that. My films do well in the north, but I wanted to connect with the audience in the south. I think this is a great opportunity for that. I really want to do more work here.Apart from my personal liking for her, it’s the very extraordinary life that she lived, and the extraordinary perseverance and strength that she showed in the face of adversity… these are truly remarkable. But of course, you need to see if it makes sense cinematically as well. When I choose to do a film, I see what’s there in it for the audience more than what’s there in it for me. I feel that her journey makes for an exceptionally good screenplay, in terms of cinema and politics blending into each other.Yes, for instance, the culture is very, very different here. Amma has been a sensational, most loved superstar. When I did my research on her, I found out what an icon she was... the way she carried herself, she’s also a style icon. She never did timid characters on screen, she was a trailblazer. To become Amma is an interesting arc, but a difficult arc to achieve.We have just started the film. When it comes out, that’s when people get to actually see the complete product and react.Oh yes, and it is amazing to be working with him. Their relationship (between Jayalalithaa and MGR , played by Arvind Swami) is layered. It’s an intense relationship between friends, mentor (and his protégée) and much more. And when they are both in politics, it also becomes competitive. This kind of dynamic relationship that they share has many shades… amicable, admiration, mentoring, and then, goes on to become a competition of sorts. It’s extraordinary. And Arvind Swami is such a subtle artiste who can pull off any scene with ease. What he brings to the film is very amazing and we are fortunate to get the casting right.The kind of films I’ve started to do in Bollywood, I need that kind of script here as well. I’m not ready to play second fiddle to the hero. I hear it happens in the south, like it happens in Mumbai as well. But the other day, I was telling Vijay sir that he has to make a film on this iconic lady who’s worshipped here — Kannagi. If I’m accepted as Jayalalithaa, I want him to make Kannagi for me. She’s such an iconic character, such a strong woman, and it will make for an epic drama. But I want to do that film only in Tamil. Hopefully, it should manifest.Vijayendra Prasad sir (writer of the film) was researching on Jayalalithaa, and I heard it from him (smiles).

Title: Mallika to play a modern-day queen in her Kollywood comeback
Content: She’s no stranger to Kollywood — she’s impressed us with her acting chops in Kamal Haasan-starrer Dasavatharam and her dance moves in Simbu ’s Osthe. Now, Mallika Sherawat is all set to return to the industry with a Tamil film, Pambattam , in which she plays a queen. Starring Jeevan in the lead, the horror-thriller is being made in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kannada and Hindi.Confirming the news, director VC Vadivudaiyan tells us, “I met Mallika a week ago in Mumbai with the script. When she heard the narration, she immediately agreed to come on board. She had taken a break for a few years and was telling me that she was keen to do a film only if it offered her enough scope to perform. And this one will give her just that – she plays a modern-day queen and her character travels throughout the script.”The team is paying special attention to draft her look. “We have elaborate costumes for her,” he says, “She will also have action blocks. So, she’s working out harder to attain that physique. We are confident that she will score with her performance in this film.” Mallika will start shooting for her portions by the end of this month. “We’ll shoot her scenes in Hyderabad, Bengaluru and also in South Africa,” he informs.

Title: Big sports events today
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

(Reuters Photo)

Title: FC Goa players maintain calm as new coaching team takes over
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Panaji: For anyone who had walked inside the GMC Athletic Stadium at Bambolim and heard FC Goa players laugh their heart out, he might have been left to wonder what the fuss is all about.

FC Goa have sacked their most successful coach Sergio Lobera , assistant coach Jesus Tato and conditioning coach Manuel Sayabera, but there was no funeral silence when interim coach Derrick Pereira and new conditioning coach Roman Cunnilera conducted their first training session on Sunday.

After two days of uncertainty when training was hastily cancelled as the club sat down with Lobera to terminate contracts, the players assembled again, this time to be greeted by Pereira, the club’s technical director and formerly assistant to Lobera during his first season here.

There was also the new conditioning coach. First to land at the stadium, Roman – who worked as assistant to Chelsea FC legend Claude Makele at Belgian top-tier club Eupen – made his presence felt and is understood to have told the club that a few changes are necessary to get the best out of the players.

On Sunday, neither Derrick nor Roman tried anything different to what was being done by the Spanish coaching team. If at all, everyone was told that they cannot afford to have any distractions at this stage, particularly when they are possibly three wins away from finishing on top and making it to the AFC Champions League.

If the players were unhappy, they did best not to show. The mood seemed just fine.

Derrick had a quiet word with Spanish defender Carlos Pena, the undisputed leader of the dressing room, before start of training, and then got the team together.

For the entire FC Goa contingent watching from the stands, this was a good sight. Players gave their all; Ahmed Jahouh connected an astonishingly good volley, goalkeeper Mohammed Nawaz showed ice-cool nerves while controlling the ball and Manvir Singh was among the goals – scored with his foot – during a small-sided game.

The bigger test, though, will be on Wednesday. And only then will everyone know if all is well with FC Goa.

Title: Nominations for the 65th Filmfare Awards 2020 are out!
Content: The wait is over and the nominations for the impending 65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020 have been announced. The list of nominations for India's most awaited award night, which will be held on February 15 in Guwahati, was officially brought out at the Filmfare Technical Awards' Night held at a suburban five-star hotel with a bevvy of Bollywood stars and some of the best minds in the business under the same roof, applauding one another. The event celebrated the nominees and technical award winners. Also the nominations were announced in 19 key categories, soon after the Technical Awards were given away.Team Kabir Singh and Sonchiriya made for the most enthusiastic part of the audience that cheered even for those people who were not a part of their crew. Neha Dhupia, who anchored the show, pulled off the nomination announcement with a lot of wit and humour.And the nominees are:Article 15 - Anubhav Sinha, Gaurav SolankiChhichhore - Nitesh Tiwari, Piyush Gupta and Nikhil Mehrotra Gully Boy - Zoya Akhtar, Reema KagtiMard Ko Dard Nahi Hota - Vasan BalaMission Mangal - Jagan Shakti,Sonchiriya - Abhishek Chaubey and Sudip SharmaArticle 15 - Anubhav Sinha, Gaurav SolankiGully Boy - Reema Kagti, Zoya AkhtarMission Mangal - Title: Delhi's Jamia university firing: Police register case against unidentified miscreants
Content:
Jamia students and locals gherao Jamia Nagar police station after another shooting incident

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police have registered a case after two unidentified persons allegedly opened fire outside Jamia Millia Islamia on Sunday night, police said.No one was injured in the attack.In a statement issued by the Jamia Coordination Committee (JCC), a group comprising students and alumni of the university formed to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act, said the attackers were on a red motorcycle.One of the miscreants was wearing a red jacket, the statement said.A senior police official said a case of attempt to murder under relevant sections of the IPC and the Arms Act was registered in connection with the incident and an investigation is underway.This is the third firing incident in the Jamia Nagar area in a week.On Thursday, a minor fired at anti-CAA protesters preparing to march from Jamia towards the Rajghat, injuring a student.Two days later, a 25-year-old fired two rounds in air at Shaheen Bagh, where a protest against the new citizenship law has been going on. No one was hurt in the incident."Firing has taken place at Gate No. 5 of Jamia Millia Islamia ... by two unidentified persons. As per report, one of them was wearing a red jacket and driving a red scooter having vehicle no. 1532 or 1534," the statement said.Asim Mohammed Khan, a former Congress MLA from Okhla, said the incident occurred around 11.30 pm."We heard the gunshot. That is when we stepped out to see and the two men left on a scooter," a student said."We have taken down the vehicle number and called police," he added.In Video: Delhi: 2 unidentified persons open fire at anti-CAA protestors near Jamia Millia Islamia

Title: 65th Filmfare Awards 2020: Technical and Short Films Awards Announced!
Content: The 65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020, technical category, was announced in Mumbai tonight (Feb 2). While the main event is set to roll out on Feb 15 in Guwahati, Assam, B-Town celebrities walked down the red carpet in support of technicians at the event held at a five star hotel. Those who were seen at the do include Kareena Kapoor Khan Sonam Kapoor , Farhan Akhtar, Ananya Pandey , Vidya Balan, Karan Johar , Alaya F, Siddhanth Chaturvedi among others.The event which was hosted by Neha Dhupia , also gave a tribute to the well-known fashion and costume designer Manish Malhotra as he completed 30 years in Bollywood. His achievements were celebrated with models displaying the costumes of his best work from his movies which include Kuch Kuch Hota Hai, Kal Ho Na Ho, Om Shanti Om, Main Hoon Na among others.While presenting the award to Manish, good friend Kareena said, "My journey as well as every Hindi film actress's journey is incomplete without you. You are my dearest friend and brother!" Manish said, "As a child I loved movies and they loved me back. This award is much more special because I am receiving it from Karan Johar and Kareena. I am working with new generation of actresses like Ananya Pandey and Tara Sutaria and they are barred from calling me uncle (laughs)."From the technical category those who walked away with the awards includeBest Action Award: Paul Jennings, Oh Sea Young, Parvez Shaikh and Franz Spilhaus for WarBest Background Score: Karsh Kale And The Salvage Audio Collective for Gully Boy Best Production Design: Suzanne Caplan Merwanji for Gully BoyBest Costume: Divvya Gambhir, Niddhi Gambhir for SonchiriyaBest Choreography: Remo D'Souza for Kalank (Ghar More Pardesiya)Best Editing: Shivkumar V Panicker for Uri: The Surgical StrikeBest Cinematography: Jay Oza for Gully BoyBest Sound Design: Bishwadeep Dipak Chatterjee and Nihar Ranjan Samal for Uri: The Surgical StrikeBest VFX: Sherry Bharda And Vishal Anand for YFX, War.The award show also honoured films in the short category, which included 20 minutes long short films. The winners includedBest Short Film Fiction: Shazia Iqbal for BebaakBest Short Film Non-Fiction: Ananth Narayan Mahadevan for Village Of A Lesser GodBest Actor Male Short Film: Rajesh Sharma for TindeyBest Actor Female Short Film: Sarah Hashmi for BebaakPeople's Choice Award for Best Short Film: Deshi

Title: Adnan Sami: You may have your own principles or your own beliefs but that doesn’t mean that you cannot respect somebody else’s beliefs
Content: Adnan Sami's Padma Shri ran into controversy on two grounds. One, does his body of work merit it? That, however, is a question that comes up each year for one or more recipients, irrespective of the regime in power. The second question, however, is not so common – should a man whose father fought against India in a war be feted by the Indian state? When Adnan spoke to us last year, he recurrently emphasised the point that he was "loyal to India because of what my father taught me". We ask him to comment on the recent outrage."See, if you have been indoctrinated with a particular belief or principle... it's like this... once you have learnt engineering after that you apply that skill to a Maruti or a Mercedes, the principle is the same, right, because the education that you got was basically for an engine. So the indoctrination that I got from my father of the concept of loyalty, patriotism etc... he used it in his capacity, in his life for the country that he belonged to and he instilled those principles in me. Today, I am an Indian and the DNA of my upbringing and the principles that have been indoctrinated in me – I am using exactly the same principles but adopting it to my country. And so my sense of loyalty is absolutely intact, but for the country that I belong to," he explains.Adnan was born in the UK, his spouse is German. We put a question to him, hoping for insight: During and after WW2, nations in Europe fought bitterly, even viciously, and political and ethnic boundaries were drawn, erased, redrawn. Yet, they have been able to function collectively, even build an EU that is close to borderless – even after Brexit – without the fallout of the hatred and killing in the 1940s. How did they reintegrate while the subcontinent still simmers in the animosity of the 1940s? "It's a very interesting question, which I have pondered over." He pauses for a bit."And I think, I mean it's just my opinion... When Germany finally woke up and realised the horror of what their leaders had done... you see, the Nazis and Hitler, in particular, with the level of oratory skills that he had, had managed to convince the masses of their superiority, the Aryan race and the white supremacy that he had advocated and the illusions that he had created that we are going to take over the world – all of that came tumbling down at the defeat. And thereafter, with the entire world teaming up against Germany and telling them what a horrid leader they had, and the horror that he inflicted upon humanity and so on, somewhere the Germans realised ki yaar humne waaqyi bahut zyadti ki hai. Therefore, they were on an extreme back foot and they admitted defeat, they accepted humiliation and with that acceptance, they went and sought forgiveness. And when that happened, you know, humanity is such that when you do have that closure whereby the other person has admitted their mistake, things settle... If you speak to a German and you start talking about Nazis, the average German is gonna feel very embarrassed because of his history. I know this because I live there... live in the sense that I have got family there and as a result I have German friends. I know this. Today if you mention Hitler, they will feel very ashamed because they've realised what a monster he was. Now, in comparison, yahan pe there has been no such thing. Nobody has accepted defeat, nobody has accepted their mistake, nobody has turned around and made any apologies. Every time there has been a possibility of a handshake, the Pakistan Army decides to step in and do a Kargil or whatever in order to sabotage any possibility of reconciliation. It doesn't suit them to have a reconciliation because then it's going to have repercussions on their economy."Even his Padma award became a discussion about India and Pakistan. "When has there ever not been a discussion of India-Pakistan?" he laughs. "That is a perpetual discussion going on ever since Partition; it's not a new phenomenon".That may be true, but Hindu-Muslim, majority-minority has perhaps not been as much of a perpetual discussion as it seems to be presently. As someone who moved from a 'majority' status to a 'minority' one by choice, what learnings and experiences does he have to share with us? How has been his association with those not of his faith after he moved to India?"When it comes to my relationship with people in India, I have, frankly speaking, never been able to differentiate in my day to day dealings with people from different walks of life. I am not even able to sometimes tell what faith they belong to unless somewhere in the conversation or at the end of the conversation, the person turns around and says Allah hafiz or Khuda hafiz. I will only then get to know that he might be a Muslim. I have so many friends who are Hindu but they will say Khuda hafiz to me. There is no difference ki main goodbye kahoon ya namaskar kahoon ya Khuda hafiz kahoon, mere liye ek hi hai."And that does not make either of the two parties traitors to their respective cultures, does it?"Of course not, of course not!” He exclaims. "The most beautiful thing in our country is that a Hindu will celebrate Eid with me, I will celebrate Diwali or Holi with him and all of us collectively will celebrate Christmas. Mere bahut saare dost joh Hindu hain woh Eid ke dauran aake kehte hain, ' achha yaar sevaiyaan bhej rahe ho na?' ya 'biryani bhej rahe ho na?'. Aur hum unki Diwali ki mithaai bade shauk se khaate hain. And now that Medina (his daughter) is with us, I was telling my wife that next year we must have a Christmas tree in the house. It's just such a beautiful thing for the child."What faith will Medina grow up to embrace? Will she be able to celebrate both Eid and Christmas or is that no longer politically correct in the times the world is living in?“My child will grow up just like me. She will be able to embrace all and respect all faiths because that’s the way I have been brought up. When I was studying in England, in boarding school, the day used to start with the entire school going to the chapel. I grew up with all of those different faiths. My upbringing instilled in me to respect all faiths because at the end of the day, if you look at all faiths, the basic teaching of every faith is the same, love thy neighbour, don’t do to others what you wouldn’t have done to yourself. Which faith turns around and says that make sure that you sleep with your belly full while your neighbour is hungry? So these are the principles with which I intend to bring up Medina and that’s the way it should be.”"The most beautiful thing in our country is that a Hindu will celebrate Eid with me, I will celebrate Diwali or Holi with him and all of us collectively will celebrate Christmas," says Adnan Sami How do these principles play out in real life, beyond the words?“I had gone to Israel just last year and I went to Jerusalem, I visited Masjid-E-Aqsa, I visited the Wailing Wall, which is for the Jews, and I also went on the ziyarat of Jesus Christ and paid my respects in all of these different places with the same sanctity. So that’s the way I am. Jab yahan pe Ganpati hota hai toh humein har taraf se daawatein aati hain ki please come and visit us and we go. The point is that you respect all faiths. You may have your own principles or your own beliefs but that doesn’t mean that you cannot respect somebody else’s beliefs. To each his own. That’s the way I have been brought up and that is also the most beautiful thing about our country that we respect this,” concludes the expressive musician, who often reiterates that art is beyond politics.

Title: TV actor Anurag Sharma marries Nandini Gupta
Content: TV actor Anurag Sharma got married to his longtime girlfriend Nandini Gupta in Delhi on Friday. The wedding celebrations kick-started with a haldi and mehendi ceremony from January 29, followed by a ring ceremony the next day.During the haldi ceremony, the couple complemented each other in yellow outfits, and Nandini was spotted applying haldi on the groom’s face. The ring ceremony was inspired by a Catholic wedding, with the bride wearing a white gown and the groom sporting a tuxedo.On the wedding day, Anurag wore a cream-coloured sherwani with a matching safa, while Nandini wore a red lehenga. She even got emotional and teary-eyed as she walked towards the mandap. Anurag said, “The feeling of being married is yet to sink in. I have known Nandini for five years now and we are good friends. In fact,it feels like my best friend is now my wife. The wedding was fun, as we spent quality time with family and friends.”The couple will fly to Phuket, Thailand for their honeymoon.

Title: Disha Patani: I am a tomboy at heart and I go back to being that every single day
Content: On the internet, she appears to be a diva. In person, she’s a tomboy who loves wearing her hair messily, slips into comfy and functional clothes and hops across to a cafe to get herself a cuppa coffee. In a chat with BT, Disha Patani talks about living life on the edge, her social media image, why it’s important to strike a balance between work and life and of course, her sizzling chemistry with co-star Aditya Roy Kapur in Mohit Suri ’s upcoming film, ' Malang '. Read on...I hope the year goes well. Even after doing a few films, I feel like a newcomer. With every film that works, expectations rise, which is a little daunting. For instance, I love dancing, but when I do it on screen, it’s not for myself. I don’t pick up choreography easily; I rehearse a lot to perfect it. I have to keep my body energised, monitor my diet and put in hours on the floor, but when the results are great, it’s relieving.(Laughs!) I actually enjoy working out. There’s no better feeling than not having backaches. I have bruised my knees so many times that today, I know the value of keeping my leg muscles in order. Fitness plays a different role in my life. I am sure people think that I do it so I can look a certain way, but with the kind of lives we lead, it’s just so important to stay healthy all the time. I work hard on my body all the time and it makes my dance and action look effortless.Yes, I knew him socially before we started working together. We had met many years ago in a gym where we would workout together. It was a little awkward to meet him as a co-star. If you’ve known someone for a long time, it becomes weird to act with them. In Aditya’s case, it was fun. As buddies, off camera, we took each other’s case. As actors, it was important to get rid of the awkwardness while performing passionate or deeply romantic scenes with conviction. In our case, we just acted our parts out without any strategy in place. We didn’t even chat about the scenes; we just took the plunge. Talking about them would have been stranger.We had very little training for it. Water-surfing and kitesurfing can be difficult; in fact, the latter can be life-threatening, as you could bang yourself into a tree or die in a road mishap because it entirely relies on the kite and the wind. You need years of training to perfect it. Water-surfing is relatively easier. On one occasion, I had to jump from a hill into the water. I was shaking the first time I had to do it for the camera. I injured my head and was hard of hearing for the whole day. I had almost died when I tried that from a smaller height in a swimming pool as a kid. So, it all looks like we were having fun, but it was stressful. Personally, I love doing crazy things but here, we were pushed to just do everything without much training.I don’t read much of what’s written about me. Not following news updates just keeps me peaceful. I’ve always kept my life away from the work I do. In this industry, wherever you go, people talk shop. You need to balance that with a simple life where you go back home to other normal things. We’re not just actors, we’re human beings, too. My friends and I don’t talk work when we meet, even though some of us are in the same business. We play video games and chill. When I’m not working, I walk into cafes and buy coffee for myself. I’m usually in messy, relaxed, workout clothes, with no make-up and hair tied in a bun or something. Dressing up is like a little break from that, when I want to be my cute or pretty self. At heart, I am a tomboy and I go back to being that every single day.I don’t Google myself, so I don’t know who says what. Earlier I thought that I’m an actor and my job is to just play a part. But actually, I also have to be entertaining when I meet people, and say these cool and funny things. I’m a boring person and I find it very hard to be funny and gimmicky. As for clothes, at the beginning of the career, you want to dress up and look a certain way. With time, you realise it doesn’t matter. No matter what you do, people will always have something to say. The idea is to be yourself and do what you like.Not entirely, but in some way I can say that I have. The decision to come to Mumbai, opting for a career in modelling and acting over completing B.Tech was like living on the edge. I am not as young as I was in those days. I was more carefree then and I made decisions which probably, I wouldn’t make today. The decisions worked for me, but now, I am relatively playing it safe. The older you grow the more you start thinking. Of course, sometimes it’s best not to think and go for what your heart says. What’s the worst that can happen? You have to strike a balance between these two spaces — being on the edge and playing it safe. I live alone here, all by myself with my dogs and cats, who are my responsibilities.

Title: Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan’s new song celebrates romance
Content: Valentine’s Day is around the corner and the makers of ' Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan ' are all set to release their new romantic track just in time for the special day. Titled Mere Liye Tum Kafi Ho, the soulful number is picturised on the lead couple in the film — Ayushmann Khurrana and Jitendra Kumar . The track, which releases tomorrow, has been composed by Tanishq Bagchi and Vayu, and sung by Ayushmann.The actor-singer says, “Mere Liye Tum Kafi Ho is conversational and at the same time, takes the narrative forward. It brings out the chemistry between the two boys.”He adds, “This is just another love song between two people, and that could be between two men, two women or a man and a woman. There is no difference, because the idea is to break stereotypes and normalise it as much as possible.”Talking about lending his voice to this track, he adds, “By default, I sing one song in the soundtrack of my films, because I love to sing. Besides, when you are lending your voice to your character, it sounds more credible and believable. For me, the criteria to choose a song — whether it is in Hindi, Punjabi or any other language — is that it should connect with me. I have a certain voice texture that goes well with soft romantic numbers. I love singing Punjabi songs, but lately, most of my songs have been Hindi or Urdu, including Ik Mulaqaat from 'Article 15' and now, this one.”The film directed by Hitesh Kewalya also features Neena Gupta and Gajraj Rao , among others.

Title: Between 2 tax regimes, no one will be worse off: Revenue secretary
Content: NEW DELHI: Explaining the rationale to offer taxpayers a choice between a flat rate and an itemised deduction system, the government on Sunday said the new income tax rates would not make anyone worse off and the move allowed taxpayers to decide which regime suited them depending on their interests.In an interview with TOI , revenue secretary Ajay Bhushan Pandey said the government’s move would benefit a large section of population, such as seniors who did not want to park money in tax-saving instruments and had paid down housing loans or youngsters just joining the workforce. Such people do not have substantial amounts to purchase life covers or deposit money in public provident fund (PPF).Data available with the tax department showed that of the around 5.8 crore people who filed returns for fiscal year 2018-19, 5.3 crore claimed income tax deductions of less than Rs 2 lakh, including deduction under section 80C of the Income Tax Act (for provident fund, PPF, life insurance premium), section 80D (mediclaim insurance), section 80CCD(1B) (additional deduction for National Pension Scheme ), deduction for housing loan interest and standard deduction .The Budget announcement of a new structure, promising lower income tax rates for those who give up exemptions with allowances such as HRA and leave travel added to their income, has generated considerable debate. While the government says the move will benefit a large section, analysts say a significant part of the salaried middle-class may not gain by transitioning to the new system.“We see that a meagre 3.77 lakh taxpayers have claimed deductions exceeding Rs 4 lakh... the choice is with the taxpayers — choose the old regime or the new one. Not a single taxpayer is going to lose in the process,” Pandey said, adding that the proposed system would make life simpler for those who opted for it. He said the assumption that all exemptions be taken into account for all slabs did not reflect in actual filings.He said the government would need more resources to ensure that all or most taxpayers are better off. The current exercise is estimated to result in a Rs 40,000 crore loss. “Ideally, we should bring down the tax rate to a level that everyone benefits. Given fiscal constraints, this is not possible,” Pandey said, adding that the government may lower rates and wipe out exemptions when revenues stabilise.

Title: Nirbhaya case convicts testing India’s patience: Centre
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre told the Delhi HC on Sunday the four Nirbhaya case convicts were “trying to test the patience of the nation” and pressed for a stay on an order postponing their hanging. Citing the 2019 gangrape and murder of a Hyderabad vet after which the four accused were killed by police in an alleged encounter and subsequent public celebrations, Solicitor general Tushar Mehta said, “It shows people losing faith in the criminal justice-delivery system.”On Saturday, the court had issued a notice to the four convicts — Mukesh Singh , Vinay Sharma , Akshay Thakur and Pawan Gupta — to respond to government’s plea seeking their immediate execution and setting aside of the trial court’s order staying the hanging scheduled for February 1.The Centre accused the convicts of adopting delaying tactics to delay the inevitable. It said the convicts had committed an “abhorrent” act and its logical conclusion of a death sentence was confirmed by all courts.Mehta revisited the night of the crime and highlighted the cruelty inflicted upon the woman and how she was thrown off a bus and left to die on the road. In his opinion, a convict with sheer, calculated inaction, in tandem with other convicts, could frustrate the process of law. The Centre’s counsel also argued that seven years had passed but the convicts were still “playing” with the machinery of the judicial system.Arguing on the point of the legal remedy of a mercy plea before the President, he said such a plea could be decided differently for different convicts. “Mercy jurisdiction is an individualistic jurisdiction. They can’t rely on the mercy plea with the President and say if one convict’s mercy is allowed, there could be a change of circumstances for the others,” Mehta argued.This point was vehemently opposed by senior advocate Rebecca John , who represented convict Mukesh Singh. “Assuming that the President was to pardon one person, to say that it won’t have an effect on me is absolutely wrong,” she added.John asked where the Centre was all this while during the warrant proceedings and why it had only “woken up” yesterday. “We are taking a life from a human being… And, therefore, the Constitution gives me the option of legal remedies. You keep saying delay, delay, delay... but you (Centre) never entered the trial court. Even death-row convicts have rights. They have rights to use their remedies and use it till their last breath of their lives,” she submitted.She also asked if Delhi government had moved court seeking issuance of a death warrant in the last several years. John, who appeared along with advocate Vrinda Grover , objected to the Centre moving the high court challenging the order of the postponement of the hangings when it ought to have gone to Supreme Court. She underlined an argument given by the high court in an earlier order about how the trial court was taking the view of Supreme Court in connection with the hanging to a logical end.John, therefore, argued that when the first date of execution was sought to be stayed in view of a mercy plea, the high court had stated that it could not decide any grievance with respect to the death warrants. “When I, a death row convict, was asked to approach Supreme Court... the same rule applies to the other party as well. This petition is not maintainable before the high court,” she said.The victim’s family had moved the trial court seeking issuance of death warrants in December 2018 and John stated that from that time till January 2020, the Centre was never a party to the warrant proceedings. “This is the first time [sic] Union of India has superimposed themselves in these proceedings. What's their locus and why they have done so is a matter of court to examine,” she said.John also submitted when the trial court set February 1, 2020, as the date of hanging on January 17, it set the time for all four convicts and not one. “It didn’t bifurcate the dates... What is the tearing hurry? The execution could happen at any point in time — whether a few days, or a week or a month. I’m a making a statement against myself. I’m the most horrible person, committed most heinous crime, but I am still protected under Article 21,” John said.The high court reserved its order after the arguments.In Video: Nirbhaya case: Delhi HC reserves order on Centre's plea challenging stay on execution of 4 death row convicts

Title: Kerala confirms 2nd coronavirus case, patient stable
Content:
File photo

ALAPPUZHA/THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala reported the country’s second novel coronavirus case on Sunday, with a male student of a university in Wuhan admitted to Alappuzha medical college hospital testing positive for the virus . The first case, that of a woman medical student who is undergoing treatment, was reported in Thrissur on Thursday.State health minister K K Shailaja told reporters after a meeting in Alappuzha that the second person who tested positive — one among four admitted to the isolation ward at Alappuzha medical college hospital — had returned to Kerala on January 24. “Three of those admitted were studying in China while the fourth person is a relative of one of them. We are waiting for test reports of the others,” she said.Shailaja said there was no need for panic as the condition of both patients was stable.The health department received the test result of the infected person from National Institute of Virology, Pune, on Sunday afternoon. “Neither of the two patients has developed any serious complications. There is nothing to panic but we need to be vigilant. The department is strictly monitoring the situation so that the virus does not spread from them,” Shailaja said.The Kerala health department has put 1,924 people under observation at their homes and 75 have been admitted to isolation wards in various hospitals. Till now, 104 samples of suspected cases have been sent for tests. Of these, 36 results have been received and two tested positive. In Alappuzha, four persons have also been admitted to the general hospital.All those coming from China are under health department surveillance. “The only request to people is that if anyone who has come from China recently has not reported to the nearby health centre so far, they should immediately do so,” Shailaja said.The Union health ministry and the India Council of Medical Research have permitted the Kerala unit of National Institute of Virology in Alappuzha to conduct tests for coronavirus. “Though we have facilities, we were not supposed to conduct the tests. There was a delay in getting test results from Pune NIV,” Shailaja said.Wuhan in China is the ground zero of the virus outbreak which had infected over 14,500 people and led to 305 deaths till Sunday evening. Despite strong measures to contain the outbreak, including the Chinese government locking down Wuhan and adjoining cities in Hubei province, the virus continues to spread rapidly.Apart from China, the virus has been detected in at least 21 countries, including India.Amid mounting fear of a wider spread, the Union health ministry has asked hospitals across all states and Union territories to prepare isolation wards.In Video: Second case of coronavirus confirmed in Kerala on Sunday

Title: Govt suspends e-visa facility for those travelling from China
Content:
Medical staffs scan the body temperature of passengers at Delhi Airport (ANI)

NEW DELHI: As the coronavirus epidemic gathered intensity with over 305 recorded deaths in China alone, India on Sunday suspended e-visa facility for Chinese travellers and foreigners travelling from China.“Due to certain current developments, travel to India on e-visas stands temporarily suspended with immediate effect,” the Indian Embassy in Beijing announced on Twitter. “This applies to holders of Chinese passports and applicants of other nationalities residing in the People's Republic of China. Holders of already issued e-visas may note that these are no longer valid,” it added.While India has not yet suspended flights as the US has done, the Indian embassy in Beijing has left a window open for emergency/important travellers from China to India. “All those who have a compelling reason to visit India may contact the embassy of India in Beijing or the Indian consulates in Shanghai or Guangzhou , as well as the Indian visa application centres in these cities,“ the statement said.An additional concern emerged on Sunday when the Chinese government said it was tackling a bird flu outbreak in Hunan province , which is adjacent to Hubei province, the scene of the coronavirus outbreak.On Sunday, India airlifted a second batch of 323 stranded Indians and seven Maldivian citizens from Wuhan, taking the number of people evacuated to 654. Air India 's 747 jumbo jet made two flights to Wuhan — ground zero of the coronavirus epidemic. In the first flight early on Saturday, 324 Indians were evacuated though a couple of people who showed symptoms like fever had to be left behind. Those who returned have been kept in quarantine for two weeks, before they are allowed out.Foreign minister S Jaishankar tweeted on Sunday, “Seven Maldivians brought back with 323 Indians from Wuhan on the second Air India flight today. Neighbourhood First at work again.” Maldives President Ibrahim Solih thanked the Indian government for the assistance.India had already started scanning visitors from China and Hong Kong. This has been expanded to travellers from Singapore and Thailand as well. So far, the virus has infected almost 15,000 people, while the first death outside China was recorded in the Philippines. Two Indians, both from Kerala , have tested positive for novel coronavirus.In the initial days, the government had said there were almost 1,200 Indian nationals in Hubei province.

Title: Amritsar: Three inmates dig hole in barrack, scale walls to flee high-security jail
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

Title: Coronavirus latest news: On rescue operation, Air India left nothing to chance
Content: NEW DELHI: Air India ’s second evacuation flight flew in 323 Indians and seven citizens of Maldives from Wuhan, the epicentre of the coronavirus epidemic, to Delhi on Sunday morning.The total number of people brought in the two flights is 654 — 647 Indians and seven foreigners.The jumbo jets used for this special operation, Ajanta and Agra, are now being fumigated and will be used for regular commercial flights after they are fully disinfected.With both these aircraft being over 25 years old, AI took critical spare parts like tyres on the flights from Delhi with engineers to minimise the chance of their getting grounded there for technical reasons. Captain Amitabh Singh , AI’s director (operations), was on both the back-to-back flights to supervise the evacuation. He and another AI employee, Sanjay Gupta , were the only two people on both the flights. “Flying into Wuhan on the first flight was like witnessing apocalypse. As soon as we exited the international overflying routes in China to head to Wuhan, there was no other air traffic there at that time. On landing, we saw planes parked with their engines sealed off. It was eerie,” Singh told TOI.The airline’s control centre in Delhi was constantly tracking the flights. With limited staff at the airport and three levels of pre-boarding health checks for passengers, Air India’s first and second flights spent six and eight hours, respectively, on-ground at Wuhan airport before flying back to Delhi.“There is a risk of infection involved on these flights. The same was communicated to the crew as their enlistment was sought on a voluntary basis, but they did not hesitate even for a moment,” Singh said.Air India staff who fumigated these aircraft were given full protection suit to do the job.

Title: Mob sets shrine on fire in Bihar over JD(U) neta’s killing
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

BIHARSHARIF: Irked over the murder of a JD(U) member, Amit Vashisht , in Sheikhpura village on Saturday night, party workers and supporters set on fire a religious place in Sheikhpura on Sunday. Local residents and police doused the fire that left the shrine partially damaged. The protesters also raised anti-administration slogans.

According to reports, a large number of supporters of Amit Vashisht alias Nand Kishore Kushwaha blocked a road near in Sheikhura by burning tyres on Sunday morning and disrupted movement of traffic for hours. Soon after, a group of protesters went to Dallu Chowk where they set on fire a shrine. They also forced the shopkeepers to down their shutters.

A local resident, Ranjeet Kumar , said the protesters were demanding action against those involved in the attack on the JD(U) member and left the place but returned soon to block the road and attacked the shrine after rumour spread that another injured person Mintu Kumar, who was sent to PMCH for treatment, had died there. The second death was neither confirmed nor denied by any official.

According to sources, police picked up several persons but have withheld names. It is also learnt that police took into custody the main culprit who was being treated at Sheikhpura sadar hospital. No arrests have been made for damaging the shrine.

The police later carried out a flag march to instill confidence in residents of some localities. The officials also assured the protesters that they would ensure early arrest of those involved in the attack. Sheikhura SP Daya Shankar who, along with other police officers, was camping at the village where the situation is said to be tense.

The JD(U) member was killed in a clash that broke out between two groups over a DJ during an immersion procession of Goddess Saraswati in the village late on Saturday. Over 15 persons sustained injuries from both the sides. A critically injured Mintu Kumar was sent to PMCH after first aid. The SP said that an FIR has been lodged against 12 people in connection with the murder and five of the accused have been held so far.

Title: Case against 2 scribes will be dropped: CM
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

T’puram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said that a report has been sought from state police chief Loknath Behera regarding registering of a case against two journalists on the basis of a complaint by former DGP T P Senkumar . Asserting that the state can’t turn into a place where case is registered for asking questions, the CM said that a directive to drop the case immediately would be issued.

While replying to the leave for adjournment motion, the CM said that it could be the influence of the former DGP that had led to the police registering a case against the journalists. The opposition raised the issue of registering case against journalists K Rasheed and P G Suresh Kumar on a counter complaint by Senkumar after police registered a case against Senkumar on the complaint filed by Rasheed. A case was registered against Senkumar after Rasheed petitioned that Senkumar and others used abusive languages against him during a news conference on January 16. TNN

Title: No more whispers about menstrual hygiene in UP, thanks to Gujarat woman
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Bedekar’s journey started in 2010 when she and her husband Shyam launched a startup ‘Sakhi’.

LUCKNOW: Bollywood might have captured the story of Coimbatore’s Arunachalam Muruganantham whose ideas revolutionised menstrual hygiene in India with the film ‘Padman’, but there are unsung heroes like Swati Bedekar whose concept of low-cost organic sanitary napkins and their eco-friendly disposal has enabled women in UP lead more carefree lives.

The Vadodara native is credited with installing sanitary vending machines in several schools of Mirzapur, Ghazipur, Noida and Agra. These machines dispense organic napkins made from bio-degradable raw materials.

Bedekar’s journey started in 2010 when she and her husband Shyam launched a startup ‘Sakhi’ to establish low-cost sanitary napkin manufacturing units.

The couple set up their first unit in Uttar Pradesh in Ghazipur in December 2018.

“These pads consist of an absorbent sheet made from banana stem fiber. These ‘green pads’ are made at our units in Ghazipur and Mirzapur,” said Bedekar, who won the ‘Best Grassroot Innovation Award’ in 2015 from then-President Pranab Mukherjee .

Each of these units produces 1,200-2,000 napkins every day, which are priced at Rs 2.50 apiece. “We employ local rural women in these low-cost units, which also gives them a way to earn. They’re paid 50 paise per pad,” said the former science educator.

The training module for the women employed by Sakhi’s units has been designed by Bedekar’s husband.

What’s more, is that the terracotta incinerators installed by Bedekar and her small army of volunteers in government schools have ensured that these young girls do not have to sneak out to dispose of sanitary pads.

Called ‘Ashudhinashak’(destroyer of impurities), these incinerators ensure that sanitary pads are disposed of in an environmentally sustainable manner.

Once the pads are dumped in the incinerator, they are burned. The ash produced is absorbed by the soil and goes on to nourish plants. Currently, such incinerators have been installed in government schools of four districts.

“These devices do not spread foul odor, prevent spread of bacterial diseases and turns disposed napkins into ash without spreading smoke,” the 54-year-old added.

Bedekar ropes in local potters to manufacture these terracotta incinerators.

“Manufacturing Ashudhdhinashak costs just Rs 1,500 and just one of these devices can cater to over 100 women.”

Before heading to UP, the Bedekars have established similar units in several villages of Gujarat, Maharashtra , Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan and West Bengal .

Today, her efforts have even won her global recognition.

She has also helped set up similar units in refugee settlements in Jordan, Cameroon , South Africa and Bhutan.

According to experts, sanitary napkins take between 500 and 800 years to decompose. Experts say that an average Indian woman in urban areas throws away more than 10,000 sanitary pads in her lifetime.

Title: Residents up in arms against encroacher
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Coimbatore: Residents of VCP Thayammal Layout on Monday requested the district administration to vacate a family that has encroached the open space reserve (OSR) land of the layout.

A group of residents including children, who came to the district collectorate, said that the 48-site layout has an OSR site of nine cents. “We had used the site to conduct social activities like health camps. We also set up a shed for children to play,” said K Kavitha.

Now the residents want to build a toilet for the children coming to the adjoining integrated child development services (ICDS) centre, a compound wall around the reserve site and a park. “However, an individual has been occupying the south side of the site since 1986,” said Kavitha. “After residents moved court regarding the encroachment, the court said that the land does not belong to the encroacher. When the encroacher appealed, his suit was dismissed. Despite this, the corporation is yet to evict him. Also, his tenants, who run a workshop in the area, are creating noise and air pollution in the residential area.”

“Ward 96 has been declared a model ward under the smart cities mission. But we can’t even remove an encroacher,” Kavitha added.

Title: ‘Groundwater extraction can affect earth’s surface’
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

KOCHI: Researchers at marine geology department of the Cochin University of Science and Technology ( Cusat ) in a recent issue of the Journal of Geophysical Research have found that the Indo-Gangetic Plain and sub-Himalayan region are showing a fall in land level by 2.40mm/yr. They say that this subsidence is related to seasonal variations in the monsoon and the heavy groundwater extraction.

This is also accompanied by the northward movement of the Indian continental plate, said that study which used geological GPS of a decade from 2005-2015.

“This is not a one-off phenomenon in just that region. It could have its bearings in Kerala and the Indian peninsular region too, which is moving, and could trigger tremors in the state’s reservoir areas and coastal zones,” said P S Sunil, head, department of marine geology and geophysics.

He said that in addition to the tectonic and non-tectonic forces, unsustainable consumption of groundwater associated to irrigation and other anthropogenic uses influence the subsidence rate in the IGP and sub-Himalaya.

“At least 12% of the sub-surface disturbances have been triggered by anthropogenic (man-made) activities. Studies have shown that they are responsible for earthquake generation in that region. A similar disturbance in the earth’s sub-surface is causing the sinking of Kerala’s Mundrothuruthu,” Sunil said.

Sunil, who began the study while he was with the Indian Institute of Geomagnetism, said that the tectonic movement which is bringing the Eurasian and Indian continental plates closer is triggering major earthquakes in the Himalayan region, the latest one that recorded 7 on the Richter scale in Nepal in 2015.

Recently, the science and engineering research board (SERB), department of science and technology (DST), cleared a project to monitor the crustal and dam deformations induced by seasonal loading and unloading of Idukki reservoir in Kerala using ground and space geodetic techniques.

“I will be establishing monitoring stations in the Idukki dam to understand the cracks in the arch dam caused by water loading. The structure would have a strain accumulation due to the loading. We will observe and then make a model to understand the mechanism or disturbances triggered by the hydrological loading,” he said.

When a crack forms on the sub-surface, these form rivers, and dams are built on these rivers. “These cracks are calls fault lines and so it is expected that a slight tremor could induce reservoir earthquakes,” he said.

Sunil said that beneath the top brittle surface, the earth is elastic and when water percolates in the monsoon, it triggers elastic activity. Movement of the techtonic plate could trigger small tremors in the reservoir and also cause changes in the coastal areas in the peninsular regions.

Title: Case against anti-CAA rally organiser despite permission
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Coimbatore: The Race Course police have filed a case against K Raja Hussain, district president of Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI), and the organiser of the federation of all Jamaths and Muslim organisations which took out the anti-CAA rally on Sunday, and others in connection with the rally , for ‘causing disturbance to general public and traffic’.

SDPI members condemned this as they had obtained prior permission to take out the rally.

Cases have been filed against him under the sections 143 (punishment for unlawful assembly) and 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint) of the Indian Penal Code. Police said the members of Coimbatore district all Jamaths and Islamic Organisations had on Sunday ‘assembled unlawfully and staged agitation condemning the implementation of CAA’.

The federation of all Muslim organisations, political outfits and Jamaths, took out a massive rally against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) on Sunday from Ukkadam bus stand till Red Cross Building near South Taluk Office in the city. Women, children, youngsters and people across all age groups had participated in the rally. Representatives of churches and political leader also participated.

Police sources said around 20,000 people participated in the rally. Around 5,000 police personnel were pressed into service for safety. While the rally was organised with police protection and prior permission, police sources said the number in the crowd had exceeded their estimate.

Raja Hussain told TOI that the case has been registered due to ‘pressure’ from certain quarters. “We had held talks with the police one week prior regarding the rally and had taken out the rally only in the allowed route. We did not cause trouble or indulge in any unlawful activity. Police had given permission for the rally. Now it is not fair to file cases against us. We will reason it out with the police and also face the case legally,” he said.

Title: Travellers from SE Asia screened at city airport
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Coimbatore: The health department has now begun screening passengers landing from Singapore, Thailand and Hongkong , in addition to China , for symptoms of the novel corona virus.

After the number of patients testing positive for the virus in Kerala rose to three, officials have begun watching the Kerala-Coimbatore borders closely.

On Monday, passengers who landed in the city after travelling to any of the above four countries were given hand sanitizers and masks.

Commuters driving into the district from Kerala, have been made aware of the virus, symptoms and ways to prevent its spread.

“ A desk has also been set up for commuters to get their doubts cleared about the virus and who they should contact or approach if they have symptoms,” said Deputy Director of Health Services G Ramesh Kumar.

So far 72 people have been home quarantined in the city to watch for symptoms, however hardly one of them had a cough. No one’s throat swab samples have been sent to be tested for the dreaded Coronavirus yet.

Besides, the District Health Department also held a meeting at Isha Yoga Centre to educate foreigners in the city about the precautions that need to be taken for the novel Coronavirus (nCoV).

The foreigners were told to stay quarantined after a thorough screening, even though they do not contain any symptoms of nCoV infections.

Meanwhile, an isolation ward was created at the ESI Hospital for people with Coronavirus symptoms.

Title: Small tea farmers seek MSP of Rs 30, warn of continuous protests
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Udhagamandalam: A group of farmers staged a protest at Jakkalodai village near Kotagiri on Monday urging the Centre to fix minimum support price of Rs 30 for green leaf tea and give ‘Scheduled Tribes’ tag for the Badaga community.

The protesters, who belong to the Nakkubetta Farmers’ Welfare Association, said around 50,000 small tea cultivators have been demanding a minimum support price for green leaf tea for more than a decade, but in vain.

While the Madras high court had directed the Centre to fix the minimum support price above the production costs, nothing has been done yet, they said.

President of the association Ramanan said the price fixed by the tea board for green leaf tea is between Rs 12 and Rs 13 per kg. “Even the labour cost could not be compenstated with the price. Then there are the maintenance cost and money for the farmers to run their family,” he said.

While the processed tea is sold minimum at Rs 400 per kg, it is only the farmers who are the receiving end, he added.

The Indian Institute of Plantation Management, Bengaluru, conducted a survey in 2013 and submitted a report to the government. It stated that the minimum cost of production of green leaf tea would be around Rs 17. After adding 50 percent of that to the social cost of a farmer, the minimum support price should fall between Rs 25 and Rs 27 per kg.

Besides, the protesters also urged the Centre to give ‘Schedule Tribes’ tag for the Badaga community, whose members are mostly small tea farmers. “The Badaga community came under Schedule Tribes before the Independence. However, after the Independence the community was classified as the backward class for reasons not known,” he said, adding, “It is a blunder made by the government. We have been fighting to regain the status for the past 30 years.”

Ramanan warned that protest will continue in every village in the Nilgiris until the Centre heeds to their demands and said a massive district-level rally would also be conducted soon.

Title: FM slams Centre over revenue share
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac slammed the Centre for slashing down the revenue share of state governments for political reasons, and breaking the essence of federal structure of the country.

Replying to a calling attention motion moved by CPM MLA K Suresh Kurup, the finance minister said that the Centre has this year slashed the state’s share almost by Rs 12,000 crore, citing various reasons. He said that the state will approach other states with similar issues, and explore the possibility of moving legally against the Centre’s actions. He said that the while the finance commission had recommended that Rs 74,000 crore should be earmarked for covering the revenue deficit of the state, the Centre had only earmarked Rs 30,000 crore, which would mean that the state’s share would be much less than what was actually demanded by the finance commission.

Isaac said the Centre also slashed the limit of external borrowing of the state by citing that the treasury deposits of the state have increased. While moving the calling attention motion, Kurup said that Centre’s revengeful attitude towards the state has pushed the state into deep crisis. He said that even the compensation for GST for which the state is eligible has been blocked without even informing the state.

He said that the compensation since November is pending, and the external borrowings was limited to Rs 16,000 crore instead of the eligible Rs 25,000 crore. He said that the Centre had refused to provide any financial aid during the time of floods and also declined to allow the state to accept aid from other countries.

Title: AU notice to BTech student for attack on jr
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Allahabad: Allahabad University issued a show-cause notice to a BTech (III year) student for allegedly thrashing a junior.

The errant student Siddharth Singh is an inmate of KPUC Hostel. He is accused of thrashing a BTech (II year) student of JK Institute Deepak Kumar.

Kumar had lodged a complaint on AU’s anti-ragging portal. AU chief proctor RK Upadhyay said, “Kumar had submitted a complaint to the anti-ragging portal. He said that Siddharth and five others had thrashed him on January 29 outside the gate of JK Institute.”

Singh and his aides had damaged Kumar’s mobile phone and watch.

“I have issued a show-cause notice to Singh and asked him to report at my office on February 5 between 3 to 4pm. He has been asked to explain why he should not be rusticated from the university. Besides, we have submitted an application to lodge an named FIR against Singh and five others, who are yet to be identified,” said Upadhyay.

Title: AI carried spares, engineers to China to avoid delays
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: Air India ’s second evacuation flight flew in 323 Indians and seven citizens of Maldives from Wuhan, the epicentre of the coronavirus epidemic, to Delhi on Sunday morning. The total number of people brought in the two flights is 654 — 647 Indians and seven foreigners. The jumbo jets used for this special operation, Ajanta and Agra, are now being fumigated and will be used for regular commercial flights after they are fully disinfected.

With both these aircraft being over 25 years old, AI took critical spare parts like tyres on the flights from Delhi with engineers to minimise the chance of their getting grounded there for technical reasons. Captain Amitabh Singh , AI’s director (operations), was on both the back-to-back flights to supervise the evacuation. He and another AI employee, Sanjay Gupta , were the only two people on both the flights. “Flying into Wuhan on the first flight was like witnessing apocalypse. As soon as we exited the international overflying routes in China to head to Wuhan, there was no other air traffic there at that time. On landing, we saw planes parked with their engines sealed off. It was eerie,” Captain Singh told TOI.

The airline’s control centre in Delhi was constantly tracking the flights.

AI staff who fumigated these aircraft were also given a full protection suit to do the job. Both Ajanta and Agra will be ready to operate as per regular schedule by Tuesday.

Title: No dry taps this summer: BMC to draw Kerwa water
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Bhadbhada dam sluice gates were opened after the water level of Upper Lake touched full tank capacity in monso... Read More

Bhopal: Expect everyday water supply in the summer season this year. Instead of drawing more water from the Upper Lake, the district administration has proposed a plan to draw the requisite additional water from Kolar and Kerwa reservoirs.

After a gap of almost four years, all the water bodies including Upper Lake were full to their capacities in 2019.

An excess drawing of water — 10 MCM Kolar and 3.42 MCM from Kerwa — should suffice the daily water needs for the entire city including Bairagarh and areas under the BMC. It would be worked out in coordination with Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC), MP Pollution Control Board, discom and revenue department, as proposed in the plan. A meeting to this effect was chaired by Bhopal divisional commissioner Kalpana Shrivastava. If the plan succeeds, it would be first time in many years that the city residents would get daily water supply from March to June.

Implementation report for the proposal will be reviewed in last week of February. It includes construction of Shahjehanabad pump house that would ensure uninterrupted water supply to Bairagarh.

Focus has also been laid on filtration of chlorination of drinking water. Repair of drinking water supply lines and preventing leakages has also been proposed.

Construction work on the land allotted for sewage treatment plant has been scheduled to be completed by March. In pursuance of the decision of the NGT, bio-remediation of water from drains is also being worked out.

Title: In the last leg, thousands throng CM Arvind Kejriwal’s roadshows
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal along with MLA candidte Rajesh Mehraulia during his road show at Trilokpuri on Monday

NEW DELHI: The narrow lanes of east Delhi’s Patparganj Kondli and Trilokpuri were swarming with residents and Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) supporters as chief minister Arvind Kejriwal ’s three roadshows took place in these areas on Monday evening.Kejriwal, atop a yellow open jeep, took out total five roadshows in five constituencies in the city on Monday.Holding placards in support of the government schemes, including free healthcare and electricity, AAP supporters danced to the tunes of “Lage Raho Kejriwal” as the chief minister waved and flashed the victory sign at them. Hundreds of children too came down to the streets and clung on to the railings of their houses to catch a glimpse of their CM.At all these three locations, people grooved to the dhol beats as they waited for Kejriwal to arrive and take part in the roadshows. Kejriwal was campaigning for the party candidates in Patparganj, Kondli and Trilokpuri constituencies--Manish Sisodia, Kuldeep Kumar and Rohit Kumar Mehrauliya, respectively.While many jostled to click a selfie with Kejriwal and the AAP candidates during the roadshows, several others took photographs from their balconies.The people whom TOI spoke to said that sanitation and encroachment were some of the major problems plaguing their area. But nothing would stop them from voting for AAP, they added.“We have sought a solution to the problem of haphazard parking, and are sure that this government will take measures to improve the situation in our area. We have faith in our CM,” said Kailash Kumar, a resident of Patparganj.“My children’s school has seen a major facelift in the past few years. No government earlier thought about improving schools and education sector. This government has worked for the poor and it is my responsibility to vote for them,” said Vicky Gaba from Trilokpuri.When asked about the problem of potholes, residents said that they were confident that AAP would get all of them filled soon. “Earlier, the condition of the roads was much worse. It was all mud. Now, at least the roads are walkable. This government has made the place liveable for us, and we will make sure that we bring them to power again. We are sure that they would work for our welfare,” said Shashi from Kondli village.

Title: In the last leg, thousands throng CM Arvind Kejriwal’s roadshows
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal along with MLA candidte Rajesh Mehraulia during his road show at Trilokpuri on Monday

NEW DELHI: The narrow lanes of east Delhi’s Patparganj , Kondli and Trilokpuri were swarming with residents and Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) supporters as chief minister Arvind Kejriwal ’s three roadshows took place in these areas on Monday evening.

Kejriwal, atop a yellow open jeep, took out total five roadshows in five constituencies in the city on Monday.

Holding placards in support of the government schemes, including free healthcare and electricity, AAP supporters danced to the tunes of “Lage Raho Kejriwal” as the chief minister waved and flashed the victory sign at them. Hundreds of children too came down to the streets and clung on to the railings of their houses to catch a glimpse of their CM.

At all these three locations, people grooved to the dhol beats as they waited for Kejriwal to arrive and take part in the roadshows. Kejriwal was campaigning for the party candidates in Patparganj, Kondli and Trilokpuri constituencies--Manish Sisodia, Kuldeep Kumar and Rohit Kumar Mehrauliya, respectively.

While many jostled to click a selfie with Kejriwal and the AAP candidates during the roadshows, several others took photographs from their balconies.

The people whom TOI spoke to said that sanitation and encroachment were some of the major problems plaguing their area. But nothing would stop them from voting for AAP, they added.
