The BMC had roped in a corporate to hire manpower and machinery to keep roads and footpaths clean as as part of the latter’s corporate social responsibility (CSR) programme The revision of the open spaces policy, which is already under way, is likely to proposed in the budget giving recreational and public grounds to private entities for maintenance for a specified period. Bandra corporator Asif Zakeria warned that the BMC would need to keep ‘errant’ private entities at bay. The budget may also emphasise on promoting tourist-friendly destinations developed by the BMC, including Byculla zoo, Pramod Nawalkar Viewing Gallery located next to Kamala Nehru Park at Malabar Hill and Matoshri Meenatai Thackeray Shilpgram at Jogeshwari.Corporators suggested that the budget should propose innovative ways to hike revenue without burdening taxpayers. “The last two budgets have been dipping into BMC’s Rs 70,000-crore fixed deposits. It is not a positive sign as FDs should ideally be put to use on during a contingency,” pointed out NCP party leader and Ghatkopar corporator Rakhi Jadhav. Opposition party leader in the BMC, Ravi Raja from Congress, said ‘realistic budget should be priority’. “Big-ticket infrastructure works should be completed in a time-bound manner,” he added. Samajwadi Party corporator Rais Shaikh said: “There’s a need to provide better footpaths and implement garbage segregation. Involvement of corporates at a certain level may be a good idea ...a CSR cell can be set up in the civic body.”

Title: Choosi Choodangaane: Choosi Choodangaane: A love story told from a woman’s perspective
Content: Director Sesha Sindhu Rao , who has earlier worked with Krish and Sukumar as an associate, made her debut recently with Shiva Kandukuri-starrer Choosi Choodangaane Raj Kandukuri , who produced the film under Dharmapatha Creations, is happy to introduce new talent along with his son in the film. “When Sindhu narrated the story, I was impressed. Despite being a boy-meets-girl tale, the way she pulled it off is amazing,” says Raj, adding, “The best part with a woman helming the show is, you get to see a female perspective. My belief in her talent is so immense that I launched my son with her.”The film is a coming-of-age tale of Siddu played by Shiva. But it also has strong female characters — his mother played by Pavitra Lokesh, who is the breadwinner, his college crush Aishwarya (Malavika) and his other love interest, Shruti ( Varsha Bollamma), both independent women aware of what they want in a relationship. “The women in my film aren’t the typical glam-dolls who breeze in and out of the hero’s life,” says Sindhu about her characters. “The effort was to show that they are flawed in their own ways. When love stories are narrated, they’re usually told from the perspective of a man; Choosi Choodangaane differs in that aspect,” she adds.The film also benefits from the huge number of women technicians, says Raj. “I believe the film industry should have more female technicians. My previous film Mental Madhilo had Manisha Satyavolu as the art director and this film sees Shanti Rao as the production designer and Padmavati Vishweshwar as the dialogue writer. More women behind the screen mean more balanced stories onscreen,” he says adding, “Women in my films are always strong and provide a certain balance to the guy.” Sindhu adds, “I’m glad the audience liked the film because the response has been great.”

Title: 56 engineers from Andhra Pradesh in quarantine at Manesar
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Though 56 engineers from Andhra Pradesh , employed and trained by a Chinese company at a facility in the coronavirus-hit Wuhan in China, heaved a sigh of relief on touching down at the Delhi airport, some of them complained that they were subjected to a series of medical checkup, more than the usual while returning from China.Female students and employees were quarantined at a navy camp in Manesar in Haryana, while males were housed at an army camp. They might be kept under observation for a couple of weeks there."While an employee (Jyothi) released a video claiming that she along with another colleague were not affected by the coronavirus , they were not allowed to take a flight to India as their body temperatures were found to be slightly above normal. Authorities were checking if anyone's temperature is even slightly higher than the normal. Those two did not have fever, but they were strained and tensed because of the many checks and atmosphere at the immigration desk in particular and the airport in general," an engineer, who is in quarantine at the army camp told TOI over the phone.The Chinese company representatives requested the Indian embassy officials to allow the two to fly to India, but they rejected their plea.Indians returning from China were being quarantined at army and navy facilities at Manesar. About 20 people were being accommodated in each tent with doctors checking their temperatures twice a day. Though the quarantined have been provided food, they were not allowed to meet anyone, including relatives."On Saturday, we could not even talk to parents over the phone, now we are able to communicate with them," another engineer said.The Chinese company did not inform the engineers, who completed their training, when to begin work at its facility in Tirupati. They were supposed to resume work after a 10-day holiday, but as they were in quarantine, there was no clarity on their work schedule.

Title: Several states to contest for setting up of 5 smart cities
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: Several states, including Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and West Bengal, have shown interest in setting up greenfield smart cities along industrial corridors and the Centre will decide on the location through a challenge method, a senior government officer said.

“We will go for a challenge to decide the states that will get the projects,” Guruprasad Mohapatra , secretary for industrial promotion and internal trade, said. In the Budget, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman had announced the setting up of five new smart cities in PPP mode. Already, new cities in Dadri (UP), Dholera (Gujarat), Shendra Bidkin (Maharashtra) and Vikram Udyogpuri (Madhya Pradesh) are coming up along the Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor.

A similar model will be followed along new industrial corridors such as Delhi-Kolkata, Kolkata-Chennai, Mumbai-Bengaluru and Chennai-Bengaluru, where the state will provide land and the Centre will provide equity to a special purpose vehicle. The SPV will raise resources to create infrastructure and plug-and-play facility. The state will provide infrastructure such as water and power supply.

States that provide land first and sign a state support scheme to back the development are expected to be preferred, sources said.

Title: BS Yediyurappa set to prepare for Karnataka budget
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

CM BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: Amid concerns of a shortfall in funds from the Centre, chief minister BS Yediyurappa is scheduled to kickstart preparations for the state budget, to be presented on March 5, on Monday.

Yediyurappa will hold a review meeting with representatives of the department of higher education and thereafter with officials of IT-BT and medical education. All these departments are under deputy chief minister CN Ashwath Narayan, who has sought an increase of Rs 3,000 crore in allocation for higher education.

The CM will also hold meetings with officials of other departments including agriculture, transport, horticulture and sericulture, housing, revenue and municipal administration on Monday.

Officials in the chief minister’s office said the CM will hold pre-budget meetings till the end of February. He is expected to meet representatives of industries and trade bodies on February 10.

In February 2019, former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy presented a budget with an outlay of Rs 2,34,153 crore. Yediyurappa continued with the budget after he took over in July. He is likely to enhance the outlay for the coming fiscal.

Title: Coronavirus transmission by ‘silent carriers’ a worry
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: It was not enough to quarantine only those with suspected symptoms of the novel coronavirus since many could be ‘silent carriers’ — like the nurse from Wuhan, who had flown back to Kochi via Kolkata on January 23 — and their symptoms may show up later when they have already come in contact with others in the community and transmitted the disease, warned experts.Even though the Indians, who landed in Delhi on Thursday night, will remain in isolation for 15 days, several may have already reached Kolkata from the affected countries. While one was suspected to have symptoms of the virus and was later released, the clinical report of a Thai national, who died at a private hospital last week, was negative.It is important to study the history of a visitor’s travel and take steps accordingly, said virologists. If he or she has been to China or any other part of the continent, where there were chances of coming in contact with infected people, vigilance is a must, felt experts. “This strain of coronavirus spreads very fast unlike other common viruses. Other strains of coronavirus cause common cough and cold and the influenza viruses. It may take several days for the symptoms to manifest so the people, who have travelled through the affected regions, need to be screened for at least a fortnight. Or else, they may end up transmitting the disease,” said virologist Amitabha Nandy.He added that a silent carrier increases more the chances of transmission and it could be difficult to control the spread of the virus, if one or two such carriers manage to sneak into the city. “Since the early signs of novel coronavirus aren’t different from other common viruses, it is difficult to detect it at the first stage. So, screening and isolation are a must,” said Nandy.The virus may take up to 14 days to manifest itself through symptoms, said Fortis Hospital internal medicine consultant Joydeep Ghosh. “The majority of the infected people could remain without the symptoms for more than a week. But they are carrying the virus and pose a bigger threat since they are not being suspected and others come in contact with them. A fortnight’s screening is the only real full-proof measure to prevent the transmission,” said Ghosh.It is, however, too early to assume that the virus is more lethal than other common viruses, said doctors. In fact, SARS that is also a coronavirus had a 10% mortality rate while novel so far has a mortality rate of less than 3%. “But these are still early days and we don’t know the real numbers yet. But going by the reports so far, it is highly contagious and difficult to contain,” said Biswas.Severe breathing distress in young healthy people, diarrhoea with fever, cough and cold may indicate novel coronavirus, said AMRI Hospitals consultant Debashish Saha. “If a healthy person shows severe viral symptoms, there is a reason to be concerned. Since there is no medicine for coronavirus, it is better to get admitted to hospital. This will ensure isolation,” said Saha.Any fast-spreading virus is bound to lead to deaths, pointed out Nandy. “Initially, people are not aware of this fact and tend to ignore the symptoms that lead to a delayed intervention and death. Those, especially elderly people suffering from low immunity, cardiac ailments, renal or kidney ailments, lung diseases are more vulnerable,” said Nandy.Novel coronavirus could be fatal for the elderly with respiratory diseases since it affects the lungs and causes breathing distress. “It may lead to pneumonia that can be fatal,” said Nandy. But there are no early sings to distinguish it from other viruses, he added.

Title: Telangana: Delays in issuance of smart cards by RTA irks residents
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Delays in issuance of smart cards to issue vehicle registration certificates has thrown the entire vehicle registration process of applicants into disarray yet again.

Each RTA office in Hyderabad and Rangareddy district is equipped to print more than 300 cards a day and these are sent to vehicle owners within 7 days by Speed Post.

However, the applicants are now being forced to wait for months due to the delay.

"It has been nearly a month since I got my vehicle registered at Trimulgherry Road Transport Authority (RTA) office and yet I did not receive the smart card which the officials are supposed to send to my mailing address. I do not understand why there is a delay when we are paying the fee for smart cards and postal fee during the registration," said G Sainath, a resident of Trimulgherry.

When Sainath went back to the RTA office recently to check the status of his smart card, he said, "Some brokers waiting outside the office said I could get the card on the same day if I paid additional money. The brokers at the RTA office are cashing in on the delsay. I think it is time they find a permanent solution to this problem."

Another applicant, Mohammad Imraan asked, "My application for registration of my new car was approved in the first week of January, but I am yet to get the smart card. Why do they collect money from us for the card if they are not able to dispatch it on time?"

The problem was addressed in July last year after the transport minister reviewed the situation and asked the district officers to arrange for the consumables of printing cards and printers within three days and clear the pending cases within 15 days.

However, the solution to clear the pending cases last year turned out to be a temporary one.

"Earlier, the printing machines were not working and now there is a delay because the contractors who supply the raw material to print these cards are not being paid on time. A committee should be formed to find a permanent solution to this problem," said M Dayananad, general secretary of Telangana Auto and Motor Vehicle union.

When contacted, C Ramesh, joint transport commissioner (IT), RTA said, "We are working on the issue and the problem will be resolved soon. As of now, we are asking people to download the documents on the mobile application."

Title: 40 bio-toilets to come up for traffic cops at major signals across Kolkata
Content:
A bio-toilet installed earlier near Kalikapur remains unused

TimesView This was badly needed. It is good that the focus is on making life a little less uncomfortable for people who do not have an easy job

KOLKATA: Keeping in mind the traffic cops working for long, Kolkata Police planned to install bio-toilets near major traffic signal points across the city. This will help the cops return to their duty spots after attending to nature's call."Recently, the police commissioner Aunj Sharma held a meeting where he gave a nod to the installation of 40 bio-toilets near the traffic signals. Earlier in 2017, some NGOs had donated bio-toilets to Kolkata Police, but most of these toilets became redundant due to the lack of proper maintenance," said a police officer. Later, more such toilets will come up in the city.Sharma said, " The bio-toilets will help the traffic police a lot. The toilets will be installed to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals for cleaner environment."Kolkata Police are planning to install bio-toilets because there are space constraints near traffic signals to set up proper toilets. A bio-toilet is an alternative to traditional waste disposal, said the officer. He added that as of now, many cops have to use the toilets of neighbourhood hotels.Anirban Mukherjee, who works in the field of bio-toilet technology, said that each bio-toilet block costs around Rs 20,000 to Rs 25,000. "Each toilet block should have a 200-litre water tank with mobile charging and other facilities," he added.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: BJP lost Vishwas Nagar ka vishwas, says CM Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal addresses a public meeting ahead of Delhi assembly elections, at Vishwas Nagar, in Ne... Read More

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday said that the development of Vishwas Nagar assembly constituency had suffered because the BJP MLA did not let AAP government work in the area. The East Delhi constituency was one of the three assembly seats that BJP won in the last assembly polls.Addressing a swarm of supporters while campaigning for party candidate Deepak Singla, Kejriwal said BJP had lost “Vishwas Nagar ka Vishwas”, but AAP was determined to work for its welfare. BJP’s Om Prakash Sharma had won the seat in both the 2013 and 2015 polls.“In the last five years, we have worked with conviction for the people of Delhi. Last time around, you didn’t put your trust in us. But this time, I am hoping that every person here will vote for us seeing the kind of development we have brought about in the city. You brought OP Sharma to power and he ruined the area. We have installed CCTV cameras across the city for everyone’s safety, but he didn’t let us put up even a single camera here,” he said.Similarly, Kejriwal alleged, Sharma hadn’t allowed his government to build mohalla clinics in the constituency. “We will start constructing 20 mohalla clinics in this constituency with immediate effect (after winning the elections),” he said. “We have worked in sectors like education, power, health and transport... provided free bus rides to women... the list is endless. Now, we pledge to continue working like that in the next five years too,” Kejriwal said, adding that BJP would stop all the schemes if it won the elections.“Till the time I am with you, I promise that all of your needs will be taken care of by your son like they have been in the last five years. We will change the face of this place and make it more liveable...5,000 CCTV cameras will be installed as soon as we are elected,” he added. He received a raucous applause from the gathering even as women and children danced to the tunes of the party’s anthem, “Lagey Raho Kejriwal”.The CM’s next stop was Laxmi Nagar where he vowed to make Yamuna so clean that people didn’t have to go to Ganga for a holy dip. Retorting to the comments made by UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath, Kejriwal said: “Yogiji is saying that we have ruined Delhi’s schools. The people couldn’t tolerate the insult and, so, they told him ‘aap apna Uttar Pradesh samhalo, Dilli sahi hai’ (you take care of Uttar Pradesh, Delhi is fine).” He added, “Yogiji, first take care of schools and hospitals in your state. We all know the condition. We all know what happened in Gorakhpur”.Hitting out at Union home minister Amit Shah, he said: “Our students are doing so well and Shahji is saying that they are not able to read properly. He is insulting the students...The parties that had nothing to do with the city earlier are also contesting the elections, just so that they could somehow defeat us. That’s their only motive,” he said. Earlier in the day, at a roadshow in northwest Delhi’s Kirari, the chief minister said the Aam Aadmi Party government was committed to transforming the unauthorised colonies in the capital.

Title: Hyderabad zoo to welcome swamp deer, lion-tailed macaque
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The Nehru Zoological Park, which is spread across 380 acres, houses 173 species and nearly 1,800 specimens

HYDERABAD: As part of the animal exchange programme with Chennai’s Vandalur Zoo , the Nehru Zoological Park in Hyderabad will soon have some new inmates, including a pair of swamp deer and one female lion tailed macaque by the end of this month.

The zoo is going to procure these animals as part of an exchange for a one-horned rhinoceros that was sent to Vandalur zoo in August last year. “The pair of swamp deer and the lion-tailed macaque are expected to arrive by the end of this month. We have one male lion-tailed macaque now and with the arrival of a female lion-tailed macaque, we will have a pair,” said zoo curator, N Kshitija.

The paperwork to procure four grey kangaroos and one pair of meerkats in exchange for one pair of Asiatic lions is also in progress. According to the zoo officials, the kangaroos and meerkats are part of the animal exchange programme with the Yokohoma Zoological Garden in Japan.

“The animals from Japan are expected to arrive in two or three months. We gave a female Asiatic lion to the Yokohoma zoo for which they are giving us two pairs of kangaroos and one pair of meerkats. We will have these animals in the zoo for the first time,” an official said.

The zoo authorities have referred the proposal to the Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) and are waiting for the permissions from Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change and Central Zoo Authority to bring the animals to the city zoo.

The Nehru Zoological Park, which is spread across 380 acres, houses 173 species and nearly 1,800 specimens.

Title: BS Yediyurappa: Suburban rail in 3 years, says CM BS Yediyurappa; 6, says K-RIDE
Content:
Representative image

Train to KIA by 2022

Services from 5am

BENGALURU: Chief minister BS Yediyurappa on Sunday said work on Bengaluru’s suburban rail project will be taken up on priority and be completed within three years, a move that is certain to ease commute across the city, especially to Kempegowda International Airport (KIA).Addressing a press conference with Union minister of state for railways Suresh Angadi alongside him, Yediyurappa said: “It is a longpending project and a dream of former Union minister [and late BJP leader] HN Ananth Kumar. The Union government announced implementation of the project in the budget. The project will be completed in three years.”That timeframe would be an astonishing feat in a city where infrastructure projects have been horribly delayed. However, it was at odds with the deadline set by Karnataka Rail Infrastructure Development Enterprises (K-RIDE), the SPV (special purpose vehicle) set up to execute the project. While unveiling a detailed plan on the four-corridor 148km project on Sunday, K-RIDE said it will take six years to complete.Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the project at a cost of Rs 18,600 crore in the Union budget on Saturday, but it is yet to be approved by the Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA). However, Angadi and Bengaluru Central MP PC Mohan said CCEA approval will be granted soon, while the central government will also extend funding.Meanwhile, K-RIDE said the suburban rail project will comprise four corridors: KSR Bengaluru City-Devanahalli, Byappanahalli-Chikkabanavara, Kengeri-Cantonment-Whitefield and Heelalige-Rajanukunte.In a huge boost to air passengers, the KSR Bengaluru City-Yelahanka- KIA- Devanahalli (41.4km) line is likely to be operational by August 2022. K-RIDE said work will be taken up on priority and the line will have 14 stations. It will be built at an estimated cost of Rs 5,127 crore. In contrast, the Rs 10,584 crore Silk Board-KR Puram (ORR)-KIA Namma Metro corridor project is yet to get approval from the Centre and is scheduled to open only in 2024.Moreover, suburban rail could provide cheaper and quicker connectivity to KIA than the Metro since airport passengers from the central business district and south Bengaluru opting for the Metro will have to change several trains to get to KIA.K-RIDE said of the 148km track, 59.4km will be elevated and 92.59km will be at grade. Similarly, of the 57 suburban stations, 21 will be elevated. All four corridors will be operational in six years and is expected to have a daily ridership of 10 lakh passengers. K-RIDE will have autonomy in deciding fares.All suburban trains will have air-conditioned coaches. Services will begin from 5am and continue till midnight. Stations at many locations will interface with Indian Railways and Namma Metro ones. This is expected to facilitate development of a multimodal transport system for Bengaluru.K-RIDE revealed 583 acres is required for the project, including railway land (327 acres), Karnataka government (153 acres) and private land for corridors and depots (103 acres). While railway land and Karnataka government land is proposed to be leased at a nominal cost of Rs 1 per acre, cost of private land will be borne by the state government.According to K-RIDE, the project will be revenue positive from the first year itself. Total revenue per year is projected at Rs 1,378 crore, while operational and maintenance cost has been estimated at Rs 614 crore a year.Yediyurappa said once completed, the project will reduce traffic congestion, promote faster connectivity and also reduce environmental pollution.

Title: GHMC to deploy drones for anti-larval operations
Content:
GHMC officials took note of the exact locations and added them to their pin-point programme

SECUNDERABAD: With residents of Uppal complaining that fogging machines just zip past their area, Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) officials took note of the exact locations and added them to their pin-point programme.As a part of the programme, anti-larval operations are carried out in a locality every eight days. The newly-appointed zonal commissioner also promised bio-remediation and antilarval operations with the help of drones. The drones would be pressed into service especially around lakes and places where human cannot reach physically.Replying to a question by a resident, GHMC zonal commissioner, LB Nagar, and additional commissioner, information technology wing, Sikta Patnaik said, “Fogging for a longer duration or staff equipped with fogging machines plying too slow can result in accidents. Fogging has to be done scientifically.”She also explained the measures being taken by the entomology wing through drone and pin-point programme. GHMC entomology department officials emphasised that fumigation, in terms of fogging, was not the solution to reduce vector-borne diseases. Fogging would be done only on streets away from houses following the World Health Organization (WHO) rules, they added.As per norms, if an employee carries a portable fogging machine (used in bylanes) on a bike, the speed limit should be between five km and 10 km. The vehicle-mounted machines ply on main roads and they ply fast compared to portable machines. “Number of vehicle-mounted fogging machines has been scaled up across Greater Hyderabad,” the IAS officer said.Coordination with sanitation, engineering and entomology department by removing garbage points, identification of hot spots by taking epidemiological data between 2017 and 2020 were the other activities GHMC was taking up in LB Nagar as well as in rest of the city, according to entomology wing officers. “GHMC is also using eportal information to track dengue cases and take measures accordingly,” they added.
