Title: Samatha gang rape: Nirbhaya verdict sealed fate of accused
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

HYDERABAD: In the Samatha gangrape and murder case, a fast-track court in Adilabad awarded capital punishment to three convicts last week after a record trial in less than 70 days, but relied heavily on the Supreme Court’s verdict in the Nirbhaya case.The judge hoped the soul of Samatha may rest in peace with the grant of capital punishment.In her 66-page order in the Samatha case, principal sessions judge MG Priyadarshini agreed with the prosecution, who quoted the apex court judgement in the Nirbhaya and other cases, while awarding death penalty to accused Shaik Babu, Shaik Shabuddin and Shaik Maqdoom.On the critical aspect of whether the fast-track court should grant death penalty or not to the trio, the judge referred and quoted the apex court judgement from the Nibhaya case.“Two questions are to be asked and answered: i) Is there something uncommon about the crimes which regard sentence of imprisonment for life inadequate. ii) Whether there is no alternative punishment suitable except death sentence. Where a crime is committed with extreme brutality and the collective conscience of society is shocked, courts must award death penalty, irrespective of their personal opinion as regards desirability of death penalty. By not imposing a death sentence in such cases, the courts may do injustice to the society at large,”.In her reasoning, the judge said, “Considering all the facts and circumstances and the ghastly nature of the offence and the heinous attitude of the accused in commission of the offence, this court feels that if a capital punishment of death is imposed against the accused 1 to 3 in this case, not only the ends of justice would meet, but at the same time the soul of deceased (Samatha) may also rest in peace. Therefore, the crime committed by the accused satisfied the test of rarest of rare cases. As such, this court feels that the accused (1 to 3) do not deserve any mercy’’.On the aspect of matching DNA profiles too, the prosecution relied on the Nibhaya case, where in the apex court said: “The matching of DNA profile from the material objects recovered from the deceased and the accused is sufficient to connect with the offence. The above findings squarely apply to the case on hand (Samatha case) as in the present case also the evidence of a witness establishes that the DNA profiles of the accused are matched with that of the DNA samples collected from the saree of the deceased (Samatha). Thus, the matching of DNA profiles of accused with that of the DNA profiles found on the saree of deceased not only strengthens the above circumstances established from the evidence, but also establishes that it is the accused, who committed rape on the deceased’’.

Title: DRI busts smuggling rackets, seizes 31kg gold
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Gold worth Rs 13.3 crore was seized

VIJAYAWADA: The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) seized 31.5 kg gold worth 13.3 crore in the last three days.

DRI caught three consignments in Vijayawada and one at Secunderabad railway station and arrested 13 people for transporting smuggled gold. DRI units of Nellore, Vijayawada and Hyderabad conducted a coordinated operation based on specific intelligence.

On January 31, DRI Nellore unit intercepted three passengers travelling from Chennai to Warangal in Jaipur SF Express train. They were carrying 7.228 kg of gold bars in bags. They told DRI that they carried cash from Warangal to Chennai and purchased smuggled gold of foreign origin and going to handover the gold to the mastermind in Warangal.

On February 1, DRI officers from Vijayawada intercepted three persons on board of GT Express at Vijayawada railway station. They purchased smuggled gold of foreign origin weighing about 7.077 kg and were going to Warangal to handover the gold to the mastermind.

On the same day, DRI Vijayawada and Hyderabad units intercepted a bus heading for Warangal from Guntur at Vijayawada. Four passengers were held with 6.47 kg of gold concealed in their clothes. They took the train from Chennai to Warangal but got off at Kavali in Nellore.

They took a bus to Ongole and from there to Guntur and to Warangal. All the three gangs were heading to Warangal and it was not clear whether they belonged to the same gang and the mastermind behind the smuggling racket is one person or multiple persons involved.

The fourth incident happened on Sunday at Secunderabad railway station where DRI intercepted three persons in Chennai-Hyderabad Superfast Express. DRI recovered 10.7 kg of gold bars concealed in their clothes. DRI booked cases under the Customs Act and investigation is on to trace the masterminds.

Title: Kolkata: Security tightened at agitation venues after attacks at Jamia and Shaheen Bagh
Content:
Cops keep watch outside the Park Circus Maidan

KOLKATA: Both organizers and the police have taken steps to strengthen security and increase vigil at the anti-CAA sit-in sites in the city after two incidents of firing at Jamia Milia and Shaheen Bagh in less than three days. Thousands throng these venues in some of the busiest areas of Kolkata to show solidarity with the protesters who have been demonstrating for weeks and it becomes difficult for the cops and organizers to scan everybody. But after the two incidents in the Capital, efforts are on to keep an eye out for trouble.Police have deployed more personnel inside and outside Park Circus Maidan where women have been sitting in protest for more than three weeks. At Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore , the organizers have increased the number of volunteers and on Zakaria Street, everybody has been told to be alert and immediately inform organizers and cops if they notice anything suspicious.“The two lone-wolf attacks in the Capital are like the worst nightmares coming true. There are elements who want to give the entire movement a communal colour and portray it as violent. There have been several peaceful protests in Kolkata. We are alert and careful so that the protests remain peaceful,” said Arshad Parvez Khan, one of the organizers of the sit-in at Nawab Ali Park. The number of volunteers has been increased and cops have been requested to keep a vigil. “We have also applied for permission to install CCTV cameras around the venue,” he said.At Park Circus Maidan, the organizers have started noting down details of all those who are coming up to address the protesters. Details are also being taken of people arriving in big groups to join the protests. The organizers have increased the number of volunteers who often make a human chain when the crowd swells. Anyone found loitering is being requested to either join the protest or leave the spot.“We are determined to keep the protests peaceful. So we are regularly co-ordinating with the cops. We are also keeping a watch on whoever is coming to join us. We are taking down the details of every person who is coming up to address the gathering. We have more than 100 volunteers working in shifts,” said a core-committee member of the organizing team.On Zakaria Street, too, the protest organizers have requested cops to increase security. The volunteers have been asked to keep a watch from the periphery.

Title: Voters aged 80 or more & disabled can vote from home
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The move is introduced to increase the participation of the age group. (File photo)

NASHIK: The Commission (EC) of India has decided to extend the " postal ballot for absentee voters " facility to the voters aged 80 years or more as well as people with disabilities.

According to senior officials of district administration, the Chief Election Officer of Maharashtra has issued a letter asking the district election office to provide "postal ballots " to voters who are 80 years old (or more) and even to PWDs who have their names in the electoral rolls for the upcoming elections.

The ECI has decided to provide this relief to the voters who find it difficult to travel to election booths based on the feedback it has received.

"Whether it is citizens aged 80 years or PWDs - both usually depend on family members or others to take them to election booths. This is the biggest reason why these citizens often do not cast their votes," the officer said.

To increase their participation in the electoral process, the EC has decided to include them in the list of "absentee voters". The list already includes servicemen - who are posted away from their native place - and their immediate relatives.

"Since it is not feasible for them to travel, the government prints postal ballots for them and sends the same to the voters through email. They are asked to mark their votes secretly and send the same to the election officer within the stipulated time," the officer added.

A similar exercise will be carried out for the citizens aged 80 or more and PWDs who will get the postal ballots at their homes.

The CEO has also asked the district election officers to identify such voters in their district electors' roll and flag them.

"The district election officers will, through the booth level officers (BLOs), prepare the list of all citizens who meet the criteria and at the time of elections, postal ballots will be sent to them," the officer said.

Title: Healthcare in rural Gujarat second cheapest in India
Content:
Representative image

Specialists not available

AHMEDABAD: Rural Gujarat pays the least, after Tamil Nadu, for treatment at public hospitals, according to a Union government report ‘Key Indicators of Social Consumption in India: Health’. The report, however, says these rural folk place more faith in small private clinics or private hospitals than in public health facilities.Rural Gujarat pays an average of Rs 1,191 for treatment at public hospitals while their urban counterparts shell out Rs 3,529 on average. However, in rural Gujarat, only one in three persons prefers government hospitals to private clinics or hospitals. In urban Gujarat, only one in five persons prefers government facilities for treatment.The report states that in rural areas the average spending at a private hospital is Rs 25,027, which is 17% lower than at a private hospital in urban Gujarat.A senior state government health official said that even with treatment costs higher at private hospitals, in both rural and urban areas people prefer private medical help to government hospitals. “The reasons for these are the lack of facilities and unavailability of senior doctors at government hospitals.”“The problem with such urban-rural surveys is that they do not capture the fact that specialized surgeries such as heart, kidney, or obstetrics don’t take place in rural areas. For that one goes to cities or district referral hospitals, where medical costs will be higher. At public referral hospitals too, patient care costs are higher as they include food, travel, loss of daily earning, among other costs,” said Dileep Mavalankar, director of the Indian Institute of Public Health (IIPH), Gandhinagar.In fact, at many taluka-level hospitals in Gujarat, specialists are not available. These positions are gradually being filled. Also, just 60% of the funds that Gujarat gets from the Centre under the National Health Mission is utilized. Thus, with fewer facilities and with specialist appointments taking time, people end up paying more at private hospitals in urban areas, Dileep Mavalankar, director of the Indian Institute of Public Health (IIPH), Gandhinagar said.Mavalankar added, “Although there are a number of health subsidies, I feel there is ample scope in Gujarat to take these benefits to those in need with better health management, planning and provisioning for a special unplanned fund to handle events such as epidemics, episodes of which will only get more frequent.”Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary, health, said, “Paying less than in other states in the country is a good sign. We are working on plans to further reduce the burden of healthcare costs on common people. We have observed that treatment often pushes people into debt.”

Title: 2 isolated to rule out infection by novel coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Two more travellers, who returned from China recently, were isolated at the civic-run Naidu hospital - on Saturday and Sunday respectively - to rule out the novel coronavirus infection after they complained of minor cold, cough and fever."One of them is a 42-year-old man whom we isolated around 9pm on Saturday (February 1). He has a cough, sore throat and was in Shanghai in China between January15 and 18," said medical expert Ramchandra Hankare, chief of the health department at Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC)."The other traveller, a 27-year-old man, was in Shanghai between January 5 and 25. We isolated him around 1.15pm on Sunday (February 2). He has a fever, sore throat and cough," Hankare said.Eight travellers, till date, have undergone care at the Naidu hospital's isolation ward over the last two weeks after they presented with some of the symptoms on their return from China."Of them, five travellers tested negative. We have discharged four of them. Four travellers, including the two new patients, are currently undergoing care at the isolation ward at Naidu hospital. We have sent their throat swab samples to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for testing. The reports are awaited," Hankare said.A total of 5,128 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have so far been screened at the Mumbai's Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA) since January 18.38 travellers - residents of Pune, Mumbai, Pimpri-Chinchwad, Kalyan, Vasai , Virar, Nanded and other parts of Maharashtra, will be under surveillance for 28 days.Of the 38 travellers, 17 travellers had complained of minor presentations of cold, cough, fever and headache, following which they were quarantined mainly in Mumbai, Pune, Nanded and Nagpur. The remaining patients have not developed any illness and hence have not been isolated.

Title: Eight Chinese nationals admitted to isolation ward at Chennai government hospital
Content:
A passenger at the arrrival bay of Chennai international airport

All fliers from SE Asia to be screened

CHENNAI: Eight Chinese citizens who arrived at the Chennai Airport on Saturday have been admitted to isolation ward in Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital after one of them had fever and cold during airport screening. Five other patients, all Indians, have been admitted to various government hospital after they complained of flu-like symptoms.Health secretary Beela Rajesh said these citizens came from Guangdong province in China, which is nearly 800km from Wuhan.They were taken to the isolation ward in tower 2 block of the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital.Doctors treating them said their condition is stable. Healthcare workers including doctors, nurses and other paramedics have been given masks, gloves and other personal protection wear.Samples including nasal swabs have been sent to the King Institute for Preventive Medicine in Guindy. "Results are expected today evening, " said director of public health Dr K Kolandaiswamy."Atleast 700 more people are in home quarantine, " he said.The Airports Authority of India (AAI) has started screening all passengers arriving from Singapore and Thailand at Chennai airport from Saturday as there have been many cases of coronavirus infection in these countries.Airport Health Organisation (APHO) has also revised the guidelines for screening and has started to advise passengers who had travelled to China in the last 14 days or had possible contact with nCoV infected person to stay in isolation at home for 14 days. They are being told to sleep in a separate room and limit contact with other family members.

Title: Mercury up but winds blow cold in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Ahmedabad on Sunday recorded 26.8 C maximum and 13.2 C minimum temperature in the 24 hours ending at 5pm

AHMEDABAD: With change in wind direction, the city experienced a rise in minimum temperature but strong winds forced citizens to wear warmer clothes on Sunday. Mild dust devils were observed in several parts of the city in the morning and afternoon.

According to India Meteorological Department (IMD) website, Ahmedabad on Sunday recorded 26.8 C maximum and 13.2 C minimum temperature in the 24 hours ending at 5pm. The maximum temperature was 2.4 degrees less than average whereas the minimum temperature was 0.2 degrees higher.

The IMD forecast mentioned that the city could expect 14 C minimum temperature on Monday. The change can be due to northeasterly to easterly winds which were earlier blowing northerly to northeasterly, said experts.

For Gujarat, the IMD forecast mentioned that on Monday and Tuesday, the region could experience 2-3 degrees rise in minimum temperature after which there would be a drop of 2-3 degrees on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

Naliya was the coldest among weather stations with minimum temperature of 6.8 C, followed by Deesa (9.2 degrees), Bhuj (10 degrees), Keshod (10.6 degrees) and Kandla (11 degrees). Maximum temperature remained in the range of 26 to 29 C.

Title: Kolkata: Chitpore level crossing may be ready by end-February
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Work on in full swing for the approach roads towards the level crossing

KOLKATA: The construction of the level crossing and approach roads on either side of the Chitpore rail yard has gained momentum after the sanction from the railways. The level crossing to the west of the frail Cossipore Bridge is meant for goods vehicles. The goods vehicle movement has suffered a serious setback ever since Tallah Bridge was made out of bounds for them in early November.

The officials are eyeing an end-February deadline to complete the work.

There are two sidings of Chitpore yard. The southern siding handles salt and northern siding is meant for perishable items and other goods. Because of the complete snapping of north-south corridors, the wagon load of goods were rotting at warehouses. Moreover, the warehouse space has always been limited, said a goods transporter. The transportation cost, thus, spiralled because of a detour by goods vehicles.

Hitherto, goods vehicles used Tallah Bridge to move in this region. But from November, Tallah Bridge was made out of bounds for heavy vehicles. A height bar prevented goods vehicles to travel along Cossipore bridge as well.

The proposal for the level crossing was mooted by chief secretary Rajiva Sinha during a high-level meeting on January 1 with senior officials of the Eastern Railway. A task force, including DRM (Sealdah), an engineer of the railways and principal secretaries to the state public works and transport departments, was formed to look into the design that would be prepared by the railways. The state needs to pay Rs 14 crore to the railways to construct the level crossing.

That's why the state government insisted on the availability of level crossing from Bagbazar-end to Turner Road so that goods vehicles can move to-and-fro Chiria More using this level crossing, said a PWD engineer. "We are now working hard to complete the level crossing by end of February. The work of approach roads on either side is on in a war-footing," he added.

Once the level crossing is ready, we can also divert buses along this route as PWD has issued caution against the health of Cossipore bridge as well.

It has been decided after an inspection on Saturday, transport department will convene a meeting with the railways and the police to work out the modalities for constructing the level crossing. Engineers, meanwhile, will work together to identify the exact quantum of railway land that will be required for building the new bridge, parallel to the existing one in Tallah.

Title: Pune: 56 parked vehicles damaged in three separate acts of vandalism
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Several vehicles in Sahakarnagar (above) bore the brunt of vandalism on Sunday when three persons went about s... Read More

PUNE: Vandals damaged 35 vehicles early on Sunday behind the Sahakarnagar police station, smashing the headlamps and display consoles with iron rods. Another 13 vehicles were damaged in Pimpri the same day around the same time by miscreants.

Both acts came after the damage to eight vehicles parked in Warje-Malwadi area by eight men late on Friday. The Warje police on Saturday arrested Vishal Ashok Sonawane (24) of Warje and booked seven of his accomplices for the damage.

The suspects, armed with sharp weapons, went on the rampage to terrorise the local residents. They damaged a school van, scooters, and an autorickshaw. A hunt is on for Sonawane's accomplices.

Hemant Rajendra Ingle, a ration shop owner from Sahakarnagar area, has lodged a complaint with the police in the Sahakarnagar incident. The suspects damaged 30 two-wheelers (motorcycles and scooters), the wind shields of two tempos and two autorickshaws.

The Sahakarnagar police have booked three unidentified men for damaging the vehicles parked on a public road, and hurling abuses.

Deputy commissioner of police (Zone II) Shirish Sardeshpande, assistant commissioner of police Shivaji Pawar, senior inspector Nandkumar Bidwai and others surveyed the damage. Sardeshpande said vandalism took place around 2.30am.

Sub-inspector Gaurav Dev from the Sahakarnagar police station said, "Local residents who came out of their houses saw three men, one of them with an iron rod. They walked around in the area with the iron rod damaging the parked vehicles ."

Dev said local residents told the police that the trio was drunk, shouting and abusing loudly."The reason behind their act is not known. We are trying to ascertain their identities. The area does not have CCTV surveillance," he said.

Two police teams have been formed and they are combing the area to trace the suspects. Dev said they suspect the vandals could be local residents.

Sachin Aglave, whose two-wheeler was damaged, said he had bought the motorcycle two years ago. "It was dear to me. The vandals damaged the console, the mudguard and the petrol tank. I am sad."

Another resident, Prashant Kale, whose vehicle was also damaged said "I use my motorcycle daily for my work. I cannot imagine that somebody can do this."

Another group of vandals used sticks and rods to damage 13 vehicles at Thermax Chowk in Pimpri on Sunday morning.

The Pimpri police said the suspects damaged two-wheelers, a car and autorickshaws parked on a road around 3am on Sunday.

The suspects came to the spot on a motorcycle and then damaged the vehicles.

The reason for the vandalism is not known.

Title: Chennai: Supply up, tomato prices touch Rs 15 a kilogram in retail
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Time is ripe to have tomato soup and chutney.

Due to a good monsoon and increased supply, the retail price of tomatoes has come down 10 and touched 15 in city. The native variety is available for 8 a kilogram at the Koyambedu market and it is available for 13 to 15 a kilogram at retail shops. The Bengaluru variety is available at Rs 15 in wholesale and 30 to 35 a kilogram in retail stores.

Traders at Koyambedu market said supply of tomatoes has increased by 50% in the past few weeks. "We used to get 40 loads of tomatoes every day. Now it has increased to 60 loads a day due to increase in produce," said V R Soundararajan from the Koyambedu Traders' Association.

In Madurai, the price dropped to 7 a kilogram at wholesale markets and to 10 in retail markets. Last month, the wholesale rate was 40 a kilogram.

With prices dropping, the Madurai central market which gets tomatoes from Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh has stopped getting supplies. "The price is too low to meet the transport cost so they are dumping it in the borders or stopping with Chennai," said Mattuthavani wholesale vegetable market president P S Murugan.

Cabbage and raddish are being sold at 10 a kilogram and a kilogram of kohlrabi costs 15. "They are the cheapest vegetables available now," said a vendor in T Nagar.

However, prices of coconuts and drumsticks have increased in recent weeks. While a coconut sold for 25 in the wholesale market, drumsticks sold for 110 a kilogram. "Once local produce reaches the market, these prices will come down," a vendor said.

Title: Ahmedabad: You can get long-term on-road parking permits
Content:
The parking rates will be calculated on the basis of daily 12 hour parking charges on any street

AHMEDABAD: You can now get some relief from the daily squabbles over parking space with your colleagues at your office complex. In a few days, you will be able to apply for a monthly to annual on-street parking permits at your local Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation ( AMC ) zonal office.Long duration and overnight parking on public roads, be it outside residential societies which are short of space or busy commercial complexes, will not be free any more. After implementing on commercial streets’, the same permit system will be extended to residential societies in a short time. Only 40 per cent of the road stretches will be designated for permit holders.Parking permits will be demand-based, and shall be issued to individuals, while group permits for institutions, corporates, shops and establishments, clubs to hospitals and in some time to residential societies as well. “The permits will not be restricted to just on-street but will even extend to nearby multi-level parking lots as well. The latter will have discounted monthly rates in comparison to onstreet parking permits,” said a senior AMC official. The permit system is flexible such that even institutions or groups of individuals can approach the AMC to designate a road as a parking stretch. “The AMC will examine the road stretch to see whether there will be traffic hindrances,” adds the AMC estate official.The parking rates will be calculated on the basis of daily 12 hour parking charges on any street and multiplied over the number of days of permit sought from the AMC. “We will be installing an electronic parking monitoring system to keep track of space available,” adds the official. The officials also added that discussions are on to halve the monthly permit charges while keeping the 12 hour charges as base rate.Municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra said, “Our permit system will be unique in the country, and an individual can approach us for parking space.” On the comprehensive parking policy for the entire city Nehra said that the policy is ready and is being examined by the legal department in the wake of recent high court and Supreme Court orders over the issue.

Title: 3D print helps save 7-year-old's leg in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The team of doctors included Dr Salunke, Dr Mayur Kamani and Dr Vishal Bhabhor

AHMEDABAD: Geeta (name changed), 7, a native of Devbhoomi Dwarka , complained to her parents of an unusual swelling near her knee in October last year. When the doctors diagnosed it as a cancerous tumour , her parents feared the leg might need amputation to save her.

Three months later, she underwent a complex surgery at Gujarat Cancer Research Institute (GCRI) at Civil Hospital where a team of doctors used a novel method to ensure that her tumour was removed and her own bone re-fixed after cryosurgery - a process where the tumour is exposed to liquid nitrogen at -185 degrees celsius.

Dr Abhijeet Salunke, orthopaedic oncosurgeon, GCRI, said that in usual cases, a tumour so close to the knee leaves no other option but to cut it from the spread above, resulting in loss of limb. "With help of a local designer, we got the exact replica of the tumour-affected femur (thigh) bone along with a jig. The 3d model was created based on CT and MRI scans and gave up to millimetre precision," he said.

The surgery, that lasted for six hours last week, included the surgeons cutting exact 18 cm of the bone along with the tumour with the help of a jig - an instrument to guide the precise cuts - designed for the patient, putting the bone in liquid nitrogen for 20 minutes, treating it and then affixing it again at the same spot with the tumour removed. The team of doctors included Dr Salunke, Dr Mayur Kamani and Dr Vishal Bhabhor. The tumour weighed 1.5 kg and caused blood loss of 500 ml.

Dr Shashank Pandya, director of GCRI, said the condition the girl had is identified as Ewing's sarcoma of femur bone. "It was just 3cm away from the knee joint and was difficult to remove through conventional methods. The girl's surgery is successful and we are hopeful she will be back on her feet nine months after the treated bone establishes connection with adjoining bones," he said.

The team members claimed that it was a unique surgery using a combination of 3D printing and cryosurgery. They added that while computer-aided surgery can perform a similar feat, the method they employed is much more economical and suitable for countries like India.

Title: Chandigarh: Rock Garden trees turning into stone
Content:
The artful hands of Nek Chand gave a junkyard a new life as Rock Garden but a falling standard of upkeep sinc... Read More

The standard of upkeep has declined

CHANDIGARH: The artful hands of Nek Chand gave a junkyard a new life as Rock Garden but a falling standard of upkeep since he left threatens to kill this wonder of the modern world. The tree cover of this major international tourist attraction is dying a slow death.Hundreds of people visit the place daily to admire hundreds of sculptures that Nek Chand made out of discarded material such as construction waste, smashed tiles, broken bangles, shattered ceramics, rags, cracked switchboards, cast-off lanterns, and mountain cobble. For a tourist place that is just 62 years old, Rock Garden's speed of decline is shocking.The sculpture park was born in the cover of a forest full of green trees on all sides. The trees that came in the way of the sculptures were incorporated in the art. Since now these trees added to the beauty of the stone figures, it saved them from cutting. Genius, you would say, but with the passage of time, a poor upkeep started killing these trees that are as much as part of Nek Chand's work as the concrete and stone that he used.The management of Rock Garden is now in the hands of the UT administration. The jurisdiction of Nek Chand Foundation is now limited. Anuj Kumar, son of Nek Chand, said: "We have no say in the management of Rock Garden. I did point out to the administration that the garden's trees needed care. Despite being notified, the UT authorities took no action to save the trees."After months of trying to persuade the civic authorities to clear concrete from around the tree bases, a local NGO ( non-governmental organization ) has filed a petition in National Green Tribunal (NGT) against the trend of strangling the trunks while concretizing the sidewalks. L R Budaniya, an environmentalist working ardently to save the city's environment said: "By cementing the tree base, they kill the roots first and then the tree itself, gradually. Gardeners call this area protected root zone, and it should be unoccupied for the health of the tree. When concrete is put over the roots or the soil dug up to build patios or cemented structures, the damage to the roots is irreparable."Concrete-covered trees are common inside Rock Garden and no one cases to give these trunks any breathing space. Budaniya said: "Looking at how the trees have been cemented without anybody's noticing it, one can't believe that the area is a protected forest. The other departments might not be aware of the ill effects of cementing the tree bases, but being a custodian of our environment, the forests wing has no excuse for this negligence."One of Rock Garden's long-time visitors, Gurpreet Singh, said: "I have been admiring this marvel since my childhood but am unfortunate to also see this piece of grand art dying a slow death of late. When the great Nek Chand was alive, these walkways were not cemented and trees stood tall and green in the mud. Now all the area around the roots is cemented, which has strangulated the trunks. The UT administration has a duty to save the beauty of Rock Garden."

Title: Lip-smacking vegetarian food, beverages wow Puneites
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

A food stall at the gourmet fest (left); a girl eats a slice of pizza.

PUNE: Good food, live music and a steady flow of beverages ensured Puneites had a great time at The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest.

A first-of-its-kind vegetarian food festival , Green Dot received an overwhelming response on Sunday as food lovers thronged to Vrindavan Lawns at Baner Road to indulge in an assortment of gourmet vegetarian fare.

For hardcore foodie Veena Joshi, Sunday evening was a special delight. "Being a vegetarian and a foodie, it's hard to find specially curated food festivals like this. This was a perfect Sunday for me and I had a fun evening listening to music by the band RDX and sampling the different cuisines," she said. Joshi particularly enjoyed the "hurda", a Maharashtrian winter delicacy. "I loved that dish. It was perfect for this weather," she said.

Anirudh Patil, founder of Pune Eat Outs - an online community of food-lovers - was responsible for the curating the cuisine experience. "Curating vegetarian meals meant having fun with all things vegetarian. We loved opening up the palate for people to experience. Green Dot was not about preaching vegetarianism. It was simply about giving the participants a chance to savour the vegetarian food palette."

Food blogger Darpan Chordia said, "There are very few options across various cuisines at regular food festivals and that is what sets Green Dot apart. An assortment of only vegetarian dishes across cuisines was made available at the festival, which we thoroughly enjoyed. We tried tandoor, Chinese, shwarma, raj kachori, bamboo biryani and much more."

Another food blogger Sonal Khule said, "We relished the Litti Chokha, which is not readily available in the city. We also found milk puddings at the festival which was very fresh and tasty."

The food bloggers, while enjoying the delicacies, also swarmed across the various food stalls, mixology sessions and masterclass. They lined up to click photographs of the event and save the memories of the delightful atmosphere.

Another food blogger, Nikita Sojoni said, "This first-of-its-kind vegetarian food festival was a different and delightful experience. I tried various dishes at multiple stalls and all of them were a treat."

Several workshops were also held as part of the event, with a cookery class for children, followed by a mixology session by chefs from Radisson Blu and Lemon Tree Hotels.

Nupur Pittie held a session in the evening about "Building H2O People". Her talk focused on how finding the right food can make people say goodbye to medicines. "People have a habit of relying on medicines. What we forget is that we have most of the ingredients to stay healthy at our homes," she said.

The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest is powered by VTP Realty and curated by Pune Eat Outs. Associate sponsors are Girikand Holidays and Ranka Jewellers.

Title: Laxma Goud: Laxma Goud hosts high tea for art frat
Content: Padma Shri award-winner and eminent artist K Laxma Goud showcased some of his latest works to his colleagues at his newly-unveiled studio in the city recently.Hyderabad’s art fraternity came out in numbers to congratulate the artist and caught up with old colleagues from the industry, while discussing in detail the works on display.Laxma Goud’s works on various mediums, including canvas, terracotta and teakwood, were on display and his fellow artists were seen looking at them in admiration.Veteran artist Thota Vaikuntam , Laxman Aelay and Nagesh Goud were some of the artists who graced the occasion, while prominent names in the Hyderabadi art scene, such as Anju Poddar and Sheetal Bangur, were also present at the do.

Title: Laxma Goud: Laxma Goud hosts high tea for art frat
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Rashami reveals she didn't know about Arhaan’s marriage or kid; was just supporting him in the game
Content: Saumya Tandon of Bhabhi Ji Ghar Par Hain fame has finally rested all the speculations around her participation in the upcoming season of Bigg Boss. The actress shared a fun video where she can be seen reacting to the rumours and clearly denying all of them.

Title: Sai Sushanth Reddy: Sai Sushanth turns hero with a romcom-meets-fantasy flick
Content: When Sai Sushanth Reddy made his debut as the charming and sophisticated Karthik, aka Jubilee Hills, in his debut film Ee Nagaraniki Emaindi (ENE), he took everyone by surprise, holding his own amidst a brilliant cast. yet, he had to wait for over a year before he found the next film he wanted to be part of. That wait ended with Raghavendra Varma’s Bombhaat, which will see Sushanth play the solo lead, as against his debut film which had an ensemble cast. “I’ve waited for this film for a while now, so I’m grateful for this opportunity,” he says.So, what made him say yes finally? “Well, it’s a romantic comedy with some sci-fi elements as well, so that’s something I am excited about. And, the film has two heroines — Simran Choudhary and Chandini Chowdary ,” he quips, adding, “On a serious note, the script and my character drew me to this film. I play a final year college student who isn’t very lucky. He’s a happy-go-lucky guy, but he’s put in a situation he is unable to control. I had a lot of fun playing this role.”Apart from the fun he had on set with co-stars Simran and Chandini, it was the experience of working with veterans that Sushanth cherishes most. “Sharing the screen with stalwarts like Tanikella Bharani and Makarand Deshpande was like a dream come true.... I learnt so much just being around both of them,” he says.Sushanth recently met with the ENE team, sparking rumours that a sequel is in the offing. he’s careful not to reveal much about it though. “I can’t confirm or deny that news at this point. I haven’t said yes to anything yet, because I want to work only in unique films, which have a narrative that excites me.” for a one-film-old actor, some would say he’s being a tad too choosy. but Sushanth is clear about his priorities. “My first film changed everything for me. People now recognise me wherever I go. when I’m hanging out with my friends, they come tell me that they like the way I act. it feels great to have your work appreciated, and I want to keep doing good work.”

Title: Ahmedabad: Four booked for forgery, cheating
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Kanu Makwana, 45, of Valmiki Avas Yojana housing scheme lodged a complaint of cheating at Naroda police station on Saturday against four persons, Raman Solanki, his wife Gauri Solanki and son Harshad Solanki and one Faiz Mohammad of Shahpur. The accused have been booked under sections of cheating and also under the SC/ST act.

The FIR states that Makwana and his family had been duped by the accused into believing they had been allotted a house in TP Scheme 99 against Rs 3 lakh. A few days after Makwana shifted to the house with his family, MEGA officials arrived and asked them to vacate the premises as the houses had been allotted for rehabilitation of those displaced by project work of MEGA.

When Makwana's documents, including receipts and letter of allotment were checked they were found to be forged. Consequently, upon Makwana's narration of the story, police registered a case of cheating.

According to the FIR the accused met Makwana about two years ago and promised him allotment of a house in TP Scheme 99. Raman Solanki took Makwana to Faiz Mohammad Shaikh of Shahpur, who has an office in Danilimda after Makwana paid Raman Rs 3 lakh. "Shaikh gave Makwana receipts of money paid to AMC and the signed house allotment documents, along with keys of the house," said a police official.

Title: Despite advantages, Chennai airport grows at snail’s pace
Content:
File photo of Chennai airport

CHENNAI: The city airport may be growing, but it’s at such a sluggish pace that it may soon lose its tag as the country’s fourth busiest airport in terms of total passengers handled. It may lose the position to Kolkata or Hyderabad. Chennai, despite geographical advantage, is struggling with limitations in ground infrastructure due to inadequate space in passenger terminals and runways.Delhi is the busiest airport in the country followed by Mumbai, Bengaluru and Chennai. Kolkata is in fifth place followed by Hyderabad.Chennai airport registered a marginal increase of 1.6% in passenger traffic in April-December 2019 compared to the period last year. But Kolkata is edging closer to Chennai with a faster growth rate of 3.8%. While Chennai handled 1.73 crore passengers in April-December 2019, Kolkata and Hyderbad airports were close behind, handling just 3.82 lakh and 4.58 lakh passengers less. An AAI official said airlines’ interest to connect Kolkata with foreign destinations and connectivity to small towns has put Kolkata airport on a faster path of growth.Meanwhile, Bengaluru is way ahead of Chennai in terms of passenger volume. The airport handled 2.51 crore passengers in the said period, fuelled by an increase in domestic flights. The airport is also expanding its international operations, using as leverage its location in the middle of the peninsular south.AAI had plan to convert Chennai into an international hub like Dubai or Singapore because it is located on the intercontinental air routes — it lies in the middle of the air route that links Europe-Middle East with Southeast Asia and Australia. But it did not take off because of poor planning and slow construction of facilities.An AAI official said city airport also could not campaign with airlines and businesses the way a private airport could do to boost the number of flights. “Bengaluru overtook Chennai because of a robust business climate there and a full fledged airport with no limitations in ground infrastructure,” he added.Air Passengers Association of India national president D Sudhakara Reddy said: “The city airport can be considered one of the worstmanaged airports in our country. Promises to upgrade toilets, immigration and other facilities have not been carried out. Inline baggage handling systems were installed after a seven-year drag. How can you expect to see growth? Many large industrial groups of Chennai ask their international visitors to land in Bengaluru and take them to their plants around Oragadam, Sriperumbudur, Hosur by car. Bengaluru and Hyderabad offer top class service.”

Title: Ahmedabad: Families here earn their bread by making rotis
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The roti-making business was not planned but started by chance

AHMEDABAD: For those who require a few hundred rotis for a wedding reception or find it burdensome to cook rotis at home, the " roti lane " in the Walled City area of Jamalpur is the go-to place. A dozen-odd families here earn their livelihood by preparing and selling rotis .

While marriage reception orders for rotis do come in regularly, what keeps their business going steady are requirements of the roadside eating joints of the city.

These eateries, along with many hotels, purchase hundreds of rotis from these roti-makers every day. Each family prepares a minimum of 500 rotis on a daily basis.

Interestingly, the now-flourishing roti-making business was not planned, but took off by chance. "Our houses are located along the road and we make rotis sitting just outside our doorstep. People passing by used to inquire if we sell the rotis and that is how we thought of making and selling rotis," said Raisa Aapa Chhipa, one of the roti makers of Jamalpur area of the city.

Raisa Aapa used to work as a domestic help earlier, but roti-making is now her full-time profession. "My two daughters and I make rotis for our living. We make about 500 rotis every day," she said.

When the business started off a little over a decade ago, the families sold rotis for one rupee each. With flour prices constantly on the rise, they increased the price of each roti to Rs 1.50 about five years ago. More recently, about a year ago, some of the families hiked the price of each roti to Rs 2.50, while others still sell rotis for two rupees each.

Ayubbhai Kalujiwala, who sold retail readymade garments at the Bhadra market until a few years ago, now earns his living by making rotis. "The readymade clothes business was not doing well. My family earns more by making rotis," he said.

Firoz Shaikh, who runs a roadside egg eatery in Khamasa area of the city, said he purchases 200 rotis everyday from those who prepare rotis in Jamalpur. "I visit the lane everyday at around sunset and purchase the rotis. Customers prefer rotis instead of bread," he said.

Title: Ahmedabad reported highest rape cases in Gujarat
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Ahmedabad, which is often hailed as the safest city for girls and women, may lose this prestigious tag. According to the latest figures of the CID crime, the city reported the highest 81 out of 525 rape cases reported in the state.Ahmedabad which has nearly 9% of the state’s population has continued to report over 10% of the total rape cases in the state since 2015, states figures of the CID crime Gujarat.The city has also recorded increase in number of rapes from 45 in 2015 to 81 in 2019. For past five years, the city has always recorded the highest numbers of rapes across the state.Last month, when the Ahmedabad city police commissioner, Ashish Bhatia held a press conference to inform about crimes in the city, he did not provide figures of crime against women. Bhatia said that he was not aware of the figures of rape cases. A senior police official said that in many instances it has been found that the case was filed when the promise of marriage was broken. Activist Manjula Pradeep vehemently opposed this argument alleging that the police always doubt statements of rape survivors.“The rate of crime against women has been increasing in Ahmedabad which is linked to social parameters like skewed sex ratio and other issues,” said Pradeep. She said that public movements against rape have also made the women come forward and register their complaints.

Title: Fresh ASQ survey: Patna airport jumps 223 places to be at 102nd
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Huge rush at Jayaprakash Narayan International Airport in Patna on Sunday.

PATNA: The rank of Jayaprakash Narayan International Airport- Patna in the Airport Service Quality (ASQ) survey improved from 325th during July to September to 102nd in the fourth quarter (October-December) of 2019, according to a recent report released by Airports Council International (ACI).

Thanks to constant increase in number of passengers and flights and ongoing construction work, the airport has achieved the overall 4.5 ASQ rating out of five in the fourth quarter, when compared to 3.56 ASQ rating in the third quarter of 2019.

According to the latest figures issued by the Airports Authority of India (AAI), Patna airport handled altogether 35,13,060 passengers between April and December in the current fiscal against 31,12,896 passengers it handled during the same period last financial year.

The ASQ survey based on the performance of the city airport on 29 parameters related to passenger services revealed that it scored perfect five in ease of making connections with other flights.

Patna airport director Bhupesh C H Negi said the improved rating was mainly due to the improvement in passenger amenities. "Teamwork and collaborative approach of all stakeholders at the airport contributed to the improved ratings," he said.

Negi added, "Helpdesk counter, new parking facilities, food kiosk and restaurant at terminal building and a pre-fabricated structure on eastern side of the airport went a long way in improving the ranking of the airport. New entry and exit routes have also been opened at the airport."

Patna airport significantly improved in business/executive lounge with 4.42 rating, closely followed by shopping facilities (4.09), availability of bank/ATMs /money changers (4.58), restaurant and eating facilities (4.06), value for money of restaurant/eating facilities (4.11), internet access/Wi-Fi (4.53), speed of baggage delivery (4.28) and value for money of shopping facilities (3.99).

Slight improvement was witnessed in areas like ground transportation to/from airport, parking facilities, availability of baggage carts/trolleys, waiting time in check-in queue/line and passport, efficiency, courtesy and helpfulness of check-in staff, thoroughness of security inspection, ease of finding your way at airport, flight information screens and walking distance inside the terminal.

Negi said more check-in counters, X-ray baggage scanners and frisking booths would come up at the airport by March.

Title: Chandigarh: Man booked for duping bank of Rs 20 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: A Zirakpur resident was booked for allegedly cheating a bank of Rs 20 lakh after taking a loan to purchase an SUV on forged sales letter and invoices.

The accused has been identified as Jatinder Pal Singh . Police said the accused had applied for loan at State Bank of India 's branch in Sector 8 to buy a Toyota Fortuner SUV in 2014. He allegedly produced fake invoices and sales letter at the bank and obtained a loan of Rs 20 lakh.

The fraud came to light when the accused stopped paying his monthly loan instalments after a few months. When bank officials reached his house, they found the accused was not living there. Later, bank officials checked with the vehicle agency and found that the accused had given a booking amount of Rs 50,000 for the SUV but later cancelled the deal and took the money back. SBI bank manager Mohinder Singh Lamba then filed a written complaint at SSP public window.

After verifying the facts, Sector 19 police registered a case under Sections 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using as genuine a forged document), 120-B (criminal conspiracy) of the IPC.

Title: Ahmedabad: When the blind navigated the journey
Content:
The BPA-Round Table Car Rally attracted 92 drivers for its annual event on Sunday

AHMEDABAD: It was a car rally with a difference - the car driver can see but doesn't know the road ahead whereas the navigator cannot see but has the roadmap to the finishing line! The BPA-Round Table Car Rally attracted 92 car drivers for its annual event on Sunday. The event was flagged off by city police commissioner Ashish Bhatia from the Blind People 's Association (BPA) premises.Bhatia told media that the event would create awareness about the causes of persons with disabilities and traffic rules.Kanishk Sajnani, an IT professional from the city who secured the first place in the event, said that it was his fourth participation in the event. "I participated for the first time in 2017 and since then, I was hooked to the concept. I was third in the first attempt and first in the second. So I am glad about the result today," he said. "The event has an important lesson in identifying strengths in everyone.My navigator was exceptional in reading the route and guiding me throughout which amazed me."The event covered important landmarks of the city. "It's not a race and there are no points for coming first just by speed - the teams have to cover all the marshal points in stipulated time. The entire route was 42km this year and covered different terrains and areas in both eastern and western city parts," said an organizer, adding that there were six all-women teams this year.For Dhirendra Chauhan, a teacher at BPA, it was fifth event as a navigator. "I can't see the road but I keep the driver on course. I look forward to the event as it helps me forge new relationships. It always gets the teams talking about our lives and challenges we face," he said.

Title: Realty ace Sandeep Mathrani is WeWork CEO
Content: BENGALURU: WeWork has appointed real estate veteran Sandeep Mathrani as its new chief executive from February 18, replacing the two incumbent co-CEOs who have been running the show since the co-working company ran into rough weather in September after its botched initial public offering (IPO).Mathrani, an Indian-American, joins from US-based real estate management company Brookfield Properties, where he was the CEO of its retail division. He will be part of the board and report to executive chairman Marcelo Claure. He was also the CEO of General Growth Properties for eight years prior to his stint at Brookfield. General Growth Properties, one of the largest shopping mall operators in the US, was acquired by Brookfield in 2018.“We have led an exhaustive search to identify a collaborative partner who is dedicated to the future success of WeWork. Sandeep is that person. He is the partner of choice with the right skills and experience as we work to execute WeWork’s transformation. He is a proven leader with turnaround expertise in the real estate industry,” said Claure.Mathrani said WeWork has redefined how people and companies approach work with an innovative platform. He said it has an exceptionally talented team and significant potential if it sticks to its shared values and maintain its members-first focus.WeWork, now controlled by SoftBank, said the co-CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham will remain through the transition period. While Minson was the chief operating officer, Gunningham joined as vice-chairman after holding senior positions in Amazon and Apple.Mathrani comes in after a tumultuous period for the New York-based firm. We-Work was rocked to the core after it withdrew its IPO following a tepid investor response and a crash in its valuation. Subsequently, founder Adam Neumann stepped down, and prime backer SoftBank came in with fresh funds to rescue it from going bust.The appointment shows that WeWork is trying to position itself as a real estate player focused on leasing out office spaces more than as a technology startup based on the shared economy principle. A lot of investor scepticism during the IPO road show was because of the lack of clarity on what exactly the company’s business model was. People also wondered whether and how the company will turn profitable after guzzling billions of dollars in funding.The company has plans to achieve profitability on an adjusted ebitda basis by 2021 and positive free cash flow the next year.

Title: Double trauma: After rape, survivor suffers acid attack in Meerut
Content:
Representative image

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

MEERUT: A 16-year-old rape survivor was attacked with acid allegedly by family members of the accused in Hapur on Sunday morning. She has sustained burn injuries in her leg and is currently under medical observation. Her family claimed that the family of the accused were pressuring them to withdraw the rape case.Family of the survivor has claimed that the accused have been pressuring them to strike a compromise in the rape case. "The family of the accused was threatening us for an out-of-court settlement. When we refused, they attacked us and threw acid on the girl. They were armed with lathis and fire arms, and attacked other family members as well," a relative of the survivor said.Several other family members of the victim were also attacked have sustained injuries in varying degrees. Based on their complaint, an FIR was filed against three named accused - Muneer, Tariq and Nooruddin - and other unidentified accused at Babugarh police station in Hapur. "No arrests have been made, but a few people have been apprehended," a sleuth investigating the case said.Police claimed that the girl had accused two of her neighbours of rape in June 2019.Later, an FIR was filed in September against Dilshad and Muneer. Based on the investigation, police pressed charges against Dilshad who was arrested and is currently in jail and gave clean chit to Muneer.As per police, the brawl ensued on Sunday morning between the family of the rape survivor and the accused over throwing of garbage."At around 6 am, the two families confronted each other over throwing of garbage. The altercation which began with women from the respective families soon swelled into full-blown brawl after men from both sides joined in," ASP Sarvesh Mishra said.Staff at district hospital has confirmed that the girl has suffered burn injuries caused by acid.Her other family members who were injured in the attack were also provided medical aid."The condition of the victim is stable. Circumstances under which the minor rape victim was attacked with acid is being probed," the ASP said.In Video: Double Trauma: Teenage rape survivor attacked with acid in UP

Title: Idea of tax charter came up between 2 meetings
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman with minister of state for finance Anurag Thakur (left) in Parliament befo... Read More

NEW DELHI: It was during a quick exchange, while moving from one meeting to another in the finance ministry corridors, that principal economic adviser Sanjeev Sanyal brought up the possibility of a tax charter being part of the Budget with finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman .

The argument was that while the government had acted to assure taxpayers, particularly businesses, that they would not be subjected to harassment, discussion of a “trust deficit” just would not go away. Dodgy officials were sacked and assessment made faceless, but the edginess among taxpayers persisted.

More discussions followed as a search for global examples revealed that very few countries had considered such measures. The idea seemed to gain traction, particularly as the government remained concerned over the need to stamp out the perception of arbitrary action by the tax bureaucracy.

Sitharaman gave it a thought, but did not say much to Sanyal. If the proposal was to make it to the Budget, it would be shrouded in secrecy. The charter, which the minister said would spell out assurances to tax assessees, found the approval of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and became a much discussed element of the Budget.

Budget discussions, sources said, were on for the past several months. In fact, the process began soon after the first Budget of the Modi 2.0 government was presented. The slowdown in growth, woes of the auto sector, unprecedented rains and damage to crops presented an urgent situation.

While the government came out with major announcements like cuts in corporate tax, a Rs 25,000-crore package for housing and Rs 102 lakh crore for infrastructure projects, work on the Budget continued. The meetings often began at Sitharaman’s office at 10:30 am, broke a couple of hours later, and some times officials reconvened in the after noon.

The minister also undertook widespread interactions, in different cities, with sections of consumers, investors, trade and business. The feedback was noted and fed into the discussions. Some demands like GST rate reductions and other “breaks” were predictable. But other suggestions were more meaningful from the point of view of addressing regulation and credit blockages, holding back growth.

The wealth of detail the ministry evaluated, sources said, contributed to a Budget speech of record length. The emphasis was to establish that resource commitments were backed by plans and would not remain pledges. As she made her way through her speech, Sitharaman ignored suggestions that she sip some water. There were lozenges from road transport and highway minister Nitin Gadkari instead.

Title: UT to submit report on steps taken to control air pollution till December 2019
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The Union government has directed the Chandigarh administration to submit details of steps taken to control ai... Read More

CHANDIGARH: The Union government has directed the Chandigarh administration to submit details of steps taken to control air pollution in the city till December 31, 2019.

A senior UT official said they would soon submit the report to the Union government. Besides, they would also submit a report to the National Green Tribunal (NGT) in this regard.

The UT, in its action plan to control air pollution, had submitted various plans from promoting battery-operated vehicles, green buffers along the traffic corridors and introducing intelligent traffic management system. The action plan was submitted to the Union government last year.

The UT had also submitted that they had already launched extensive drive against polluting vehicles and had even prepared an action plan to widen roads and improvement of infrastructure for decongestion of roads.

The other initiatives mentioned in the action plan includes synchronisation of traffic signals in the city, greening of open areas, and introducing water fountain at major traffic intersections wherever feasible with the use of tertiary treated water.

The UT submitted that the ambient air quality of the city was mainly affected by the construction and demolition waste and increase in the number of vehicles.

The UT had submitted, "There has been an increase of around 60% in the number of vehicles in 10 years with no change in the length of roads. Increase of light motor vehicles (LMVs), basically cars, by more than 100% in the past 10 years in comparison to approximately 48% increase in two-wheelers. This has resulted in more congestion, ultimately contributing to air pollution."

The UT had also stated other factors, too, including road dust re-suspension, horticulture waste, and stubble burning in the neighbouring states, leading to air pollution.

The administration is also working on promoting hybrid and electric vehicles. Two years ago, a team of the transport department had visited Nagpur to study charging stations' set-up.

Nagpur was the first city in the country to have electric vehicle charging stations in place. Chandigarh has the highest density of vehicles in India with around 12 lakh registered ones, including two-wheelers and four-wheelers. The number of vehicles per house on an average is two, which has led to a sharp deterioration in air quality.

To cut down the pollution level, the Chandigarh Transport Undertaking (CTU) will induct electric buses. At present, around 3,000 e-rickshaws are plying on the city roads.

Title: Two youths found murdered in Begusarai, woman raped in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

Title: India CEO mafia: Techies with a social heart
Content:
(From left to right) Microsoft chief Satya Nadella, Google's Sundar Pichai, Adobe's Shantanu Narayen and IBM C... Read More

BENGALURU: Some are beginning to call it the ‘India Mafia’, like the PayPal Mafia. The latter was used to describe the many former PayPal employees and founders who went on to found and develop other technology companies such as Tesla, LinkedIn, Palantir, SpaceX, YouTube, Yelp, and Yammer.The India Mafia of Satya Nadella (chief of Microsoft), Sundar Pichai (Google), Shantanu Narayen (Adobe), Sanjay Mehrotra (Micron), Nikesh Arora (Palo Alto Networks), George Kurian (NetApp), and now Arvind Krishna (IBM) are all heading some of the biggest technology companies in the world. There are others too, like Thomas Kurian, CEO of Google Cloud, and Sanjay Poonen, COO of VMware. And of course, the latest appointment of Sandeep Mathrani at WeWork.What makes Indians so good in technology leadership? Vivek Wadhwa, distinguished fellow at the Carnegie Mellon University’s college of engineering at Silicon Valley, says the combination of formidable technical abilities with strong business acumen and management skills have enabled Nadella and Pichai to build the most valuable companies in the world.“But what people don’t realise is that they also have something which is usually missing in the tech world — a sense of humility and understanding of human needs. Too many of Silicon Valley’s leaders have grown up in its bubble, they are cut off from the realities of the world. They get lucky and begin to believe they are Gods. This is not a problem that Indiaborn leaders have,” he said.Something similar was pointed out by The Wall Street Journal in 2015 when it quoted a then recent cross-cultural study from Southern New Hampshire University that examined managers from the US and India. The study found that more Indian managers achieved the highest ranking in terms of leadership traits. Indian managers, the study said, are future-oriented, and had a “paradoxical blend of genuine personal humility and intense professional will...These leaders achieved extraordinary results and built great organisations without much hoopla.”Vijay Govindarajan, Coxe Distinguished Professor at Tuck at Dartmouth, also says that to lead in today’s world, a CEO must embody ‘Social Heart, Business Mind’. Indian-Americans have the ability to cultivate this,” he says.Indian CEOs are seen to have an uncanny ability to spot the “new” and turn disagreements and dissents within the firm into preparing it for the future. Nirmalya Kumar , Lee Kong Chian professor of marketing at Singapore Management University, calls it the “browning of the top management team”. Kumar says given the huge technology disruptions that are happening, companies are seeking CEOs who understand the evolving technological landscape and combine it with market insight.“It is easier to teach a technologist about markets and sales compared to bringing a marketing/sales person up to speed on technology. Previously, we needed CEOs with sales capability and an understanding of finance to compete in relatively undifferentiated, slow-moving markets,” he says. All of the India leaders built their careers as technologists, before getting into the sales and marketing side. Krishna, for instance, was a researcher for much of his career, and has co-authored 15 patents. Govindarajan says since every company is a digital company today, he expects more and more technologist CEOs, since domain knowledge is key for leading an enterprise.

Title: Gujarat: Wildlife biologist helps save threatened otters from poaching
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Widlife biologist Akhit Suthar

VADODARA: The vulnerable smooth-coated otters had been facing serious threat from poachers . The semiaquatic fish-eating mammal of the weasel family, that had made a comeback in central and south Gujarat in the past one decade only, already saw 53 animals being poached by hunters since 2011.

However, efforts by a city-based wildlife biologist to sensitize local communities on the poaching menace, not a single otter was killed in 2019.

Wildlife biologist Akhit Suthar mobilized local community including fisherman, aquaculture farm owners, woman, youth and tribal for otter conservation in Bharuch. Suthar, who works with Gujarat Ecology Society (GES) and is a member of International Union of Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Otter Specialist Group, held several meetings with local communities and also set up local information network to foil any poaching bid.

His efforts paid off last year when Suthar was one among the seven people from across the globe to be honoured by UK-based International Otter Survival Fund. Last month Suthar was awarded the 'Otter Oscars' under the research category for his research titled, 'Mitigation of illegal hunting and poaching of smooth-coated otters in south Gujarat'.

Suthar's work, which was funded by Wildlife Trust of India and Stop Poaching Fund had revealed that a gang of poachers, led by a Haryana-based man, has been targeting otters since 2011 for its water-resistant skin. The skin is smuggled to Nepal, Myanmar, China and Bhutan as it is used for making jackets, hats, mufflers and traditional skirts worn by women in China.

"This is a proud moment as this recognition encourages and helps us to work more for otter conservation and research in Gujarat," he said.

Other recipients of this award were from the USA, Scotland, Germany, Montenegro, Sri Lanka and Netherlands.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Farrukhabad abductor took YouTube lessons
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Subhas Batham’s house in Farrukhabad where Batham had held the children hostage

AGRA: Farrukhabad hostagetaker and murder convict, Subhash Batham , was a historysheeter as per police records. There were four FIRs, including theft and assaulting a Dalit, against his name. But, he was never suspected by local intelligence unit (LIU) or Mohammadabad police of making bombs.

The police said the "illiterate" man watched YouTube videos on bomb-making and kidnapping of children. On Sunday, superintendent of police, Anil Kumar Mishra, Farrukhabad, said, "Neither Subhash nor his wife were social. The couple secretively constructed a 'bunker' with ill intentions which no one was aware of. They were jointly responsible for the [children] hostage situation.

When their neighbours were unaware, then how could the police know about it?" According to Farrukhabad district police, a total of 145 crude bombs, including a cylinder bomb and a canned bomb along with wire, battery, tape, sutali (thread), 20 live cartridges, 11 used cartridges and one each 315 bore country-made rifle and pistol were recovered, but no one could sniff or had any idea from where he collected such a large quantity of weapons and explosive powder.

Subhash, who had arranged a fake birthday party for his oneyear-old daughter and then held more than 20 children as hostage at Kathariya village in Farrukhabad, was shot dead by police after nearly a 10-hour standoff. Angry locals later reportedly beat his wife to death.

"Around one-and-a-half months ago, Subhash was released from jail after being arrested by SOG team in a theft case. Scanning through mobile phone history recovered from his home revealed that he watched YouTube videos on bomb-making and kidnapping of children. Though, he was illiterate," said special operation group, Farrukhabad in-charge Dinesh Kumar Gautam. While LIU in-charge, Preeti Singh said, "LIU had no idea about his ammo stock or from where he gathered the explosives."

Title: 'States need to boost ease of doing business': Niti Aayog vice-chairman
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Niti Aayog vice-chairman Rajiv Kumar (File photo)

NEW DELHI: State governments will now have to accelerate their move on ease of doing business to remove bottlenecks for investors and the taxpayer charter will help instil confidence and end harassment, a top official said on Sunday.

“Most follow-up now has to be done at the level of the states. The Economic Survey gives the example of, if you want to run a restaurant, you need 43 clearances. In those 43 clearances, I doubt if more than one or two would be at the central government level, the rest would be municipal, state, that is where the rubber meets the road. Investment climate will be improved now by reforms of state governance and ease of doing business,” Niti Aayog vice-chairman Rajiv Kumar told TOI in an interview.

“One of the biggest obstacles to improving investor sentiment is tax terrorism, which now has been finally recognised. Now you have a taxpayers’ charter, you got the dispute-resolution mechanism. The government wants the tax system to be hands off and the PM has reiterated this several times,” said Kumar, while reacting to the Budget proposals unveiled by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday.

Kumar said the Budget proposals will help improve sentiment, raise investment and boost overall growth, which is estimated to slow to an 11-year low of 5% in the current fiscal year.

“The real rise in growth comes through investment and investment demand and there I am very happy to note the Budget has several measures to improve the return on investment and also the investor sentiment. The dividend distribution tax has been removed, the impact of 15% concessional rate of tax not just on manufacturing but also on power generation, the tax concession to sovereign wealth funds, the tax concession to the builders plus the tax dispute-resolution mechanism.”

“All these measures will help to improve investment, which in turn will improve growth. The second part is the 20% increase in capital expenditure. So within the constraints of the fiscal, these measures will boost investment and growth,” said Kumar, referring to the government’s move to relax the fiscal deficit target by 0.5 percentage points this year to boost spending.

Kumar said the Budget emphasis on improving the data system in the country would help usher in changes as the issue needs urgent attention. “Reliability, credibility, coherence, consistency and time — those are key features of a good statistics system. We must move towards that and sooner the better. We have neglected this for a very long time. Whatever it takes we must finish it in one or two years.”

Title: Gujarat: Groundnut scam rocks Junagadh market yard
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Groundnut scam has returned to haunt Junagadh Market Yard

RAJKOT: The ghost of groundnut scam has returned to haunt Junagadh Market Yard where 156 gunny bags of groundnut (containing 35kg each) were yet again found filled with cheaper quality of produce on Saturday night.

"When we carried out inspection, we found 156 gunny bags of groundnut which were either wet or of cheaper quality. The bags, which were supposed to be sealed in the presence of farmers , were not done so," said Yogesh Vala, manager of Gujarat Civil Supply Department, Junagadh.

The inspection was conducted after Khedut Hit Rakshak Samity, a farmers' body raised a hue and cry about the possibility of a groundnut scam.

"When we checked the footage of CCTV cameras installed inside the market yard, we saw four unidentified persons sneaking into the yard who later covered the CCTVs with gunny bags. After this, the miscreants may have allegedly culled out good quality groundnut from the bags and mixed cheaper quality into the bags to maintain weight," Vala said.

Apart from the adulteration, the gunny bags also weighed less, he added.

"We have registered a case and started investigation," said K K Zala, inspector, Junagadh police station.

In August last year in Jetpur of Rajkot district , a total of 30,000 sacks of groundnuts (containing 35kg each) were found to be mixed with sand and pebbles.

Title: BJP & RJD busy making booth level agents in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

PATNA: BJP and RJD are focused on their booth level preparations for the upcoming assembly elections later this year. The two parties, slated to function as fulcrum for their respective coalitions are busy appointing their booth level agents (BLA-II) to interact with voters in their respective areas. There are 72,723 polling booths in the state.

"We have already constituted more than 67,000 booth level committees (BLCs) covering around 90% of the polling booths in state. Now, we have moved to the second stage of appointing BLA-II for the respective polling booths," BJP state vice-president Anil Sharma said. Sharma was the co-incharge of state BJP's four-tier organizational elections. A BLC has 11-20 members. Sharma also said the party's MLAs and district presidents have been asked to submit the list of BLAs to the district administrations. "Instructions have been issued in this regard," he added.

During the 2015 assembly elections, RJD had appointed the highest number of BLAs among the political parties in the state - 53,000 compared to BJP's 48,000.

There are two kinds of BLAs: BLA-I appointed by the administration to work for the Election Commission and BLA-II appointed by the respective political parties to assist the voters or even mobilize them to cast their votes in favour of their party candidates on the polling day.

RJD vice-president and former MLC Tanveer Hassan said his party had already instructed its district presidents to continue with membership drive, while ensuring that the BLAs-II were also appointed without missing the deadline set by the Election Commission for that.

Even in terms of the party's primary members, the two parties appeared to be evenly matched, reaching the figure of around 1 crore. "Last year, we had set the target of making 50 lakh primary members, but the number has reached around 1 crore - or around 80-90 lakh. Members are being made even today," Hassan added.
