Title: Aggression is Sofia Kenin's middle name
Content:
Sofia Kenin holds the Daphne Ackhurst Memorial Cup at a photo shoot on the Yarra River in Melbourne. (AP Photo... Read More

MELBOURNE: Sofia Kenin is expressive. It's in her stance, in her stride, the fire in her eyes. In the words coming at you at the pace of bullets from a Sten gun. Like her tennis, she leaves it all out there. It's all said and done, one way or the other.Kenin, who won her maiden major title at Melbourne Park on Saturday, was in tears after she turned the match around in the second set. Tears rolled down her cheeks as she collected balls, preparing to serve. Commentators picked it up and viewers wondered what was up. Those seated in the lower bowls of the Rod Laver Arena were a little stunned. Was she hurt? What was up? The 21-year-old was in control of the match, or as close to it when still live.Kenin, now the top-ranked American at No. 7 in the world, explained to the media that she was getting anxious as she approached the finish line. "I felt I was getting closer to the title, something that I really wanted. I knew I needed to somehow try and relax, just try to calm down. I looked a few times to my box. They cheered for me, calmed me down," she said.Garbine Muguruza, who was the favourite in the final, given that she had already won Major titles twice, was surprised by how well her younger opponent handled the situation. "I was nervous when I played my first Grand Slam final. She held pretty good her emotions," the 26-year-old said.Alexander, Kenin's father and coach, a man of generous build and a relaxed step, said his daughter was nervous before and during the final. She was crying before the final, also before most of her matches, coming into the title round. "She was really, really nervous. I think it's normal. How can you not be nervous? You're playing in a Grand Slam, in a final. I am nervous," said Alexander, who says the best way to handle nerves is to get busy. The duo discussed strategy, they watched previous matches, studied statistics and mapped a road. "We try to problem solve," Alexander said.Kenin says she has always been confident. "The confidence has come with all the matches that I've had success in the last year. I am the WTA 's Most Improved Player of the Year, FYI (for your information)," she said.Alexander said ever since he can remember, perhaps from the time she was battering down his garage door in Pembroke Pines, Florida , she knew where she was headed. "She always wanted to be No. 1, win a Grand Slam," he said. "She hates to lose, it's just not an option."Kenin, whose parents moved out of the Soviet Union in the late 80s, returning to Moscow only to have their daughter because they couldn't afford care in the United States, acknowledged her roots even as she embraced the American way of life."I've looked up to Maria Sharapova , Anna Kournikova . I followed their matches. I feel like I got the feisty. I saw what it's like. Maria won a Grand Slam at 17, I remember watching it on TV. I have part of Russian stuff inside me, fight and fierce," she said before adding. "And thank you to my parents for giving me the American dream."

Title: Pune: Civic body issues over 80,000 notices to tax defaulters
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The civic body may take possession of over 80,000 properties in the city as their owners failed to clear tax dues despite several reminders.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) recently issued notices to 80,000 property tax defaulters in this regard. Civic officials said the PMC has already taken possession of 35 such properties and converted them into municipal assets.

The civic body has set a property tax target of Rs1,970.2 crore for the next financial year (2020-2021).

To achieve this, new municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad has proposed a 12% hike in property tax in the draft civic budget for financial year 2020-2021, through which the PMC hopes to rope in an additional income of Rs150 crore.

“Some of the owners are genuinely incapable of paying the property tax. Legal cases pertaining to property ownership, too, have led to the pendency,” said Vilas Kanade, head of PMC’s property tax department.

He said the PMC had issued notices to the defaulters and also set a deadline for the dues to be cleared.

If the owners fail to clear their dues, a warrant is issued, following which the process of confiscation of properties starts and the PMC puts its name on the 7/12 extract of the property.

For the current fiscal, the PMC had set a property tax target of Rs2,100 crore. Of this, it has collected around Rs1,300 crore so far.

The civic administration has also started recovering tax from 11 villages that were merged in the civic limits in 2017. “Owners of around 7.8 lakh properties have paid the tax. Owners of nearly 2.4 lakh properties are yet to make the payment,” a civic official said.

The civic officials said the PMC’s revenue was likely to go up as many new properties, including those from the newly merged villages, had been registered in the past two years in the municipal limits.

Title: EC shifts out senior cop over shooting incidents
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Commission on Sunday transferred DCP (South-East) Chinmoy Biswal after it reportedly found his continuance in the post not conducive to holding a free, fair and impartial election in Delhi. The action, said sources, is linked to the firing incident at Shaheen Bagh on Saturday, in which youth from Dallupura had fired two rounds in the air near the site of ongoing protests against the Citizenship Amendment Bill.

Biswal, who EC said stands relieved from his post with immediate effect, will be replaced by Kumar Gyanesh , senior additional DCP (South-East).

Biswal, for now, will report to the ministry of home affairs, as directed by per EC.

Sources said the poll panel had received adverse reports from its observers as well as special police observer about the handling of security arrangements and policing around the site of anti-CAA protests in Shaheen Bagh. This was corroborated in the report received from the Delhi chief electoral officer, said sources. “Given that the area is so sensitive in view of the ongoing protests and the impending election and since one incident of random firing by a civilian has earlier taken place in Jamia Nagar area, it was expected that the security around the anti-CAA dharna site would be further beefed up with strict access control and constant vigil against any attempt to create a communally-charged situation. But the second firing incident happened despite EC’s directions to field-level officers at the poll review meeting held on Friday, to take swift action wherever warranted in the interest of fair, just, legal and impartial election in Delhi. It was particularly stressed that law and order arrangements in the identified vulnerable polling booths must be tightened ahead of polling day,” said an EC official.

The meeting on Friday was convened by EC for a comprehensive review of the poll arrangements including state of law and order. It was attended by a chief electoral officer of Delhi, district election officers, special commissioner of police, district commissioners of police, nodal officers and chief executives of local bodies. A second meeting was also held by EC with state chief secretary, home secretary, finance secretary, Delhi Police commissioner, Delhi CEO and special commissioners of police.

As exclusively reported by TOI earlier, EC also felt Delhi Police should have filed an FIR against Union minister Anurag Thakur and BJP leader Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma for their communal remarks, which EC has held in violation of Section 123(3A) and Section 125 of Representation of the People Act. The latter section provides for imprisonment of up to three years. A senior EC functionary had told TOI that both the district magistrate concerned and Delhi Police were empowered under CrPC and IPC to direct filing of/file and FIR in the said instances, without waiting for a direction from EC.

Title: 50 days of protests at Shaheen Bagh: 'We will stay here until they change'
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The women's protest has continued through the coldest winters, with protesters battling more than just the har... Read More

NEW DELHI: Goli Nahin Phool (Flowers not bullets) was the clarion call at Shaheen Bagh on Sunday, a day after a man opened fire a few metres away from the protest site. The aftermath of the shooting was apparent - fresh ropes had been tied to secure the barricades at the entrance of the protest site, security was heightened and outsiders' IDs were being checked. But the quiet determination of women protesters had never been so apparent before.

The women's protest has continued through the coldest winters, with protesters battling more than just the harsh weather. There have been allegations of them being politically motivated and funded by fringe groups. But they have found support in students, artists and activists. On Sunday, members of this leaderless group came together to celebrate the spirit of the women of the small neighbourhood in southeast Delhi.

The blue and yellow tent echoed with chants of " Desh ke pyaaron par, phool barsaao saaro par" as flower petals were showered on the women who have become the face of the protests against CAA, NRC and NPR.

"People use flowers to communicate love and to worship Gods. We thought it can be used here to spread the idea of peace," Jaya Aiyer, a theatre artist, a participant in the #GoliNahinPhool intitiative.

The 50th day of the sit-in had begun with a nukkad performance around 10pm. Nearly a dozen students dressed in black highlighted the hatred dominating the current political discourse. By 12pm, the crowd had swelled, with thousands gathering at the protest site, anticipating violence after Hindu Sena's call for volunteers to empty the stretch of road of protesters.

The fringe outfit later recalled its statement, but a crowd of men turned up at the protest site, demanding that the road be cleared. They shouted slogans, calling for protesters to be shot, but were later dispersed by police.

The women, aware of the threats being made just a kilometre away, were balanced in their approach. They appealed for peace at regular intervals, often reminding speakers to avoid any statement that could be construed as communal.

"Our fight is to safeguard the rights guaranteed by the constitution. Over the last few days, there have been attempts to polarise the situation but our message of inclusivity still stands," said Prakash Devi, a resident of Karol Bagh, one of the volunteers who micromanages the stage.

A few days ago, the official handle of the protest site had put out a call asking artists and influencers to come and address the crowd. Actor Kusha Kapila, famous for playing the fictional character 'Billi Maasi', was one of those who responded to the call and reached the protest site around 6, amid thundering applause.

Representatives from JNU Student's Union also reached the site around 5pm.

Addressing the gathering, Saket Moon, JNUSU vice president, said, "We students salute the courage of mothers and daughters of Shaheen Bagh. You all inspire us everyday to fight in the face of hate."

As the day came to an end, one of the women protesters commented on the role women have come to play in the current political discourse. "Women have found their political instinct for the first time in many years. They will counter the hate and change power dynamics. There's a wave of change, and until they do, we will be right here," she said.

Title: Land is still the biggest stumbling block for investors in Karnataka
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

A bird’s-eye view of the Special Economic Zone in Mangaluru

BENGALURU: For long, acquisition of farm land for industries has been a major constraint for investors in Karnataka because of bureaucratic red tape and intricate land reform laws .

The problem is so acute that about 90% of investments proposals cleared by the state government through the State High Level Clearance Committee (SHLCC) between 2013 and 2018 have not been realised due to hurdles in land acquisition, according to officials in the state industries department.

Of around 140 proposals worth Rs 49,379 crore cleared between 2013 and 2018 under Section 109, about 90%remained non-starters. About 23 proposals are said to have been dropped. Even the majority of proposals cleared in two editions of Global Investor Meets held during the BJP regime between 2008 and 2012 have remained on paper.

Keen to shake off the perception of its investorunfriendly image, the Karnataka government recently announced a plan to cut red tape by setting a 30-day time limit for bureaucratic clearances.

This seemed to have been triggered by chief minister BS Yediyurappa’s recent experience at Davos, Switzerland at the World Economic Forum. He met UK-based steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal and extended an invitation to invest in Karnataka. Mittal mentioned delays by the administration and Yediyurappa later said, “His concern seemed to be genuine.”

As a first step, the government has proposed to amend Section 109 of the Karnataka Land Reforms Act 1961, which deals with purchase of agriculture land directly by investors to make the process quick and time-bound.

The proposed amendment, likely to be tabled in the upcoming legislature session, will require competent authorities to provide permission to purchase farm land within 30 days for projects cleared by the State High Level Clearance Committee and State Level Single Window Clearance Committee. If the deadline lapses, then permission, both for purchase and land use change under Section 95 of Karnataka Land Revenue Act 1964, will be deemed to have been granted.

Though many industrialists welcomed the move, they see it as nothing more than a cosmetic change while stating adherence to rules and addressing critical issues bothering them is more important.

“The government must change its attitude towards industries, not rules. Section 109 in its current form has deadlines for giving permission for purchase of land and its conversion. The clauses of deemed permission and deemed conversion are also there. But the problem is in honouring the deadlines. There’s not even a single instance in the past 15 years where the government has met these deadlines. So, what’s the guarantee that the new 30-day timeframe will be honoured?” asks Vasant Ladava, an industrialist from Hubballi.

Another hurdle is the Karnataka Land reforms Act, which restricts non-agriculturists with over Rs 25 lakh annual income from purchasing agriculture land. This law is in place to prevent misuse of farmland and ensure food security. Earlier, the income limit was Rs 2 lakh but it was hiked to Rs 25 lakh in 2015.

This leaves investors with two options; one, to buy land from Karnataka Industrial Area Development Board, a nodal agency for acquiring land for industrial purpose, which has created 20,000 acres of land bank in select places. Two, they can buy land on their own by seeking special permission from competent authorities under Section 109 of the KLR Act, which in its current form, some industrialists allege, is a cumbersome process beset by red tape and corruption.

Both options have become investor-unfriendly in recent times. For instance, KIADB, which acquires land from farmers, will sell land to investors for profit after developing it. “If KIADB acquired land for Rs 50 lakh per acre from farmers, it demands Rs 1.2 crore to Rs 1.5 crore per acre from investors. It also takes its own time to acquire and develop land, thereby increasing cost of investment,” says Mahendra H Ladhad, president, Karnataka Chamber of Commerce and Industries, Hubballi, Concurring with his views, a senior IAS officer, who worked in the industries department earlier, said: “Industries have been facing a tough time in land acquisition and getting approvals in Karnataka for many years. Land rates are also high when compared to neighbouring states and, as a result, Karnataka has lost substantial investment proposals to Tamil Nadu and Telangana in recent times. Though the government has put restrictions on non-agriculturists to purchase farm land, it is neither helping farmers nor industries.’’ Many industrialists believe that the only solution to end the land acquisition problem is to lift restrictions on non-agriculturists. “Like in neighbouring states Tamil Nadu and Telangana, we should allow industries to purchase land directly from farmers. The interference of government means more layers of obstacles and more scope for delays and corruption,” said another official.

Though the proposal to do away with these restrictions has been placed before the government, it often develops cold feet as they fear a backlash from farmers, a core vote-bank.

Title: Fire on water: Burhidihing river blaze brought under control
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The incidents of fire due to leakage from the pipelines are often related to crude oil theft by miscreants

GUWAHATI: A fire which broke out on Burhidihing river at Tengakhat of Duliajan in Dibrugarh on Sunday due to leakage from underwater crude oil carrying pipeline has been brought under control.

There was panic among the locals after dark smoke and flames started rising from the river.

The incidents of fire due to leakage from the pipelines are often related to crude oil theft by miscreants who try to drill holes into the pipes.

Experts are now examining the level of threat to ecosystem because of Burhidhing river fire, following the oil spill.

The site of incident is more than 600km away from Guwahati.

Title: Mangaluru: Rowdy-sheeter found stabbed to death inside car
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: A rowdy-sheeter was stabbed to death in a car by unidentified persons near Nagri in Bantwal.

Muthasim C M, 39, a resident of Chembarikka in Kasaragod, was abducted and later stabbed to death, said police.

The incident came to light on Sunday evening when locals noticed an abandoned car near Nagri and immediately informed local police.

Muthasim and his aides, including two Afghan nationals were recently arrested for a jewellery burglary in Mangaluru. He was lodged at Kalaburaghi jail before being released on bail. Soon after his release, a gang abducted him from Jevargi in Kalaburaghi and a case was registered, said police.

Three people were arrested in connection with the abduction, said Dakshina Kannada district police.

Police suspect gang rivalry behind the murder.

Muthasim has five cases registered against him - three at Bekal Police Station in Kerala, one at Ullal Police Station in Mangaluru and one under the Arms Act in Delhi.

He was in contact with Mumbai-based criminals too, said police.

Bantwal police have registered a case.

Title: Pune: Expect warmer days & nights, says IMD
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

PUNE: The India Meteorological Department ( IMD ) on Sunday has forecast warmer day and night temperatures for the city till February 6.

Although the northerly wind is expected to penetrate the state, its effect will not last for a long period. Minimum temperatures would hover between 12 degrees celsius to 13 degrees celsius which is above normal by one or two degrees.

"The effect of the northerly wind will remain for a short duration. It will not have a major impact on day and night temperatures in the city," a senior official from IMD said.

On Sunday, Pune and Lohegaon observatories recorded 13.8 degrees celsius and 15.9 degrees celsius which are above the normal by 2.6 degrees and 2.9 degrees, respectively.

Some parts of the city had overcast skies for a few hours in the morning.

"Chances of a fall in the minimum temperature is less for the second week of February as indicated by the extended range weather forecast," the official added.

Barring some locations, Madhya Maharashtra , Konkan and Goa and Marathwada regions are recording above normal day and night temperatures by 2 to 3 degrees, but all observatories in Vidarbha have recorded below normal minimum temperatures.

"The effect of northerly components in the region is intense, bringing cold temperatures than other regions," the official added. On Sunday, nine places recorded day and night temperatures below the normal by 3 to 5 degrees.

Title: At Deonar, 20 women ‘detained’ for protest bid against CAA, NRC, NPR
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The protest at Mumbai Bagh

MUMBAI: A group of women on Sunday evening tried to stage a sit-in protest against the implementation of CAA, NRC and NPR outside a garden in Deonar , but police foiled their bid, an officer said.

“The women...tried to squat on the road outside the garden. We asked them to vacate the road, but they didn't budge. We have shifted some of them to the police station. They will be released soon,” said Deonar police senior inspector Ragini Bhagwat. Additional commissioner of police Lakhmi Gautam said the women were not being detained. “The details of 20 women are being collected and they will be allowed to leave,” he added. A group of 15 graffiti artists from Delhi also joined the anti-CAA protests at Mumbra’s Shaheen Bagh, which is on since nearly a fortnight. Durriya Ghadiyali, a protester, said the artists were denied permission to create artwork on the road, so they painted their support messages on cloth banners.

The women-led vigil at Mumbai Bagh in Byculla entered its seventh night Sunday.

Former MLA Waris Pathan said, “The coordination committee of Mumbai Bagh will meet home minister Anil Deshmukh on Monday to direct police to permit us to use megaphones to address the assembly. We will also make a representation to CM Uddhav Thackeray to pass a resolution in the upcoming assembly session that the MVA government will not implement CAA-NRCNPR laws in Maharashtra... More women are joining each day, averaging 7,000 last night. Hundreds of non-Muslims are joining too. Police tried to evict them resulting in a fracas, but the women were firm.”

Activists, including actor Sushant Singh and JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh, visited Mumbai Bagh on Saturday.

Title: Sharjeel Imam: Mumbai cops to probe viral video in support of Sharjeel Imam
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Sharjeel Imam

MUMBAI: The city police will call on the organisers of a parade to inquire about a video that went viral on social media, in which slogans were allegedly raised in support of JNU student Sharjeel Imam , who was arrested for sedition recently.

In the purported video that went viral on social media, including Twitter, people are seen holding placards and banners, and raising slogans.

Imam, who was booked for sedition for his 'provocative' speeches, was sent to five-day custody under the Delhi crime branch. A case against Imam was also registered by Uttar Pradesh police for his 'controversial' speech at a protest held on January 16 at Aligarh Muslim University, where he spoke against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Title: Chennai: Loop Road turns into market on Marina promenade
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Vehicles parked on the Loop Road near Marina

CHENNAI: Traffic comes to a standstill on the Loop Road between Light House and Foreshore Estate as the beach promenade has been converted into a market by vendors.

While fish and vegetable vendors have eated into the road space, customers on wheels, who make a beeline to Marina, add to the menace by blocking the entry to the road.

The 19m-wide road has got shrunk to a few metres causing misery for motorists who use the Loop Road to reach their destinations quicker.

M Subramani, an auto rickshaw driver from Basin Bridge, said the bottleneck begins with encroachment by vendors. "The vendors selling fish occupy about 20 feet of the 60 feet wide road on either sides. Thanks to availability of fresh fish, the market attracts people from across the city... those with vehicles park them in the middle of the road," he said.

Bharati, president of South Indian Fishermen Welfare Association, said that fisherfolk have been traditionally engaged in selling fish on the stretch for several years. "It was never a road meant for vehicular traffic till two day decades ago, but a traditional pathway for fishermen to access sea," he said. Moreover, traffic congestion happens only on Sunday, he added. "About 300 vendors are operating on Loop Road," he said.

Officials of the corporation refused to comment on the traffic quagmire and said the issue of Loop Road was a sub-judice matter as a case had been filed in the Madras High Court over its expansion.

Title: Study claims to have finally found the SECRET that can make women look younger
Content: The world of beauty is forever evolving with researchers studying various aspects related to it in a quest to find out the road to eternal beauty, and now, a team of researchers has found that a facial beautification procedure- Rhinoplasty, or cosmetic nose surgery is a way to make women look younger up to three years.The study conducted by the researchers of UCLA was recently published in the journal - Aesthetic Surgery Journal.The researchers conducted the study by using the technology to study the before and after photos of a total of 100 females aged between 16 to 72.All of the women associated with the study had undergone rhinoplasty for cosmetic reasons by a UCLA surgeon and others.After 12 or more weeks later, researchers studied the standardized photographs of the women using the technology that estimates the age of a person by cropping the face from a photograph and then reaching a prediction using the algorithm."Rhinoplasty is widely recognized as a facial beautification procedure, but it isn't commonly known for its anti-aging effects," said the lead researcher, Dr. Robert Dorfman.Rhinoplasty consists of altering bone and cartilage structurally through small incisions inside the nose and when necessary around the nostril, during the time when the patient is under anesthesia."This technology allows us to accurately estimate age in an objective way and has proven to recognize patterns and features of aging beyond what the human eye can perceive," he said.The results of the study were dramatic in women over the age of 40, some of whom were estimated to look seven years younger after rhinoplasty. However, because the sample size of the 40-plus group was small of about 25 women, the researchers said that further studies need to be done to validate the results.The median age of the participants in the study was 32.According to the researcher's nose is never taken as a focus to treat aging but like any other feature of the body, nose which is made up of soft tissue, bone, and cartilage, ages too."The nose loses support as it ages and can take on a more prominent or droopy appearance," said another researcher Dr. Jason Roostaeian.The nose is also affected when other features of the face age."When we lose facial fat and volume in our cheeks, which are the canvas that our nose sits on, the nose becomes more prominent," said Roostaeian."This is something we have subjectively thought for many decades but now we have objective evidence through artificial intelligence to support this," he added.The researchers further said that the youthful appearance of the entire face can be refined by refining the nose.With inputs from ANI

Title: E-tailers seek more details from government on new seller tax
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: The top two e-tailers, Amazon and Flipkart, are worried over the introduction of new tax clause on e-commerce transactions fearing it will hurt the growth of third-party sellers online and deter small businesses to come online, according to senior industry executives. Amazon India told TOI that it will seek clarification from the government on the issue and is 'hoping for a simple and uniform tax regime'.

Sources in these firms are also of the view that the new tax should not be imposed on the gross sale value and could be charged after excluding various costs of selling online - including the marketplace fee charged by e-commerce players. Last month Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, during his India visit, had said Amazon will invest $1 billion to digitise small and medium businesses and bring 10 million small businesses online by 2025.

On Saturday, the government introduced a new withholding tax on e-commerce transactions in the union budget. What this would mean is -- companies like Amazon India and Flipkart will withhold an additional 1% tax-deduction-at-source (TDS) while making payments to merchants who sell goods on their platforms. This would be in addition to the GST tax deduction that e-tailers charge online sellers. Online sellers are worried this will impact their liquidity and e-tailers are worried that it would impact their platforms as they try to widen their base of independent sellers.

“We are studying the details, and will reach out to the government for clarifications. We hope the tax regime is simple and uniform so that millions of small and medium businesses can go online, digitise their operations and continue to contribute to growing the economy," a spokesperson of Amazon India said. Walmart-owned Flipkart has declined to comment on the matter so far.

“Small-scale sellers would now think twice about taking their business online. Instead of promoting small businesses online, it will do the opposite. Seller ecosystem will be impacted negatively,” another senior executive at an e-commerce firm said. While Amazon has 5.5 lakh sellers in India Flipkart has over a lakh sellers on its platform.

“In certain cases where the payment is not routed through e-commerce player, they would be under an obligation to withhold tax when they are not involved in collection of payments from consumers and payment to the sellers. Hence, business models may need to be re-visited to ensure that cash flow issues and procedural difficulties are minimised,” said Anil Talreja , partner, Deloitte India .

Title: Jamia News: Bought pistol seven years ago, Shaheen Bagh shooter tells cops
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Gurjar told police that he had bought it for celebratory firing during his brother's wedding and had hidden it... Read More

NEW DELHI: The pistol used by 25-year-old Kapil Gurjar to open fire at the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest site at Shaheen Bagh was acquired by him seven years ago. Gurjar told police that he had bought it for celebratory firing during his brother's wedding and had hidden it from his parents. However, he has been evading questions about where he bought the weapon.

Police are scanning through his Facebook profile to find out whether he was influenced by someone to carry out the attack. Gurjar's profile was deleted immediately after his arrest. His family's antecedents will also be analysed.

Meanwhile, a Delhi court sent Gurjar to two-day police custody. Police will verify his claims and also from where he procured his pistol.

The officer who interrogated Gurjar told TOI that he gave evasive replies when asked where he procured the pistol from. "He remained composed during the investigation, but did not cooperate much, giving multiple replies to the same question. Looking at his conversations and body language, Gurjar does not seem to be mentally disturbed," the officer said. However, Gurjar told one of the investigators, " Apne desh mein kab tak dab ke rahenge? (For how long will we live suppressed in our country)"

Gurjar's father told police he did not know about his son's plans or that he had a pistol.

The accused said that he was not affiliated with any political party and was angry because of the traffic jams due to the protests. Police have seized his mobile phone and are scanning the call data records and WhatsApp chats.

Title: Coast Guard Navik DB 02/2020 Batch application process closing today
Content:
S. No. Event Date 1 Starting Date January 26, 2020 2 Last Date February 3, 2020 (up to 05:00 PM) 3 Admit Card February 15-22, 2020 4 Exam Date February / March 2020

Minimum 18 Years Maximum 22 Years

SC/ST 27 Years OBC 25 Years

General 113 EWS 26 OBC 75 SC 33 ST 13 Total 260

NEW DELHI: Application registration process for the Coast Guard Navik (General Duty), Domestic Branch (DB) is closing today i.e., Monday, February 3, 2020.As per the official notification the application process was to close on February 2, 2020, but the date is extended by a day as the site was closed by the authorities for the maintenance. A message posted on the official website read: "SITE WILL BE DOWN ON 02 FEB 2020 FROM 2030 HRS TO 2345 HRS ON ACCOUNT OF MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY OF SERVER.THEREFORE, THE ONLINE FILLING OF APPLICATION FORM PERIOD IS EXTENDED FROM 0001 HRS TILL 0600 HRS OF 03 FEB 2020".Candidates, who wish to join the Indian Coast Guard Navik (General Duty), can apply for online through the official website - https://joinindiancoastguard.gov.in/.Candidates have to upload the photograph and signature in .jpeg format (image quality 200 dpi). The size of photograph and signature must be between 10 kb to 40 kb and 10 kb to 30 kb respectively.Age Relaxation (Upper Age Limit)Minimum 18 Years and maximum 22 years i.e. born between 01 Aug 1998 to 31 Jul 2002 (both dates inclusive). Upper age relaxation of 5 years for SC/ST and 3 years for OBC candidates.Candidates are to logon to www.joinindiancoastguard.gov.in and click on opportunities button.The important instructions for filling of online application are:-(1) The Name of the Candidate, Father and Mother's name and Date of Birth should be mentioned as per 10th class certificate.(2) Indicate exact percentage of 12th class up to two decimals and this is not to be rounded off.(3) Filling up of information like personal email ID and Mobile number of the candidate are compulsory. The date, time and Centre of the written examination and other information will be informed through Coast Guard Recruitment website www.joinindiancoastguard.gov.in(4) The application provides choice of only One Centre for examination. The candidate is to choose Centre from the list mentioned against each state to which he belongs to.

Title: Residents must fuel Hubballi's growth: Mohandas Pai
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Experts of industry highlighted the immense potential Hubballi had for growing into a metropolis in its own ri... Read More

HUBBALLI: Hubballi city has necessary potential to grow as a second metro city in Karnataka, but the onus is on locals to unitedly put pressure on elected representatives and officials to ensure the same, said Mohandas Pai , chairman of Aarin Capital and Manipal Global Education.

Sharing his views at 'Evening with Legends', organised as part of Development Dialogue-2020 here on Saturday evening, he said many entrepreneurs have been urging the government to develop Hubballi as another IT city in the state, but to no avail. "Even a group of IT entrepreneurs and enthusiasts was formed here, but it did not get local support. Locals should own up and help develop Hubballi," he said.

Endorsing the same, Ajai Chowdhry, founder of HCL, said many positive things are happening in Hubballi in recent years, thanks to the initiatives of Deshpande Foundation. "I would like to contribute to develop entrepreneurship here," he said.

Recalling the history of Vijaynagar (the erstwhile kingdom in Ballari), mentor Rajeev said it was the second-largest city in the country in the 15th century. "Hubballi, which is close to Vijaynagar, can be developed as the second city on the lines of Pune or Nagpur in Maharashtra," he said.

Former IPS officer Annamalai also spoke. Gururaj Deshpande, co-founder of Deshpande Foundation, moderated the session.

Title: Varun Dhawan’s marriage plans with Natasha Dalal on hold due to 'Street Dancer 3D' underperforming at the box office?
Content: Bollywood actor Varun Dhawan was recently seen in Remo D’Souza’s dance film ‘Street Dancer 3D’. The film also starred Shraddha Kapoor , Nora Fatehi and Prabhudheva in pivotal roles. Despite getting good reviews from the critics, the film has failed to earn moolah at the box office.According to a report in Mumbai Mirror, it is being said that Varun is ‘deeply disturbed’ by how Remo’s film has done at the box office. There were also reports that Varun has signed Remo’s next ‘Dancing Dad’ that Salman Khan was supposed to do.But now it is being said that he has refused to do the film. Apart from this, reports also suggest that he is planning to postpone his wedding with girlfriend Natasha Dalal . The duo was set to marry by the end of this year but now he plans to concentrate on his career first. His last films have not done great business at the box office and looks like this hasn’t gone well with the actor.Varun has a great line up of films ahead. He will be soon seen in David Dhawan ’s ‘Coolie No.1’ remake alongside Sara Ali Khan . Apart from this, he also has Karan Johar’s ‘Mr.Lele’ and Sriram Raghvan’s next.Well, only time will say if Varun is planning to postpone his wedding.

Title: Kolkata: Man beaten up over theft suspicion
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Repressentative image

KOLKATA: A middle-aged Group D staff of the TB hospital in Jadavpur was beaten up by a group of men on suspicion of being a thief in the early hours of Saturday. Police said Manoj Mallick, who lives in the staff quarters, was allegedly walking suspiciously around a bike parked in Santoshpur. When he fumbled on being grilled by the bike owner, a group of locals thrashed him.

When his wife and son came to his rescue, they were also allegedly assaulted. The man underwent treatment at Medical College and Hospital . "He was drunk and had allegedly moved suspiciously around the bike," said an officer. Police later arrested bike owner Subhra Dutta (28) and his friend Biswajit Midya (30).

Title: IRSDC to soon float Pune station re-development tenders
Content:
File photo of Pune railway station

PUNE: The Indian Railway Stations Development Corporation ( IRSDC ) is set to float tenders for the re-development of the city and Shivajinagar stations with an aim to start the actual work this year.AN IRSDC official said the aim of the initiative was to turn these stations into ‘Rail-O-polis’. These ‘re-devopment hubs’ will have establishments such as a commercial centre, mall or hotel nearby.The IRSDC had taken over the over the Pune railway station’s facility management barely a year ago.“The re-development of some select stations is being done by two agencies — IRSDC and the Rail Land Development Authority (RLDA). In its Union Budget on Saturday, the central government referred to the redevelopment of four stations under the public private partnership (PPP) model,” IRSDC managing director and chief executive officer S K Lohia said.“The RLDA is handling 44 stations and we are redeveloping 60 stations across the country. In some cases, we are jointly doing the work. We will soon float tenders for the re-development project of the Pune and the Shivajinagar stations under the PPP Model. The building of the Pune station is a heritage structure and we will not touch it,” he told TOI.The IRSDC had in December 2018 taken over the Pune station from the Railways for its facility management and appointed city-based BVG India for the work.“We also have to do the redevelopment of the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus and its building is also a heritage structure. The idea behind it is to get the railway land near these stations and develop them into proper commercial ‘Rail-o-polis’. We had some issues as far as Shivajinagar station is concerned. But all the issues have been resolved,” Lohia said.In December 2019, the IRSDC had invited bids for the re-development of Nagpur, Gwalior, Amravati and Sabarmati stations at an investment of around Rs1,300 crore. In October last year, Niti Ayog CEO Amitabh Kant had written to Railway Board, stressing the need to re-develop 50 stations on a priority basis .Sources said besides getting bidders, land availability was also problem at times for the redevelopment programme. “The project doesn’t include land acquisition, as plots belonging to the Railways will be used. But availability of railway land near the stations is a problem. Then there are issues of finding a bidder. So, floating tenders is just not enough. The authorities need to convince the bidders about the project viability,” a source in the Railways privy to the development said.

Title: Taxing remittances might prove onerous
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: Many fear it might prove onerous if the government started taxing remittances. In the Finance Bill , the government has proposed a 5% tax collection at source (TCS) for remittances over Rs 7 lakh under the Liberalised Remittance Scheme. This will block a big chunk of funds for those wishing to send money overseas.

The Finance Bill states, "banks who receive Rs 7 lakh from an individual for remittance out of India under the LRS or from a seller of a tour package shall debit a sum equal to five percent of the remitted amount as income tax."

Manipal Global Education chairman Mohandas Pai on Sunday raised the issue of taxing remittances. In a tweet to the FM, he asked, “5% tax collection at source for remittances over Rs 7 lakh. Sir this is very wrong; why is there a tax on our own tax paid money when we remit? Where is ease of living?”

TOI has reported that Indians on average send $1.5 billion (Rs 10,700 crore) abroad every month for various reasons like student fees, travel, gifts, and medical treatment. If taxed at 5%, the government will be able to raise about $75 million every month.

India is one of the top recipients of remittances but outward remittances are relatively low. The global average cost of sending was around 7% in 2019, according to the World Bank 's Remittance Prices Worldwide database.

"Now with the taxation, the amount one sends overseas will further get eaten into," said the chief technical officer of a remittances firm.

Shailesh Haribhakti, founder and chief mentor of auditing firm Baker Tilly DHC, said in an era of falling interest rates and falling growth it is very difficult to extract significant returns on investments out of LRS. "This 5% deduction would need a review in the light of returns actually being generated from LRS remittances. Simple analytics of the reported incomes will reveal the need quite clearly," he said.

K R Sekar, partner in Deloitte, said, "It's an added cost. If I have to send my son for education in the US, why should I pay 5% tax to the government? It's a ridiculous move to tax these items on the premise that this is a luxury item, which is not the case."

Title: Hubballi: Project took 7 long years to materialise
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

HUBBALLI: The Hubballi-Dharwad Bus Rapid Transport Service ( HD-BRTS ) Company Ltd is a government project involving 13 agencies - five funding and monitoring agencies, two implementing agencies, one each for monitoring, operational, design consultancy, Project Management Consultant (PMC) for civil works, PMC for ITS works and a stakeholder - to build the dedicated bus corridor along 22.25km between Hubballi and Dharwad.

Though both BJP and Congress claim credit for the implementation of the project, people had been holding Union minister Pralhad Joshi and district minister Jagadish Shettar responsible for the delay of over seven years. When HDBRTS Company, a state government undertaking, was registered under the Companies Act on May 7, 2012, it was said that buses will ply in two years. Though the estimated cost in the beginning was Rs 692 crore, it ended up at Rs 970.33 crore. With the assurance of safe, affordable and world-class bus rapid transit infrastructure and services, HD-BRTS work started in 2012. Land acquisition was the first hurdle for the ambitious project. However, elected representatives and officials cleared the hurdle amidst allegations of partiality in acquiring the land and the related pricing. Though promoting the participation of citizens in the planning process was one of the objectives, people were kept out.

BRTS, which claims itself being environment-friendly, did not keep its word on planting saplings along the corridor. Another major miss is the use of Compressed Natural Gas (CNG). But BRTS escaped from this responsibility by saying the buses were ordered in 2012-13. It has adopted Euro-IV engine buses, which are already outdated in developed countries.

Title: Mahindra Electric to start EV powertrain exports this year
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

BENGALURU: Mahindra Electric will supply electric vehicle (EV) powertrains to South Korea and European markets from this year, its chief executive Mahesh Babu said.

The company has already partnered with SsangYong Motors in Korea. “We are looking for partners in Europe,” Babu added. The powertrains are being manufactured in the Bengaluru and Chakan plants. A powertrain comprises the main components that work together to generate the necessary power to propel the vehicle. Babu added that the company’s proposed R&D centre, which will be set up on a 14-acre land parcel near the Bengaluru airport, is expected to be operational towards the end of next year.

Mahindra is investing Rs 400 crore in setting up the unit which will have a design centre and testing laboratories for three critical parts of an electric vehicle, namely, the battery packs, power electronics, and motor assembly. These are integral parts of an electric powertrain.

Title: Big Temple consecration: Special trains to run from February 4
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

THANJAVUR: Anticipating huge rush during the consecration of Brihadeeswarar Temple on February 5, Trichy Railway Division will operate four special passenger trains to Thanjavur for three days from February 4.

The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) will operate several special buses to the city from all districts February 3 onwards. Chief secretary of the state and state-level officials have inspected the arrangements at the temple.

Four passenger trains will be operated for three days to facilitate the devotees.

The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation, Kumbakonam division is operating special buses to Thanjavur to clear the extra rush from several districts across the state including Chennai, Coimbatore, Madurai, Kancheepuram, Thiruvannamalai, Thirunelveli, Nagercoil, Sivagangai, Ariyalur, Peramblalur and Karur from February 3. A total of 1,426 services will be operated via 10 routes in the city and 1,649 services by mofussil buses in seven routes every day, managing director of TNSTC R Ponmudi said.

Earlier on Saturday evening, chief secretary of the state K Shanmugam visited the Big Temple and inspected the arrangements made by the district administration and the police to help devotees to witness the consecration ceremony without any difficulties.

Meanwhile, the Trichy Corporation has deputed 160 sanitary workers and officials to assist in the sanitation and hygiene management activities during the festival. "We have hired three transport corporation buses to send the 160 employees. Five sanitary supervisors and a sanitary inspector were also sent on special duty," an official with Trichy Corporation said. The sanitation workers who left the city on Saturday will stay at Thanjavur till February 10, to take part in sanitation works at the temple.

Title: Pune: From the Wood-works, modded motorcycles & unique bicycles
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Albert Wood with the customised Thunderbird, one of his earlier projects.

The motorcycles rolling off the factory production line, though well-structured, are plain vanilla machines for some in terms of look and feel. Spanking yet staid; engineering paragons yet underwhelming and boring; fuel efficient… yawn!! These days, guys in their leathers don’t often go hammering down the road noisily to grab attention but they sure want their beasts to be head-turning, visual distractions.

That’s where the likes of Albert Wood come in, jazzing up motorbikes with engine modifications and exterior embellishments — all while sticking to the legal scheme of things. He also manufactures unique bicycles , but more on that later.

Operating from his workshop in the Pune cantonment, the 30-year-old Wood interestingly says he never had a passion for motorcycles and has no engineering or mechanical background either. A career in soccer would have been an option for him earlier, having played for Pune and Maharashtra as a student, but his legs ran weary long before the Indian super league emerged to snap up promising players.

Wood, however, had entrepreneurial dreams, which he cherished even during his long stint in the field of marketing. He started his new venture 18 months ago, restoring and customising two of his own motorcycles — an Avenger and a TVS Victor. Both found ready buyers, firing his interest to build motorcycles right from the ground up. Today, he has already customised around 25 bikes, with heavy-duty modifications having turned some of them into café racers and cruisers.

Wood operates singlehandedly. An ongoing project on a 2007 Pulsar will see him cutting the frame, changing the tank and handle, and fitting improved shock absorbers, broader tyres, a Harley mask in front and a rather selfish no-pillion seat. An earlier customisation on a Thunderbird was for a tall, muscular guy with a love for long rides. Wood first lowered the seat and extended the backrest for comfort before customising the tank, speedometer and lamps.

Wood has invested Rs 2.5 lakh in machinery and taught himself designing, cutting, grinding, welding, buffing and pipe bending. The markup on the modded bike is low; there’s no competition in the market for his reasonable selling price, he says.

While working in a resort in Goa, Wood first saw a tandem bicycle (to be ridden by two people) standing among mini-carts lugging vacationers submitting to torpidity while on holiday. He’s manufactured his own tandems since and is eyeing a market for them in the 2,000-odd resorts across the country. Apart from tandems, he makes cruising, women’s and advertising bicycles in offbeat sizes. The cycles are tubeless and gearless, and are designed for commute, not speed.

The innovator has a soft corner for the small-time motorcycle mechanics with unsung customisation skills. He was fortunate to have money to put into his business but knows banks won’t lend easily to other bikebuilders. He plans to hold an annual bazaar where these mechanics can showcase their customisation works.

Wood refuses to rate any of his several motorcycle projects as the best, saying each one has been unique. But he derives maximum satisfaction when the modded bike speeds out of his workshop and the owner pulls up along the way to scream his gratitude over the phone.

Title: Congress gives adjournment notice in Lok Sabha over CAA
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The Parliament House (ANI)

NEW DELHI: Leader of Congress in lower House Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury , chief whip Kodikunnil Suresh and party MP Gaurav Gogoi have given adjournment motion notice in Lok Sabha on the "issue of reconsideration of CAA after unrest in the Country and to stop NPR Process and NRC".

President Ram Nath Kovind's address to the joint sitting of Parliament on Friday was briefly interrupted by the Opposition members when he began speaking about the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

The CAA fast-tracks the process of granting citizenship to Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christians who fled religious persecution in Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan and took refuge in India on or before December 31, 2014.

Members of the Opposition have deemed it "discriminatory and anti-Constitution" while the Centre has maintained that the new law has no effect on Indian citizens.

Title: Mumbai: 16 arrested for horse-cart racing, betting
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A horse-cart race racket was busted in Vasai on Saturday, and 16 men were arrested, by the local crime branch in Palghar. The police seized 14 horses, seven carts, a truck and cash, collectively worth Rs 22 lakh.

Acting on a tip off, the police raided a ground behind a hotel on the Mumbai-Ahmedabad national highway at Vasai. People from Mumbai, Thane, and Palghar districts were there, and had placed bets on the races.

A total of 16 men, including organisers and participants, who were booked, also have cases of gambling registered against them in several other police stations. The rescued horses were sheltered at an animal farm in Sakwar, Virar. The police are ascertaining the details about the horses’ owners. They suspect that the horses were given to the organisers of the races on rent. The Vasai races are believed to have taken place at least two times previously, before they were busted on Saturday.

Title: Seat children on basis of roll numbers, Himachal Pradesh schools told
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The Himachal Pradesh education department has directed the schools to ensure that children are made to sit acc... Read More

SHIMLA: To put an end to the practice of caste-based discrimination during the serving of midday meals in government schools, the Himachal Pradesh education department has directed the schools to ensure that children are made to sit according to their roll numbers. This is not the first time that such an order has been issued.

In a circular issued to the deputy directors of high education on January 31, director (education) Amarjeet Kumar Sharma said that despite several instructions issued earlier, incidents of discrimination against dalit students while serving of midday meals are still being reported.

"It is, therefore, once again forcefully reiterated that such type of discrimination should be completely stopped," he said.

Directing the schools to ensure that students are made to sit according to their roll numbers at meal time, he asserted that this programme should be used as a vehicle for inculcation of good habits, discipline and spirit of equality among children. The circular refers to the midday meal scheme guidelines which stipulate that community members, teachers and department officials must ensure that children eat the midday meal together and sit according to their roll numbers without any discrimination.

The department has even warned of strict action against those indulging in such acts and directed the deputy directors to issue instructions to all schools regarding discrimination on the basis of religion, caste and creed and also sensitise parents and public in this regard.

Title: Students claim inconsistencies in University of Hyderabad’s selection of research scholars
Content:
University of Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Students of the University of Hyderabad (UoH) have pointed out discrepancies in the selection process of research scholars in the admissions which were conducted in January 2020, and claimed that the varsity failed to fill reserved category seats despite the availability of eligible candidates.Members of the Ambedkar Students Association (ASA), who obtained the interview mark-sheets of several candidates through RTI, alleged that several students were denied a seat with a remark saying that their performance was ‘not satisfactory’.“While about 25 students appeared for the interview for a PhD seat in the education department, the panel gave marks to just seven students. For all the remaining candidates, ‘not satisfactory’ was written in the marks column,” said Gopi Swamy , convener, ASA adding that even the candidate who topped the written examination was not awarded any marks in the interview.He said that as per the UGC guidelines, interviewers have to mandatorily award marks. “Inspite of having a vacancy in the reserved category, two students belonging to the Muslim community were not given admission in the education department,” he added.“While the PhD seats under the general category were filled, reserved seats under OBC and SC category for Material Engineering were left vacant during the admissions. The Department of English has also not filled the Scheduled Tribe (ST) category and left the seats vacant. In the Department of Psychology, two SC seats have been left vacant,” said M Iniyavan, president, ASA adding that UGC mandates that a special admission drive must be conducted to fill the vacant seats from the reserved category.The official spokesperson of UoH, Vinod Pavarala said that when a similar issue was raised during July, they asked the departments to reconsider admission recommendations. “Subsequently, few students were given admissions and remaining vacant seats were advertised in January. Now that the students have raised the issue again, the issue will be examined afresh by the varsity,” said Pavarala, who was also the chair of the Admission Grievance Committee, which looked into the issue in July last year.

Title: Mysuru temperature: It's February, but feels like April in Mysuru & Kodagu
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Saturday's was the second highest temperature for February in Kodagu in the past 10 years

MYSURU: The sudden rise in the mercury levels has created a summer-like feeling in Myuru and Kodagu . The maximum temperature in these two districts have been more than 4 degrees celsius above normal.

On Saturday, temperature touched 34.5 degrees Celsius in Mysuru and 31.9 degrees Celsius in Kodagu. The average temperature for February is 31.1 degrees celsius in Mysuru and 28.2 degrees celsius in Kodagu.

Saturday's was the second highest temperature for February in Kodagu in the past 10 years, according to the Karnataka State Natural Disaster Monitoring Centre (KSNDMC) data. The all-time record for February registered in Kodagu is 32.1 degrees Celsius in 2005 and 2016.

The temperature is expected to rise further with the IMD predicting clear sky over Mysuru and Kodagu in the next one week. Experts observe that South Interior Karnataka will witness frequent heatwaves this summer. KSNDMC director G Srinivasa Reddy attributed the rising temperature to the increased sea surface temperature in the Arabian Sea and Bay of Bengal. "The winter has vanished. It is the starting point of summer. So naturally, there is an increase in temperature. Temperature increase has become a global phenomenon," he said.

However, variations in temperature are causing rain in many places. "Rainfall is expected in the Malnad region due to soaring temperature," said Reddy.

Title: Pune: Illegal farmers’ markets that clog roads set to face action
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

PUNE: Farmers , vegetable traders , and weekly markets that encroach upon the streets in the city and operate without permission in civic properties and amenity spaces will face action. The Pune Municipal Corporation has given all such operators one week to stop encroaching.The civic administration has issued a public notice stating that the Maharashtra State Agriculture Marketing Board has not given permission to any of these illegal markets to operate.Weekly markets are held on different days of the week across the city.Some vendors are setting up the markets in the mornings and evenings, blocking access to footpaths and public spaces. Local residents have complained about some of these markets which also block traffic prompting the civic administration to decide upon a plan of action against them."The PMC has planned such markets. Some permissions are needed for their operation. Till such time, action will be taken against vendors of markets who clog roads and cause traffic jams," Madhav Jagtap, head of PMC antiencroachment department, told TOI.The notice added that the civic administration will not be responsible for any loss caused to the traders due to their action. The operators will have to shoulder the responsibility for it, Jagtap added.The state government in 2016-17 decided to start weekly farmers’ markets to promote farm produce and provide a platform to the farmers. It had directed local self-governing bodies to provide land to farmers. The intention was also to help citizens get vegetables at cheaper rates.The Maharashtra State Agriculture Marketing Board (MSAMB) was told to grant and promote farmers’ markets. But many political leaders have grabbed the opportunity and started weekly bazaars in their wards. Many operate without completing the proper process for such markets.The PMC had found that some groups and companies are purchasing vegetables from wholesale markets and involving local traders to sell the produce under the banner of the farmers’ markets. thus violating the government policy.Farmers’ markets are huge hits. The showers last monsoon had affected vegetable supplies in the city, but the operators of weekly farmers’ markets managed to tide over the crisis by streamlining supply.The operators, who run over 66 markets in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad, had said they leveraged their wide network of farmers — about 4,500 from 70 villages in Pune, Ahmednagar and Satara districts — and ensured there was a steady, if declined, supply of fresh vegetables .

Title: Malappuram: Long march against CAA to begin today
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representational Image

MALAPPURAM: A long march demanding repeal of Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) being organized by district Congress committee will begin on Monday. The 10-day-long march will begin at Vazhikkadavu in the evening and conclude at Ponnani on February 13.

Kerala Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) president Mullappally Ramachandran will inaugurate the march at Vazhikkadavu at 4pm. Senior leaders of the party, Aryadan Muhammed, MLA A P Anilkumar, KPCC general secretary V A Karim, P T Ajaymohan, KPA Majeed also will attend the inaugural function.

KPCC vice-president P C Vishnu Nath will inaugurate the march from Edakkara on the second day and it will conclude at Nilambur. KPCC vicepresident C P Muhammed will inaugurate the march from Nilambur on the third day. The march on fourth day will begin from Edavanna and conclude at Manjeri. On the fifth day, former KPCC president V M Sudheeran will inaugurate the march, which will begin its tour from Malappuram town.

On February 11, former chief minister Oommen Chandy will inaugurate the march from Kottakkal. UDF convener Benny Behanan will inaugurate the march on February 12.

The march will concluded at Chamravattom Junction in Ponnani on February 13. All India Congress Committee general secretary K C Venugopal will inaugurate function. Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala, K Muraleedharan, Aryadan Muhammed, MLA A P Anilkumar and others will attend it.

Title: Plastic ban: Aurangabad civic chief leads the way
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Aurangabad municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey

Title: KEAM 2020 online registration begins, check how to apply
Content: The online registration process for the KEAM 2020 (Kerala Engineering, Agriculture, and Medical courses) entrance examination started on February 01, 2020. The students who wish to get admission to Professional Degree Courses in Engineering, Agriculture and Medical stream are advised to visit the official website - cee.kerala.gov.in - to register and submit online application form for the same. The last date to apply for the KEAM 2020 exam is February 25, 2020, and the last date of certificates uploading (except nativity and date of birth proof) is February 29, 2020.Here's step-by-step guide on how to apply for the KEAM 2020 exam:Open official website - cee.kerala.gov.in - and enter your own or parent's Email ID and Mobile Number to register.After registration, fill up Basic Details, Communication Details, Academic Details, Reservation Details, Annual Family Income in the online form.Pay the Application Fee online or by Paying Cash using e-Challan at selected Head and Sub Post Offices.Upload Candidate's Photograph and Signature adhering to the specification. Upload PDF format of Date of Birth proof and Nativity proof. Other supporting documents for Communal Reservation, Special Reservation and Annual family income may be uploaded before the stipulated time. Original of all Uploaded Certificates should be preserved and produced as and when demanded.After completing the online submission, take a printout of confirmation page for future reference.Engineering rank is prepared by giving equal weightage of 50:50 to the score obtained in the Entrance Examination conducted by CEE for Engineering and the marks obtained in the final year of the qualifying examination for Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry put together, after effecting the standardization procedure as described in the exam brochure.B.Pharm Rank list will be prepared on the basis of Index mark calculated from the score obtained in Paper-1 (Physics & Chemistry) of the Engineering Entrance Examination.Admission to MBBS, BDS, BAMS, BSMS, BHMS, BUMS, Agricultural, Forestry, Fisheries and Veterinary courses will be based on NEET-UG 2020.The Architecture Rank list will be prepared by the Commissioner for Entrance Examinations by giving equal weightage to the marks obtained in the National Aptitude Test in Architecture (NATA), conducted by the Council of Architecture, and the marks in the qualifying examination.

Title: 'We should offer accident insurance for polo players'
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

JAIPUR: Marketing. It's a two-way street that requires sincere interest in the sponsor's objectives and how it can help them achieve goals. In today's sports world, all major events are advertised and promoted on multiple platforms to ensure viewers for the events.

Secure in the belief that it can also help polo in Rajasthan make a turnaround, Kaushal Doda, director of Sphiro Infratech Pvt Limited is mulling to set up a polo institute in Jaipur and involve sponsors in a big way. With the help of famous rider like Dhruvpal Godara, they will approach the state government, seeking a land for the purpose.

"But the project will never be shelved if we don't get the government help or not," Doda said. He believes the training institute will help educate and nurture talents.

"There would be a proper infrastructure and we can save a lot of money. Our first priority is to offer personal accident insurance for players in case of accident or injury. Today, the majority are either inadequately insured, or are not insured at all. I feel we should look into the matter seriously."

Happy to see that opportunities are more widespread, and polo is being seen as a sport, he stressed on the fact that instead of inviting polo riders from Delhi or other places, Rajasthan should have a right infrastructure to groom the young talents.

"In that way, we can open avenues for others, who are directly or indirectly involved with the trade, like trainers, animal doctors, and those who can look after the stables. It can also create job opportunities. It's not an utopian idea and I mean it," he stated.

Handicap +5player, Dhruvpal has been playing the sport for the past 25 years and has set a standard among the few non-army personnel to have achieved great heights in a sport often associated with the armed forces. Naturally, he believes it's the right time to take the step forward.

"It makes me sad when I find polo doesn't attract the attention of spectators not much as it did before. People know Angad Kalan, Samsher Singh, Basir Ali, Padmanabh Singh . But how? Because the spectators love and admire them. And it's no exaggeration if I say the fans may be sometime tempted to give it a try."

Reminiscing the day when the Rambagh Polo Club was chock-o-block with spectators, hooting for the local side during a match sometime back, Dhruvpal said that he escaped by the skin of teeth as the surging crowd invaded the field like a swarm of bees. It was scary but thrilling too."

Asked how optimistic he is to expect a similar situation in future, he said, 'Whatever will be, will be.

"It's like Doris Day's famous song Que Sera Sera," he said with eyes shining.

Title: 32-year-old man stabbed due to enmity in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 32-year-old man was stabbed to death by a group of individuals in Kamatipura in the early hours of Sunday.

The accused persons, suspected to be known to the victim, fled from the spot. The deceased was identified as Syed Imran, a resident of Moinpura who was a scrap businessman.

According to police, the incident took place in Moinpura at 2.30 am. “The victim was allegedly stabbed by two to three persons, suspected to be known to him and from the same locality. The accused persons are suspected to have previous enmity with the victim,” said Kamatipura inspector, G Rambabu.

The accused persons are absconding and the police are checking the CCTV footage. “We suspect the accused called the victim at the spot on the pretext of settling a issue before stabbing him,” added the officer.

The victim sustained multiple stab injuries on his neck and chest. The victim was rushed to Osmania General Hospital and was declared brought dead. “We are checking the CCTV cameras but there are no signs of any person at the spot,” said the inspector. Police have registered a case under Sec-302 (murder) of IPC and relevant sections of Arms Act.

Title: Mysuru zoo to set up quarantine facility at Koorgalli for rescued wild animals
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Foresters transport injured, deserted, orphaned and rescued animals to Mysuru Zoo, from as far as 100km or mor... Read More

MYSURU: With Mysuru zoo becoming the one stop for treatment of wild animals rescued from tiger reserves, sanctuaries and fringe villages near and far, an advance quarantine facility is being set up in Koorgalli to ensure effective treatment of the patients and to prevent infection of the captive animals at the zoo.

Over the last two years alone, the zoo has treated tigers, leopards, a slender loris and a muntjac (barking deer) from the wild. It also received a pair of foxes from the Raipur zoo in Chhattisgarh. One of the tigers received last year was captured after it mauled two farmers near Bandipur tiger reserve; another was a two-year-old caught in a snare in Nagarahole.

Zoo authorities said the quarantine facility and a postmortem centre would be established at the Chamundi Rescue and Rehabilitation Centre in Koorgalli. At present the foresters transport injured, deserted, orphaned and rescued animals to Mysuru Zoo, from as far as 100km or more. The animals are brought from Bandipur TR, Nagarahole TR, Cauvery Wildlife Sanctuary, Ranganathittu Bird Sanctuary, Brahmagiri, Pushpagiri, Talacauvery and Biligiri Ranganatha wildlife sanctuary, besides the fringe villages around these parks.

Veterinarians said the wild animals are accommodated in the inpatient wards in the zoo hospital as there is no separate shelter on the premises. Besides being an inconvenience, this brings with it the risk of transmission of diseases between the captive animals and the wild. "We receive rescued elephant calves, gaur calves, leopard cubs, injured spotted deer, sambar, muntjac, bonnet macaques, bear cubs, tigers, leopards, jackals, freshwater muggers, snakes, starred tortoise, terrapins and many species of terrestrial and aquatic birds. They are treated and shifted to the Koorgalli centre," said a zoo official. "But without an operation theatre and quarantine facility, it had become very difficult to conduct tests and monitor these rescued animals."

Executive director of the zoo Ajit M Kulkarni said increased man-animal conflict was leading to an influx of captured and rescued animals. "We did not have a proper postmortem facility at the centre and carcasses were brought to Mysuru zoo. As there is a clear risk of infection spreading to other animals, a scientific postmortem centre will be set up. The rescued animals will be treated and kept at the quarantine facility for observation after which they will be housed with the stock," he said. Adequate staff and veterinarians have been deputed for the new units in Koorgalli, he added.

Title: All the President's men keep tradition alive
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: Mornings were especially tough on Vimla in the cold wave that gripped Delhi this December. But by 7am every day, the 50-year-old would be at work, removing weeds around 'sherbet' roses of Mughal Gardens at Rashtrapati Bhavan . "It was a difficult winter," she said, but she had to make sure the flowers endured.

Every February, just as the biting cold begins to yield, the Mughal Gardens open to the public as part of 'Udyanotsav'. Putting it together this year, the garden staff said, was the most difficult it has ever been. The day before 2019 ended was Delhi's coldest in 119 years. For weeks around that time, the weather was the city's only relevant subject of conversation. "But we had to prepare. Opening of the gardens is an unbroken tradition. We covered the stalks with plastic and placed nets on the shrubs to prevent frost," said Ramesh Sharma, a 53-year-old senior gardener on the grounds.

The 42 garden staff members of the presidential residence did keep the tradition alive. The gardens open on February 5. The numbers are big - 15 acres, 138 varieties of roses, 5,000 dahlias, 10,000 tulips. The names are quirky - 'Mother Teresa' is a chrysanthemum and 'Red Pinocchio' is a rose, as is 'Delhi Princess'. A pale yellow-orange rose is 'President Pranab'. The American connect is strong and many rose shrubs are named after holidays - 'Memorial Day', 'Fourth of July' - or states like 'Oklahoma', 'Pasadena', 'Louisiana'. "But that's just the rose federation," said PN Joshi, superintendent of the President's gardens, referring to the World Federation of Rose Societies .

Names have often sparked strange controversies. In 2014, a rose named 'Sonia' stirred a hornet's nest. That it was named not after the Congress politician but a rose cultivator from France didn't seem to matter much. The perceived symbolism did. A rose by any other name would, perhaps, have placated those who were incensed. Then, last December, a fringe outfit wanted the entire garden to be renamed. The demand was oblivious to history - that the charbagh Mughal gardens of Kashmir and the pleasure gardens of Europe had inspired Edward Lutyens, who designed this one over seven years.

"When (APJ Abdul) Kalam ji was President, he said he wanted a spiritual garden. Plants and trees significant to each religion - tulsi, henna, dates - were grown together in the garden as a symbol of unity. It's important to see the world like that," Joshi said.

Rashtrapati Bhavan had seven occupants in the 33 years Joshi has been around, tending to the gardens. Each President has brought something new - under Shankar Dayal Sharma , the garden went organic; KR Narayanan introduced a rainwater catchment system and Kalam brought in a herb garden with indigenous plants.

Earlier, the first Indian resident of the Rashtrapati Bhavan and the first governor general of independent India, C Rajagopalachari, had subverted the opulence of the gardens at a time when the country was facing a food crisis and sectioned off an area for wheat cultivation. "The practice continued till 1962, under our first President Rajendra Prasad . There's a lot to the history of this place," said Kumar Samresh, public relations officer of the President's secretariat.

Title: Arjun Kapoor shares an emotional note on his mother Mona Kapoor’s birth anniversary, says ‘wish we had more time’
Content: Bollywood actor Arjun Kapoor is a proud mama’s boy and all his social media posts are proof of it. Every now and then, he keeps on sharing his mother Mona Kapoor ’s unseen picture on social media.His mother breathed her last on March 25, 2012 just before his Bollywood debut. Today on her 56birthday, Arjun has posted an emotional note on Instagram. He also went on to write that he misses her every single day.Sharing a picture with his mom, Arjun wrote, “Happy birthday Mom Love You. I hope ur smiling right now whenever you are... this picture was the last birthday we had together & I just assumed we would have many more... it’s selfish to say I miss you all the time but I really do ya... I try & be strong cause that’s the way society expected me to be at the age of 25 when I lost you forever... they all expect u to figure it all out with ur life taken away from you I was supposed to sorted & what not... but I’m not strong enough on most days... I just ride it out... anyway as usual I sit and complain & trouble u with my non sense... happy birthday Mom wish we had more time together.... PS - @anshulakapoor s started @fankindofficial & she’s kicking ass just like you did....”Both Arjun and Anshula often share their childhood pictures with their mother with an emotional caption. They lost their mother due to multiple organ failure after a long battle with cancer.

Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020
