#astrology #horoscope #dailyhoroscope #horoscopetoday #horoscopefebruary #februaryhoroscope

Title: Mumbai: Film City tender slashes developer’s fee to be paid to government from Rs 128 crore to Rs 20 crore
Content:
The Film City redevelopment project will operate on a Design, Build, Finance, Operate and Transfer (DBFOT) bas... Read More

The latest tender for the Film City redevelopment project has drastically slashed the fee to be paid to the government by private entities to convert the prime land into a filmmaking and tourism hub like Universal Studios. The tender asks private parties to pay an initial annual fee of just Rs 20 crore besides revenue share for the right to develop 211 acres over a 40-year period, TOI found. The first tender, which failed to attract bids, had pegged the annual fee at 128.5 crore, to escalate each year. The new fee is over six times lower.In real terms, the successful bidder will control around 400 acres of the state-owned Film City’s land in Goregaon , of which only 211 acres will be buildable, officials say. Portions of the rest can be given over to activities like film shoots. Both tenders were introduced when the BJP-led government was in power in the state during 2014-19. The first tender was floated in July 2018. The second was introduced in August 2019. The last day for receiving bids is February 7.The project will operate on a Design, Build, Finance, Operate and Transfer (DBFOT) basis. During the 40-year license period, the private entity will have control over the project and pay the state an annual “concession fee” and a share of the revenue generated from the project. The license period can be extended by another ten years.The first tender listed an initial fee of Rs 128.5 crore to be paid to the state and to escalate by 5% each year to reach Rs 1,147 crore in the 40th year. If extended by another 10 years, the fee would be Rs 1,868 crore in the 50th year.In the latest tender, a potential developer is expected to pay the state just Rs 20 crore for the first year. The rest of the fee for the 40-year span will be linked to a price index which has not been revealed in the tender.The Rs 2,550 crore project has two components. The mandatory portion includes the creation of filmmaking infrastructure, including sound stages and special effects studios, a Bollywood theme park and museum, hotels and a convention centre. The project also has a commercial component, which allows the developer flexibility to build retail shops, a commercial hub, club and stadium. The value of this has not been estimated.After the discount on the concession fee, there are voices of concern within the government about whether the state is giving prime land to the developer for a pittance. Especially since the project will also remain within the control of the private entity for 40 years.However, officials say the concession fee was reduced after potential bidders felt it was too high. “The idea was to reduce the concession fee in order to avail of a higher revenuesharing agreement,” said a senior official from Maharashtra Film, Stage and Cultural Development Corporation, which manages Film City.Officials say the old fee was linked to the land’s lease rent after taking the ready reckoner into account. However, the new fee is linked to the revenue currently being earned from the property. “The profit being earned by Film City comes to around Rs 17 crore annually. So, the concession fee was fixed for Rs 20 crore for the base year,” the official said.The second tender appears to have increased the amount of land that can be accessed by the private player. The first tender says the project will be limited to 211 acres of buildable land. However, the second tender says the development of Film City will be spread over the 211 acres buildable area or on any other potion of its land once approved by the government, except for the reserved forest area.Officials clarified that the private player will control around 400 acres, of which only 211acres will be buildable. “The land around the buildable area is contiguous, so, it will be in the control of the party that wins the bid. As no development can take place there, it can only be given for activities like film shoots,” said a senior official. Since the government will receive a revenue share, the private entity will not pay extra fee for renting out nonbuildable land, the official said.

Title: Women's college in Aurangabad declared 'mobile free zone'
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Dr Rafiq Zakiriya Women's College in Aurangabad has made its campus 'mobile free zone'. (Photo: ANI)

AURANAGABAD: Students of Dr Rafiq Zakiriya Women's College in Aurangabad have welcomed the ' mobile free zone ' initiative.

The principal of the college, Dr Maqdoom Farooqui said that students are happy as their concentration levels have increased.

"Girls are happy as their concentration levels have increased. Their interaction with each other has increased as well. This was done with the consent of parents, students and teachers," he told ANI.

The vice-principal of the college said, "If they need to make a phone call, they can use a cellphone in the reading room for which they need to write their name, roll number, mobile number and the name of the person they are calling in the register."

She also said that the students could access the internet in the computer room and reading room.

Welcoming the move, Taiyaba, a student said: "We respect the principal's decision to make the campus a 'mobile free zone'. Initially, we had problems but later realised it is a good initiative. We are spending more time on our studies and talking more with our friends now," she said.

"Students waste time on phones. With this initiative, we are concentrating more on our studies." Fatima said.

Title: jamia Millia Islamia: Cops haven't found any bullet shells
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

A case has been registered and an investigation is underway in the firing incident which was reported near gat... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has not found any bullet shells from the site near Jamia Millia Islamia University where the firing was reported on Sunday late night.

A case has been registered and an investigation is under way in the firing incident which was reported near gate no. 5 at the university.

Earlier, ACP Jagdish Yadav said, "Statements have been recorded. On their basis, FIR has been registered under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) Section 307/34 and Section 27 of the Arms Act."

He said that a team will go to the spot and collect the CCTV footage from gate no. 5 and 7.

"Further details which will come out will be included in the FIR. Action will be taken," the ACP said.

A statement was made by an eyewitness in the FIR saying, "On Sunday, at around 11.30pm, at gate number seven, two people in a two-wheeler were approaching towards the Jamia University. The person on the pillion seat stood up and shot a bullet. They later escaped towards Holy Family Hospital."

Title: Punjab allows traders to tie up with small general stores to sell foreign liquor
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

CHANDIGARH: To increase the availability of imported liquor in the state, the Punjab government has allowed liquor traders to tie up with small general stores to sell foreign liquor, the licence (L2B) for which was earlier given only to departmental stores.

The provision for granting L2B licence - retail sale of imported foreign liquor - has been relaxed in the new excise policy which will come into force from April 1. Under the new norms, an L2 licencee - wholesale and retail vendor of foreign liquor - has been allowed to get a licence to sell foreign liquor at any general store after entering into an agreement with such a store.

The minimum covered area of the store should be 400 square feet and it should be dealing in any four items, including grocery items, frozen goods, sugar and bakery items, toiletries, cosmetics, household goods, toys, sports goods, electronics, apparels, office stationery, gift items and any other household goods.

The condition of minimum guaranteed quota for this licence has also been done away with. In the present policy, 2,700 proof litres (PL) is the minimum quota of imported foreign liquor which the licence holders are required to lift compulsorily. In case quota is not lifted, licencees are required to pay Rs 330 per PL as assessed fee.

The annual licence fee has also been brought down from Rs 20 lakh to Rs 10 lakh. For operating this licence, the licencee will have to utilise up to 25% of covered area of the store for display of liquor which will be supplied from L2 licence with approval of collector. The annual good and services tax (GST) turnover/supply of the store of the last year should be minimum of Rs 1 crore, which is same as in current policy.

The L1 (imported liquor) licence fee has also been cut from Rs 15 lakh to Rs 10 lakh. Taking a dig at the state government, leader of the opposition Harpal Singh Cheema said on one hand the government was running Tandrust Mission Punjab to keep people of the state, especially youth, healthy, but on the other hand it was allowing sale of liquor at general stores. "The move will give youngsters easy access to alcohol. The government should remove the clause," said Cheema.

Title: Bengaluru businessman acquitted in contraband case
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A city businessman who was arrested after his firm was allegedly found exporting 30kg of methaqualone, a sedative-hypnotic drug whose effect is like barbiturates, was acquitted after a special court gave him the benefit of doubt.

The prosecution failed to prove his guilt beyond reasonable doubt, the court said. The seized drugs are said to be worth Rs 12 crore.

Special judge GM Sheenappa cited lack of corroborated evidence and discrepancies in the prosecution witnesses while acquitting Arun V, proprietor of Integrated Corporation, Prakash Nagar, Bengaluru.

The prosecution's case was that, on October 13, 2016, officers on duty at the Air India SATS export shed found off-white powder in plastic tubes in non-woven shopping bags which were to be exported by Integrated Corporation.

On testing, the powder turned out to be positive for methaqualone, a controlled substance under the NDPS Act, 1985.

Arun, was arrested the next day. He spent more than six months in jail and got bail on May 9, 2017.

Title: Subarban Rail Project: Will suburban rail reach Bengaluru airport ahead of Namma Metro?
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Kempegowda International Airport

BENGALURU: In a huge boost to air passengers, priority corridor of the Bengaluru suburban rail project to the Kempegowda International Airport ( KIA ) is likely to be operational by August 2022, according to Karnataka Rail Infrastructure Development Enterprises’ ( K-RIDE ) current plan.

On Sunday, the SPV which is executing the suburban rail project unveiled the 148km suburban rail project with four corridors: KSR Bengaluru City -Devanahalli, Byappanahalli-Chikkabanavara, Kengeri-Cantonment-Whitefield and Heelalige-Rajanukunte.

While finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the project at a cost of Rs 18,600 crore in the budget on Saturday, it is yet to receive a nod from the Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs (CCEA).

In 2019 alone, KIA saw 33.65 million passengers. According to K-RIDE, the KSR Bengaluru City-Yelahanka- KIA- Devanahalli (41.4km) line is likely to be operational by August 15, 2022. K-RIDE said work will be taken up on priority and the line will have 14 stations. It will be built at an estimated cost of Rs 5,127 crore and will provide direct connectivity to the terminal.

In contrast, the Rs 10,584 crore Silk Board-KR Puram (ORR)-KIA Metro corridor project which is yet to be approved by the Centre, is scheduled to open only in 2024. BMRCL in December invited tenders for the ORR line, while tenders for KR Puram-KIA section are likely to be floated by this month end. Going by the pace of work, Metro’s deadline may further get delayed, however, officials maintains that majority of the land acquisitions have been completed and have also commenced soil testing along the corridor.

Moreover, suburban rail could provide cheaper and quicker connectivity to KIA than the Metro since airport passengers from the central business district and south Bengaluru opting for the Metro will have to change trains to get to KIA.

The suburban rail system is also likely to get Metro-like facilities. Sources said 53 air-conditioned suburban trains with automated double-leaf sliding doors will be deployed in the first phase. Automated fare collection (AFC) gates at stations will enable smart card-based cashless travel for suburban rail users.

Chief minister BS Yediyurappa on Sunday said work on Bengaluru’s suburban rail project will be taken up on priority and will be completed within three years. While unveiling a detailed plan on the four-corridor 148km project on Sunday, K-RIDE revealed it would take six years to complete the project.

Meanwhile, a halt railway station — between Doddajala and Devanahalli railway stations — will be ready by February-end, bringing relief to airport-bound passengers. The proposed halt station will be close to the airport boundary and 2-3km away from the terminal. Bangalore International Airport Limited (BIAL) is building the halt station and also operates shuttle services between the station and terminal. An online petition launched by Rajkumar Dugar titled 'Bengaluru needs trains to airport - and fast' has got more than 12,650 signatures so far.

Title: Mehreen Pirzada: A family vacay for Mehreen
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: Madras high court orders reinstatement of nurse made scapegoat
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Madras high court

MADURAI: Madras high court has directed the state government to reinstate a staff nurse who was terminated from service following a maternal death at a primary health centre (PHC) in Tirunelveli , saying she was made a scape goat without conducting a proper inquiry.

Petitioner T Blessie moved the HC Madurai bench in 2011 seeking to quash the termination order passed by the director of medical and rural health services dated July 23 that year and reinstate her. Her counsel stated that on April 24, 2009, a woman named Kannuthai delivered a baby girl at the Ukkirankottai PHC where the nurse was employed on contract. However, the woman developed a complication following which duty doctor Padma shifted her to the Tirunelveli medical college hospital where she died after two hours.

The petitioner was subsequently transferred to three PHCs within 27 months. On June 10, 2011, Tirunelveli deputy director of health services instructed her to sign a pre-written paper without allowing her to read it. The counsel submitted that on July 23 the termination order was passed on the charge that it was dereliction of duty on her part which resulted in the maternal death. When the nurse had discharged the duties on the instructions of the duty doctor, she alone had been punished, which was a discrimination. He stated that the order was passed without providing an opportunity to the petitioner to explain. The government advocate submitted that based on the representation given by the mother of the deceased woman, an inquiry was conducted and departmental proceedings initiated against Blessie, Padma and block medical officer Dr Sivagami Ebinezer.

The deputy director on completion of oral inquiry held the petitioner responsible for the death as she had not written the details on the case sheet, administered methergine injection before separation of placenta against protocol, did not administer an injection (syntocinon) and had not given proper treatment during the referral. On perusal of the submissions, Justice J Nisha Banu observed that the authorities concerned have straightaway passed the termination order without issuing charge-memo and without conducting any departmental inquiry in violation of Article 311(2) of the Constitution.

Title: Dhanush’s next will be with Karthick Naren
Content: Kangana Ranaut fans were in for a surprise on August 21 as the actress announced her arrival on Twitter. And within 10 days of her debut on the micro-blogging site, Kangana has clocked 1 million followers. Title: Maharashtra Accident: 10 killed, seven injured as dumper collides with SUV in Maharashtra's Jalgaon
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Twelve people were killed and five others injured after a dumper truck collided with their sports utility vehicle (SUV) in Maharashtra's Jalgaon district , a police official said on Monday.

The mishap took place around 11 pm on Sunday when Balu Narayan Chowdhary and his family members were on their way to Chinchol village after attending a marriage function in Chopra village, located around 400km from here, he said.

A dumper truck coming from the opposite direction collided with the SUV on Chopra-Faizpur road near Hingola village in Yaval tehsil, the official at Faizpur police station said.

Chowdhary, his wife and eight other SUV occupants died on the spot while two others succumbed to their injuries during treatment at a hospital, he said.

Five other car occupants who sustained injuries were admitted to different hospitals in Jalgaon, he said.

The dumper driver, Mukund Bhangale, was arrested and booked under Indian Penal Code Sections 304 A (causing death by negligence) and 279 (rash driving), he said.

The victims were residents of Chinchol and Mehul villages under Muktai tehsil, the official said.

Besides Balu Chowdhary, 10 other deceased have been identified as Mangla Chowdhary, Ashlesha Chowdhary, Riya Chowdhary, Sonali Chowdhary, Priyanka Chowdhary, Sonali Mahajan, Sumanbai Patil, Sangeeta Patil, Shivam Chowdhary and SUV driver Dhanraj Koli.

One of the deceased was not yet identified, the official added.

Title: New Motor Vehicles Act's roll-out in Maharashtra a distant possibility
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

PUNE: The Maharashtra government doesn't seem to be in any mood to implement the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, on the ground that penalties for some of the offences are "unreasonable"."We feel that the penalties for certain offences are way too high and should be reduced. A report on it will be ready by next week and sent to the road transport and highways ministry with a request to lower the penalties. Further decision by the state depends on the ministry's reply," transport minister Anil Parab told TOI .The Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Bill, 2019 was approved by the Cabinet on June 24, 2019, for re-introduction in the Lok Sabha. The bill was passed in the Lok Sabha on July 23. Later, it was taken into consideration by the Rajya Sabha on July 31 and was passed the same day.The new Motor Vehicles Act with stricter penalties for violation of traffic came into force Pan-India from September 1, 2019.All this happened when Maharashtra was governed by the BJP-Shiv Sena alliance, which too had refrained from implementing the amended stature in the state. "When I was the transport minister, I had sent a letter to the Union transport minister urging him to reconsider the quantum of the penalties. But there was no reply to the letter," Diwakar Raote, Parab's predecessor, told TOI .A senior official in the transport department said the situation has not changed much even after Maharashtra got a new government. "These decisions are taken at the chief minister-level and we don't have any clue. The amended Act has not been implemented in the state till now. The government has to issue a notification first," the official said.Sujit Patwardhan of NGO Parisar said, "The cost of living has gone up, but that hasn't deterred people from spending. A bike or a scooter costs nothing less than 65,000 and the cost of fuel has gone up as well. But we don't see people not buying two-wheelers or other vehicles."He added, "Then where is the problem if the quantum of the penalties is high? The lawmakers should realize that the amended Act would curb violation of the motor vehicle rules."

Title: Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt are nearing the finish line
Content:
T 3429 BRAHMĀSTRA.. coming to cinemas on 4/12/20 & Ayan is NOT allowed to change it now! #Brahmastra #RanbirKapoor… https://t.co/YaLqh0sHT7 — Amitabh Bachchan (@SrBachchan) 1580621404000

On Sunday, Amitabh Bachchan took to Twitter to announce the new release date of Ayan Mukerji ’s fantasy-action-adventure, ' Brahmastra ', fronted by Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt. “T 3429 'BRAHMSTRA'… coming to cinemas on 4/12/20 & Ayan is NOT allowed to change it now,” the veteran actor exclaimed, referring to several changes in the date since it went on the floors. Media has now learnt that the Karan Johar production, the first part of a trilogy, will wrap up with a 20-day schedule, which kicks off early next month in Mumbai.“The team will shoot some romantic scenes with RK and Alia and complete some patchwork with the rest of the cast,” revealed a source. The film had flagged off in February 2018 in Bulgaria, followed by marathon schedules in London, New York, Scotland, Varanasi and, Manali, where the climax was canned. The film features Ranbir as Shiva, who emits fire from his hand, with Alia as his love interest, Isha.“It’s an ambitious film for Ayan as the visual effects are not limited to the action sequences. Even the real shooting locations will be enhanced with VFX, which is why the film has taken longer than expected,” the source informed. The film has been in the making for around 170 days. By the time it wraps up, the cast would have worked for almost 200 days. “It’s one of the longest shoot for a film in the last 20 years, along with 'Bahubali' and 'Padmaavat'.”A London-based team is working on the visual effects. Ayan will move to the editing, background score and dubbing once he wraps up the shoot. “The new date was announced keeping in mind the time required for the finishing touches. There will be no delay in the release now,” the source added.'Brahmastra' also features Nagarjuna and Dimple Kapadia in pivotal roles and a cameo by Shah Rukh Khan, who shot for his turn in November last year.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 29 under watch in Haryana
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: With 16 more Haryana residents who returned from China in the past fortnight being put under medical watch for coronavirus, their number has reached 29.

The state health department took samples of four more persons with suspected symptoms of the deadly viral disease on Saturday. These persons include two from Panchkula, one each from Gurgaon and Karnal.

The department officials said the ones from Panchkula have travel history from Wuhan, while the other two were found to be symptomatic anyhow.

"The samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune for testing. The Panipat resident whose sample was sent to NIV on January 31 has tested negative," a health official said.

In a bid to intensify the screening, the state health department has also set up special check posts on the national highways connecting to Delhi.

Besides this, hospitals have been provided with self-declaration forms for the persons who volunteer for screening for coronavirus.

Title: Thane conman held for duping finance company
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A 38-year-old history-sheeter who procured loans using forged IDs and government documents was arrested by the property cell of the crime branch on Saturday. Divakar Jaiswal, a resident of Wagle Estate in Thane, had on him Aadhaar and PAN cards with his photograph and various fictitious names.

Jaiswal allegedly duped Bajaj Finance, which helps consumers buy electronic goods with loans, of several lakhs. He procured loans with bogus documents and purchased different mobile phones and other goods. The company had approached the police when several loans were defaulted on.

Title: Hassled flat buyer to get Rs 20 lakh payout from Thane society, builder
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Reprimanding a Thane-based housing society for being "hand in glove" with a builder in "mentally harassing" a flat owner to extract excess money, the state consumer commissioner has ordered it, its office bearers and the builder to pay Rs 5.5 lakh as compensation to the family. The builder will also have to pay the family Rs 14.4 lakh as compensation for delay in handing over their flat.

The flat's owner, Kishor Narkhede, had alleged that the society refused to give him a share certificate, demanded excessive money and prevented the family from peacefully using their flat and parking lot. He said the society filed false criminal complaints against him and his family.

Penalising the society's chairman, secretary, ex-secretary, treasurer, and some members, the commission said, "A society once formed, cannot be justified to act unlawfully in connivance with the builder and other members to pick and choose a flat purchaser to collectively harass him to knock out ransom or subjecting him to illegal demands and frivolous, false and vexatious prosecution."

In a complaint submitted online last year, Narkhade told the Maharashtra State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission that he bought the 865-sqft flat in Ganraj Heights from Ganraj Group for Rs 36 lakh in 2011. He received possession only in 2018.

In its order, the commission directed the society to induct the owner as a member and not interfere in the family's possession of the flat and parking space. "Ganraj Height CHS shall issue share certificate of the society in favour of the complainants without demanding any illegal payments. Demand of payment, if any, shall be made in writing and payment, when made, shall be acknowledged by a valid receipt in writing," the commission said.

Narkhade told the commission that in a bid to grab the parking lot he had already paid for, the housing society in connivance with the builder and members named in the complaint had begun passing resolutions against him in his absence. Stating that the housing society should conduct its affairs and financial aspects transparently, the commission said, "Each flat purchaser shall be informed in writing to participate in meetings to pass valid and legal resolutions to maintain the building in a habitable condition. The society can never be permitted to act in collusion with any ill-motivated selfish flat purchaser or builder intending to grab property so as to continuously harass the complainants, mentally or physically."

Title: Telangana traffic cops get typhoid shots
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A vaccination drive was conducted for over 500 traffic police personnel at CAR, Police Headquarters, Amberpet, on Sunday.

The purpose of the vaccination drive was to help traffic police, who are at risk and spend odd hours on the field to immunize them against typhoid infection. Despite honest efforts from the department, many times they end up having no access to safe water and food, while on duty. This puts them at risk for typhoid.

Speaking after inaugurating the drive, Rachakonda deputy commissioner of police, LB Nagar, Sunpreet Singh said, “This is a great initiative. With the help of Bharat Biotech, United Ways of Hyderabad and Nice Foundation , we vaccinated over 500 Rachakonda police staff. When our policemen are at work, they may consume contaminated water or food and are prone to typhoid, I am happy they are now immunized against typhoid infection.” He also divulged that he was twice infected with typhoid.

Title: Task cut out for Nagal and Prajnesh
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Sumit Nagal. (TOI Photo)

PUNE: Prajnesh Gunneswaran and Sumit Nagal will carry the nation's hopes when they walk out on the Centre Court in the $610,000 Tata Open Maharashtra, starting at Mhalunge-Balewadi sports complex here on Monday.

While the expectations on Gunneswaran might be a tad less, as he had been recovering from a wrist injury, it will be a completely different story with Nagal. The 22-yearold, ranked131, did not feature even in qualifying last year while he lost in the first round as a qualifier in 2018. This time, however, the Haryanvi can be sure that the crowd will be rooting for him.

"I would say there is a bit of pressure, but in a good way," said Nagal, who faces Serbian Viktor Troicki in the third match on centre court on Monday. Troicki, a former world No. 12 now ranked 159, came through the qualifying round. "Having pressure, having the Indian people behind me, hoping to do well is a good thing. I like the spotlight."

Nagal, though, is aware that it's only the start of the year and he has a lot of work to do. He acknowledged that his best performances, apart from the US Open first round clash against Roger Federer, had come on clay last year, and that he needed to do well on hard to go further up ladder. "I need to improve on hard court. I can't just keep playing on one surface," he said. "That is one of the goals we have set, try to be more comfortable on hard court."

And he knows which areas of his game need attention. "Serve matters a lot on clay. You can get by with the kick serve. On hard court it is important with the serve and the first shot," he said.

"That is where I think if I start doing better, it will start to have an impact not only on hard, but on clay as well.

"So there is stuff like getting used to coming to the net because you want the points to be shorter."

Gunneswaran, who's opener against German Yannick Maden is set for Tuesday, will feel confident after a rigorous practice match against Italian Thomas Fabbiano when his groundstrokes seemed to flow fluently. Ramkumar Ramanathan is another home lad who would be keen to impress his fans and prove his pundits wrong.

Title: Just Cricket, Raipur teams post wins in Royal Premium Cricket League
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The fifth edition of the Royal Premium Cricket League inaugurated at the Methodist Mecosabagh ground

NAGPUR: Just Riders and Fine Star, Raipur registered contrasting victories on the second day of the fifth edition of the Royal Premium Cricket League at the Methodist Mecosabagh ground here on Sunday.

Batting first in the first outing of the day, Roast Riders Cafe were restricted to 65 for 7 wickets in 8 overs. In reply, Just Riders reached the target with a wicket to spare. They huffed and puffed their way to score 68 for 9 wickets in 8 overs.

The second match was played between Fine Star, Raipur and Roast Riders Cafe. The visitors won the match by 22 runs.

Opting to bat, Raipur amassed 100 for the loss of 2 wickets in their stipulated 8 overs. Gopi Patel hammered 68 off just 28 balls, while Shabuddin Ali belted 21 off 16 balls. For Roast Riders Café, Deepak Kashyap and Vikram Patel took one wicket each.

Chasing a daunting target, Roast Riders Cafe could muster only 78 for 8 in 8 overs. Deepak Kashyap (20) and Malcolm John (17) tried hard but lack support from others.

Raipur’s Hassain scalped 2 wickets while Shabuddin Ali, Izhar, Ankit and Vardan took a wicket apiece. Man-of-the-match given to Sharad Anil Sharma by Umesh Ojha, director City Care and by Kodumal Dhanrajani, Chariman RPCL-V.

Earlier, the annual tourney was inaugurated by Sarabjeet Singh Bhatia, managing director, Bhatia Farms and Arun Kumar Jaiswar, chief regional manager (Nagpur Circle), Oriental Insurance Co Ltd. Kodumal Dhanrajani, chairman RPCL and MD, Shrikrishan Traders and Nagpur Restaurant, presided over the function. Rohit Kaisalwar, Kunal Bhumralkar, Kodumal Dhanrajani, Sunny Dudhani and Mohd Irfan Razzak were present on the occasion.

Title: Hyderabad man hangs self after ‘love failure’
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 32-year-old man hanged himself at his shop in Ramanthapur allegedly after a failure in a relationship.

The victim, identified as A Ravi , a tailor and resident of Nehru Nagar , who owns a shop at Indiranagar area hanged himself at his shop on Saturday night.

“The incident came to light on Sunday morning, after the workers arrived at the shop and found him hanging at around 10.30am on Sunday. We suspect the victim committed suicide on Saturday night,” said Uppal subinspector, Jayaram.

Police found a suicide note stating that the victim took the step after a love failure . “He also mentioned in his suicide note that his shop and machines should be handed over to his brother-in-law,” added the officer. A case of suspicious death case was registered.

Title: Mumbai: At Sunday’s bird race, watchers sing elegy over loss of green cover
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The red-breasted flycatcher

MUMBAI: With over 300 avid birdwatchers waking up at daybreak to participate in the annual Mumbai BirdRace on Sunday, the event got off to a flying start in the city and surrounding regions of Thane, Navi Mumbai, Raigad.

“The presence of bird species is an indicator of a region’s biodiversity. This year, once more, we got great response to the Mumbai BirdRace as birders visited areas like Sanjay Gandhi National Park, Karnala Bird Sanctuary, the wetlands at Sewree, Airoli, Bhandup and Uran, among others,” said veteran naturalist and core team member, Sunjoy Monga.

Sponsored by Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Ltd (HSBC) and co-sponsored by Tata Chemicals and Nikon, the city’s enthusiastic birding community spoke about how rampant ‘development’ in green zones had affected the number of species spotted.

The assistant director of Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS), Raju Kasambe, said, “At Uran, where wetlands have diminished over the years, the number of bird species spotted have also come down. But I am happy to see youngsters and even school children show a keen interest in birds and in the environment.”

Another birder, Kunal Munsiff, said, “Our team visited Tungareshwar forest where we saw the red-breasted flycatcher, racket-tailed drongo and golden oriole and heard the call of the jungle owlet.”

Paediatrician, Dr Salil Choksi, said, “Due to rampant development, finding birding areas in Mumbai has become challenging. We went to Karnala, near Panvel, where we saw the forest wagtail, taiga flycatcher and green pigeon. Later, at the Dombivali Bhopar scrubland, we saw over 50 bird species. If towers are erected here tomorrow, all the birds will disappear.”

“Statistics show the bird species in Uran has gone down in the past 15 years during the BirdRaces. Though we do not claim to do any precise scientific study, our figures show something is wrong with Uran region,” said Monga.

Title: Dead for nine years, UT to breathe life into FIR-hit theme park project
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: More than nine years after the registration of an FIR in the controversial theme-cum-amusement park project, the UT administration has decided to revive the plan, with Punjab governor cum-UT administrator V P Singh Badnore directing officials to look for 40 acres of land.“There were some issues in the past. But this time, the administration will start the project with complete transparency. We will go for international bidding. The project will be beneficial for the city. It will also boost tourism. Land will not be a major problem,” Badnore said while interacting with mediapersons at Chandigarh Press Club on Sunday.The FIR was registered on October 4, 2010, stating that the former top officials of the UT in connivance with Unitech Limited indulged in a criminal conspiracy and awarded 73.65 acres of land in Sarangpur to Unitech for a Rs 5.5-crore fixed annual licence fee and on 1.1% annual revenue sharing basis. It was alleged the administration ignored financial rules while inviting tenders and shortlisting companies. The officers had allegedly ‘ignored’ the highest bidder, DLF, and allotted the project to Unitech.A special CBI court had issued fresh summons to the then UT adviser, Lalit Sharma, then home secretary Krishan Mohan and then director, tourism, Vivek Atray and Unitech Limited director Ajay Chandra under Sections 120 B, 420, 201 of IPC and Section 13(1)d and section 13(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act. This after a CBI court had rejected the third closure report in the scam. The CBI had earlier moved two closure reports in the case, but the court had rejected both, mentioning further investigation should be conducted in the matter. The special CBI court had a few days back granted bail to three former IAS officers in the case on furnishing bail bonds of Rs 1lakh each.The central vigilance commission (CVC) was the first investigating agency to look into the financial irregularities in the project. The case was later shifted to the CBI. The CVC, which had received a complaint from Vivek Aditya, an RTI activist, in 2009, had submitted its report with the CBI.

Title: 49,000 flats of over Rs 1.5 crore left unsold in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

BENGALURU: For at least the third consecutive year, the luxury housing market was the worst performing segment in residential sales.

Data from property consultancy Anarock show that unsold luxury stock (homes priced at Rs 1.5 crore and more), rose 10% to 89,200 units in 2019 in the top 7 cities, compared to the year before. The value of such stock is estimated to be about Rs 1.6 lakh crore ($22 billion), which is 34% of total unsold inventory.

Mumbai’s unsold luxury stock stood at 48,970 units, New Delhi’s 18,400 units and Bengaluru’s 7,470 units. These three cities contributed the most to the leftover inventory. Projects in south and central Mumbai, one of the most expensive micro markets, have dried up as buyers of luxury homes prefer ready-tomove-in projects.

The uncertainty and slowness in the economy and a glut of unsold stock has also prevented a price rise in the segment, which was the major reason that drew investors between 2006 and 2010. The market was also badly impacted by demonetisation, which brought cash transactions to a sudden halt.

“There is hardly any movement in the category over Rs 1.5 crore,” Ravindra Pai, managing director of Century Real Estate, said. “We have one project in the CBD area, which has about 36 apartments at a price bracket of Rs 5 crore. While 80% is sold, we have not sold anything in the last one and half years. We are only focusing on commercial, plotted and mid-segment,” he said.

While luxury apartments comprise one-third of the value of total unsold stock, it contributes only 14% to the volumes. Developers have severely curtailed the supply due to lack of interest in the segment. A Brigade Estates executive said that the company has seen some traction in ready-to-move-in luxury properties compared to under construction ones. “While we have launched a project in Chennai where the apartments cost Rs 2 crore each, there is nothing planned in Bengaluru for the future,” he said.

Pankaj Kapoor, CEO of real estate analytics company Liases Foras, said the category gained popularity between 2006 and 2008 due to the rise of millionaires but came crashing post the financial crisis. “The segment became absolutely irrational due to the high prices after that. Also, many builders in Mumbai built costly apartments in areas which were surrounded by slums. Buyers paying a fortune demand something special and exclusive,” he said.

Title: Vikram Bhatt: We allow people to hack into our lives
Content: What would you do if someone accessed your online data and started blackmailing you? That’s the question Vikram Bhatt ’s next, 'Hacked', tries to answer. The filmmaker said that he was closely watching Wikileaks, the Julian Assange-founded organisation that publishes news leaks and classified media, and Edward Snowden’s account of flying to Hong Kong and staying at a Russian transit lounge for 40 days, struck a chord.“Six years ago, my laptop was hacked and with that, so were my social media accounts. I was being notified about friend requests being accepted when I hadn’t sent any, but the scatterbrain that I am, I assumed I may have mistakenly sent them, till a friend pinged me to ask why was I chatting with him on FB messenger when I had his number,” he recounts, adding that he had to change the operating and security systems to deal with the menace.But that hasn’t helped. On Sunday, Vikram was forced to deactivate his Facebook account again, after he learnt that someone had got through his two-step verification and hacked in. On Instagram, he warned followers that “this is not me”. “We allow people to hack into our lives, it just takes a little knowledge of technology,” he sighs.Prod him on how hacking happens, and he explains that when we download an app or software on our phone, it asks permission to access our camera, mic, photo gallery and contacts and we click on ‘I agree’ without hesitation. Similarly, we accept cookies from a website without reading terms and conditions. “Even WhatsApp, though only a messaging service, monitors where you are and Google uses it to update its maps,” he cautions, adding that Snowden now removes the mic every time he buys a new phone, attaching an external mic to make calls.But isn’t the cyber cell created to deal with such miscreants? “How much can they control?” Vikram asks, pointing out that hackers have wormed their way into the websites of big companies with firewalls. “They keep inventing newer trojans and viruses.”In his film, 19-year-old Rohan Shah plays the antagonist and Vikram informs that’s the average age of a hacker. “These kids mature faster because power corrupts,” he says, drawing parallels between his character and the delinquents who hacked into Amitabh Bachchan ’s Twitter to put up a Pakistani flag there. “It was their way of saying that despite all the security, we got into Amit ji’s house, shook hands with him, and you couldn’t touch us.”'Hacked' will come up against Mohit Suri ’s star-studded ' Malang ' but Vikram is unfazed. “Mohit was my assistant and learnt filmmaking from me. I sent him a message, saying that both of us should pop champagne together on February 7,” he smiles, revealing that he plans to take a sabbatical now. “I’ve been working for 39 years, since I was 14, starting a film while another was still in the theatres. I missed the bus on my youth. My daughter, Krishna, is 25 and may get married soon. My parents are getting old. I want to spend as much time as I can with them. I’ll focus on writing for a while and write a script for my daughter to direct.”Will it be in the horror space? He laughs, “I go to people with a love story and they ask for a horror story. First you make a brand, then, the brand follows you. Fortunately, Krishna wants to do a love story as she doesn’t want to be compared to her papa.”

Title: Four fatka gang members held after Vashi cops lay trap in bushes
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

NAVI MUMBAI: The Vashi GRP has arrested four fatka gang members on Thursday night by laying a trap near Sanpada railway tracks. While two of the accused were arrested when they robbed two women commuters of their mobiles by striking on their hands, their two aides were found hiding behind the bushes abutting the tracks.

The accused have been identified as Umar Shaikh (21), Mohammad Shaikh (18), Rehan Qureshi (18) and Danish Qureshi (18), all residents of Behrampada and Fattarnagar in Bandra .

Vashi GRP inspector Nandkumar Saste said, “In the past 15 days, the fatka thieves had robbed 10 women commuters travelling on the footboard, of their mobiles by hitting them on their hand with a stick. They had targeted them between Sanpada-Turbhe and Sanpada-Juinagar tracks. As the accused used to target commuters between 7pm and 10pm, a special GRP squad was deployed between 3pm and 10pm. We arrested two thieves red-handed on Thursday when they targeted two women commuters. We continued our search and found two more youths hiding in the bushes abut the tracks.”

Title: Priyanshu stars in Hyderabad win
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

HYDERABAD: In a battle to avoid the wooden spoon, Hyderabad Hunters downed Mumbai Rockets 4-3 in the Premier Badminton League match here on Sunday.

But the inconsequential tie became the perfect stage for the launch of another promising shuttler, Priyanshu Rajawat. The 18-year-old, representing Hunters, stunned world No.49 Lee Dong Keun of Korea 15-13, 15-9. Ranked No.284 in the world, the sprightly teen displayed superb skills near the net and away from it in equal measure. The manner in which he executed the half smashes and crosscourt pushes were a delight to watch. The fans, who had come to watch PV Sindhu , left home chanting the name of Priyanshu.

Even while engaging his rival in long rallies, Priyanshu never lost his composure and negotiated the tough situations with ease.

Meanwhile, Hunters' semifinal hopes, which were hanging by a thread, have effectively ended as they secured only four points from the tie. Both Hunters and Rockets are at the bottom of the table with 10 points each.

Earlier, the home team got off to a disastrous start as its men's doubles pair of Vladimir Ivanov and Ben Lane went down without a fight against Kim Gi Jung and Kim Sa Rang of Mumbai 10-15, 8-15. The Koreans, who won bronze at the World Championships twice, were too good for the Anglo-Russian pair of Lane and Ivanov. The Hunters' duo was in the game only up to the 7th point in both the games.

Rockets' skipper Parupalli Kashyap struck form after losing three matches on trot to beat Daren Liew. With Kashyap winning the trump 15-8, 15-13, Mumbai secured a 3-0 lead. Sindhu then won the trump match to revive Hunters' hopes before Priyanshu made it 3-3 for the home team. Sindhu hardly broke any sweat as she dismissed Shreyanshi Pardeshi in two games 15-5, 15-10.

Title: Airline can cap compensation for loss of baggage
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

Title: Punjab: VP Singh Badnore backs congestion fee
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

V P Singh Badnore at a Kashmiri food festival in Chandigarh Press Club on Sunday

CHANDIGARH: At a time when the city is grappling with traffic chaos and parking space crunch, Punjab governor-cum-UT administrator VP Singh Badnore has backed congestion charges in busy markets. He, however, clarified that such a solution should come from sub-committees of the UT administrator's advisory council.

"Some sub-committees have compiled their reports and they will be discussed in the advisory council meeting next month," Badnore said. "Chandigarh's per capita income is very high. People roam around in expensive cars but many feel parking charges should be Rs 5. When you look at big cities around the world, there is always a core area where you have to pay more for parking your vehicle," he said. On traffic congestion, he said all options of mass rapid transport system (MRTS) are open for consideration.

Title: War Hammer reduces Indian Derby to one-horse race
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

War Hammer. (TOI Photo)

Title: Coronavirus Treatment: Thai doctors claim to have cracked coronavirus cure using HIV drugs
Content: In what may be termed as a positive development, a group of doctors from Thailand have claimed to have found a cure for the deadly Coronavirus by administrating HIV drugs. As numbers continue to rise, estimates suggest that more than 17,000 people have been infected with the viral strain, as more and more countries impose travel bans and restrictions. The deadly infection has now been declared a worldwide public health emergency by the World Health Organisation.Thailand, which has recorded the second-highest number of cases of the rampant infection (18) after China has been seeing a good potential recovery rate, with doctors reporting success rates in treating patients infected with the disease.According to a statement issued by Thailand's health ministry, a woman of Chinese origin, admitted to a hospital in Bangkok has shown surprising improvement and recovery rate after the doctors attending to her case administered a mix of medicines, largely anti-viral drugs mainly used to treat infections like the Flu and the HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus).According to the report released, doctors involved in the case administered a combination of drugs, including oseltamivir with lopinavir and ritonavir to the patient which has shown "speedy" results. The research is still to be published.According to inputs from AFP, the woman, who recorded the same symptoms as of other patients, like exhaustion, tiredness and flu was able to rest and sit up properly after the dose was given to her.The patient, who is 71 years old tested negative for Coronavirus infection, nearly 48 hours after the first dose of the combination medicines were given to her. If this news is true, this might be the much-needed breakthrough needed to crack the Coronavirus outbreak , which is now fast spreading around the world. Till date, a total of 362 people have lost their lives due to the virus, including a 44-year-old who died in the Philippines, which makes it the first death to happen outside of China, the area of primary attack.In India, two people in Kerala who travelled back to the country from China have so far tested positive for the virus and are undergoing quarantine and getting necessary treatment for the same.Apart from this, many new researchers are underway to find a fast and effective cure for the virus outbreak which started in December 2019. No cure or preventive measure has been established to tackle the virus, as of yet.

Title: Union Budget 2020: Rs 204 crore allotted to improve Patna's air quality, says Sushil Modi
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Sunday said of the Rs 408 crore allocated by the 15th Finance Commission for Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC), Rs 204 crore would be spent on improving air quality in the city.

Modi said Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, while presenting the Union Budget on Saturday, had noted that the Centre accepted the recommendations of the 15th Finance Commission headed by N K Singh for the 2020-21 fiscal as to the states' share in the central pool of taxes.

Track the pollution level in your city

He also said that of the total allocation of Rs 2,416 crore for the urban bodies of Bihar, Rs 408 crore had been allocated for PMC. Further, half of this sum or Rs 204 crore would be spent on improving air quality in Patna. The remaining Rs 204 crore would be spent on safe drinking water and solid waste management. All other local urban bodies in the state will share the allocation worth Rs 2,008 crore.

Pointing to the salient features of the recommendations made by the 15th Finance Commission for Bihar, Modi said the allocations for disaster management and urban bodies had been increased three-fold compared to the allocations made in 2019-20 fiscal. Moreover, Rs 20 crore has been allocated for expenditure on schemes to be made specifically for the drought-prone districts. The Anganwadi Kendras would have additional Rs 664 crore to combat malnutrition among children.

"While the allocation for disaster management in 2019-20 financial year was Rs 569 crore, it has been increased to Rs 1,818 crore. As much as 80% of the sum will be spent on combatting disaster and the remaining 20% on mitigation of the disaster. Similarly, the allocation of Rs 2,416 crore for local urban bodies is for 2020-21. It was Rs 818 crore in 2019-20 fiscal," Modi said.

He added that the allocation for the three-tier panchayati raj institutions - zila parishads, prakhand samitis and panchayats - is 5,018 crore, which would go directly into the bank accounts of these bodies. "As much as 50% of the total amount would be an untagged sum and the remaining 50% would be spent on cleanliness and safe drinking water," Modi said.

Title: Midday workers to launch stir on Monday
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Some 15,000 midday meal (bisioota) workers have threatened to launch an indefinite protest here on Monday even as police imposed ban orders under section 144 and threatened to arrest them on arrival at KSR City railway station.

While the workers had sought permission to hold their protest at Freedom Park, cops feared since the venue won't be able to accommodate so many people, the protesters would pitch camp on adjoining Seshadri Road.

Police commissioner Bhaskar Rao cited traffic issues, law and order and lack of infrastructure such as toilets for women while denying their request and imposed ban orders on Sunday evening. S Varalakshmi, president, Karnataka State Midday Meal Workers Association described the police action as undemocratic.

According to police, 15,000-20,000 workers are expected to reach Bengaluru on Monday, many of them by train. Police will deploy additional forces at KSR City station to prevent them from entering Seshadri Road.

The workers are demanding hike in remuneration and fixation of minimum monthly wages. Currently, cooks get Rs 2,700 every month and their helpers Rs 2,600.

Title: Bengaluru: Student, 19, nabbed for killing father
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 19-year-old diploma student was arrested for allegedly murdering his 56-year-old father for harassing his mother under the influence of alcohol.

Police said D Gahan beat his father, Dodda Chowdappa, a bank employee, to death with a club used to make ragi balls.

Chowdappa lived in Ganapati Nagar with wife Tippamma and children Ranjan, an engineering student, and Gahan. he used to regularly fight with his wife under the influence of alcohol. On January 28, Gahan took the club used to prepare ragi balls and beat his father. Tippamma found Chowdappa dead the next day.

Title: As govt divides, our duty is to unite people: Yogendra Yadav
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Yogendra Yadav

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The country is presently going through an unforeseen movement, a movement to unite the people. When the BJP-led Union government wants to divide the people, “our responsibility is to unite the people”, said psephologist and politician-activist Yogendra Yadav .

“The implementation of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) is unprecedented in the country and we never expected a Union government to divide people in the name of religion,” said Yadav, who was in the city to campaign against CAA.

“This move by the Centre has united the people the same way we stood up for our freedom struggle. The protest has become a national movement of unity. This is the first time that strong protests have taken place, especially by students and youths,” he said, while participating at the meet-the -press programme organised by Kerala Union of Working Journalists.

Yadav is of the opinion that the main purpose of implementing CAA is to classify people in the country as firstand second-grade citizens. “The CAA is not for taking the citizenship away from citizens. But it is to create two categories of people in the country. So the Centre is trying to signal the people about this classification. The combination of CAA, NRC and NPR is a deadly weapon,” Yadav said.

There is enormous pressure on the national media and judiciary to suppress anti-CAA protests. But Kerala is an exception. He also appreciated the state government for its resolution against CAA.

Yadav clarified that he was not interested in Delhi elections and his focus is on anti-CAA campaign. “But one thing is for sure, BJP is losing and they are trying to trigger communalism in Delhi as they are now desperate to win,” Yadav said.

He flayed the Union Budget as a declaration of war on farmers. “The Union finance minister said in the budget speech that the government has proposed 40 points to improve the agriculture sector in the country. However, she had not allocated a single paisa for these projects. When I read the budget allocations, none of the farming sectors has got good allocations. So it was just an eyewash by the minister,” Yadav said.

Title: Godrej Properties Q3 results to be out today
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: Realty developer Godrej Properties is all set to announce its earnings for the quarter ended December 2019 today i.e. Monday, February 3.

For the quarter ended September 2019 (Q2), the company reported a 50 per cent year-on-year (YoY) rise in consolidated net profit at Rs 31 crore. During the second quarter, the company witnessed a total booking value of Rs 1,446 crore and a total booking volume of 2.26 million sq ft.

While declaring the Q2 results, Pirojsha Godrej , Executive Chairman, Godrej Properties said, "The overall environment in the real estate sector remains challenging. This provides Godrej Properties with tremendous opportunity to drive market share growth in residential real estate. We expect strong momentum in both portfolio project additions and new project launches in H2 FY20."

While market experts are eagerly waiting for the performance report, the shares of the company were trading at Rs 1040 (NSE) around 10:50 am on Monday, February 3.

Title: Many sanctioned posts of officials in Patna University lying vacant
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Patna University

PATNA: Even as almost all the sanctioned posts of Patna University officials are lying vacant for the last several years (in some cases, decades), no sincere efforts have been made by the authorities concerned to fill up these posts on regular basis.

The university has been allowed to run on an ad hoc arrangement all these years. The erstwhile Bihar State University (Constituent Colleges) Service Commission or the Bihar Public Service Commission never bothered to make appointment against all these vacant posts.

The office of the registrar fell vacant after the transfer of last regularly appointed registrar Vibhas Kumar Yadav to Veer Kunwar Singh University more than a decade back. Quite recently, Colonel Manoj Kumar Mishra was appointed as registrar by then governor-cum-chancellor Satya Pal Malik. Earlier, PU zoology department former head Sudhir Kumar Srivastava and Hindi department former head Balram Tiwari had served as the registrar for some time.

PU assistant registrar N Zaman was promoted as deputy registrar. He also officiated as the proctor of PU for a brief period until Patna Science College chemistry teacher Rajnish Kumar was appointed on the post. There are two sanctioned posts of assistant registrars, but both are lying vacant.

The university has not got a regular controller of examinations for the last three decades following the superannuation of S A Imam. Senior teachers of the university have been officiating as the controller of examinations all these years. Patna Science College botany department teacher R K Mandal has been acting as the examination controller at present.

The post of finance officer is also lying vacant for the last 25 years as no regular appointment has been made against the post after the retirement of J D Chaudhary.

The post of university engineer fell vacant in 1985 following the retirement of P K Mukherjee, but no regular appointment has been made against this post. As many as four out of seven posts of assistant engineers are also lying vacant. Besides, only three assistant engineers are working against 20 sanctioned posts.

Worst is the condition of PU Central Library which has not a single regularly appointed official. Patna Science College geology department teacher Rabindra Kumar is presently serving as the library incharge. The posts of university librarian, seven assistant librarians, two research assistants, one classifier and cataloguer and three non-professional assistants are all lying vacant for the last several years.

The last regularly appointed chief medical officer of the university, Vijayee Singh, retired more than two decades ago and since then the PU Central Dispensary is being managed on an ad hoc basis. As many as five posts of medical officers are lying vacant.

The post of development officer was created in 1967, but no regular appointment has since been made against this post. PU zoology department teacher P K Khan has been officiating as the development officer at present. PU applied economics and commerce department teacher Ashim Lal Chakravorty has been officiating as the budget-cum-accounts officer of the university following the retirement of Ganeshwar Pradhan some years back.

Even the class III and IV posts in most colleges and postgraduate departments have fallen vacant. More than a couple of years ago, the state government had announced that class III and IV staff would now be outsourced in the colleges and universities. But, only a few staff could be provided to some institutions till date, even as most departments and colleges are facing acute shortage of secretarial staff.

Of late, PU has made a move to appoint class III and IV staff against sanctioned posts through an open advertisement to ensure smooth conduct of academic activities in all the institutions, said vice-chancellor Rash Bihari Prasad Singh. But nobody knows as to when PU will get regularly appointed officers to manage its work smoothly.

Title: Kerala: Farmers welcome decision to make wine from fruits
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

Palakkad-based farmer James P Mathew has been making wine from jackfruit

PALAKKAD: Farmers have welcomed the statement of excise minister T P Ramakrishnan that steps were being taken by the government to start a winery at Malabar Distilleries of the now defunct Chittur Cooperative Sugars Ltd in the district.

During the inaugural of excise tower complex here on Saturday, minister for water resources K Krishnankutty, a leading farmer, reminded the excise minister about the Cabinet decision in October last year on making wine at Malabar Distilleries to help farmers. The excise minister replied that after the ongoing Assembly session, steps will be intensified to start production of low-alcoholic wine from fruits and vegetables in Palakkad and the state as a whole.

Muthalamthode Mani, general secretary, Desheeya Karshaka collective, said, “Allowing wine making from fruits such as jackfruit, pineapple, bananas, mango, orange, grapes and tender coconut will help the farmers in fetching good price for their products.”

Mani said mango farmers of Muthalamada Mango City have been hit due to late flowering of the plants due to climate change. Muthalamada mango used to hit the international market early in January. But this season, the mango production was late by more than oneand-a half months. Because of this, mango farmers will not get good price for their product which used to be exported.

Irumpakachola Farmers Club at Kanjirapuzha in Mannarkkad headed by James P Mathew, a jackfruit farmer popularly called ‘jackfruit man’, said “If wine is commercially made, it will help jackfruit farmers to get at least Rs 300 per fruit which is wasted in the state in a criminal way during every season.”

Title: Pavan Gino Thomas: Bigg Boss Malayalam 2 update, February 2: Sooraj and Pavan enter the house
Content: The weekend episode of Bigg Boss Malayalam 2 starts with Mohanlal welcoming evicted contestant Thesni Khan to the stage. Lal quizzes about her experience inside the house and the actress replies that it was a great opportunity. Thesni goes emotional after watching the snippet video on her journey in the show.Later, Mohanlal interacts with the housemates and congratulates Rajith , the new captain. The host suggests the captain to conduct a meeting with all the inmates every day.On the stage, Lal invites the 3rd wild card entry of the season. Popular RJ and social media star Sooraj enters the stage. In the interaction with the host, Sooraj says that his biggest challenge is to be away from social media.Background music plays inside the house and everyone waits for the new person to enter. All gets surprised to see Sooraj and Arya hugs him. RJ Raghu is seen delighted to see Sooraj who is apparently his friend.Surprisingly, on the stage, Mohanlal invites the next wild card entrant, Pavan Gino Thomas . The former Mr India finalist says that he is expecting a good game. He openly says that Rajith is his favourite contestant. Pavan also makes a mass entry to the house in a motorbike and housemates are spotted awestruck. Sujo hugs Pavan and welcomes him.Later, Mohanlal signs off saying that now the male-female ratio inside the house is correct.Bigg Boss welcomes the new entrants to the house and invites them for the introduction. Sooraj briefs about his career and the controversies he had faced, whereas Pavan shares about his dream of becoming an actor.After the interaction, Suja says to Raghu that Pavan is his cousin. Others are also seen discussing about their first impressions about the new entrants.

Title: Punjab: 647 illegal autos seized, drivers cry harassment
Content:
This story is from February 3, 2020

The drive against illegal autos is under way since January 27

CHANDIGARH: As many as 647 autos plying illegally in the city were impounded from January 27 till February 2 in the special drive started following the directions of the Punjab and Haryana high court .

Data revealed that most of the seized autos (342) were from Punjab. Cops said they were plying without permit or proper documents, a claim that has been contested by the drivers. They alleged traffic cops were challaning them without checking their documents and holding any awareness drive. Anil Kumar, president, Hind Autorickshaw Workers' Union, alleged when they went to meet senior police officials to clear the issue, they were not allowed to see them. "No CNG and LPG filling stations are available in Panchkula. If we come Chandigarh to fill LPG or CNG, cops impound our autos and slap fines of more than Rs 20,000," he said. Drivers suggested the UT administration could impose a tax, like Panchkula, daily for entering the city, as their livelihood depends on autos.

Title: Exclusive! Shantanu Maheshwari, Ash King and Bharat Goel on their track 'Gud Khake'
Content: The amazing combination of Shantanu Maheshwari, Ash King and Bharat Goel has its magic churning in the song ‘Gud Khake’ sung by the soulful Ash King, acted out by the talented Shantanu Maheshwari and composed by Bharat Goel. The audience is loving the hot new romantic song, the cute and the chocolate boy charm of Shantanu which is very refreshing to see.While the song is about cute love at first sight instances of a guy and a girl falling in love at an Indian wedding, it has a really beautiful ethnic touch being shot in the beautiful place Jaipur which gives it a proper desi wedding feel.In an exclusive conversation with Shantanu, Ash and Bharat for the song we got in touch with them for a candid interview and here are the excerpts from the interview:: Actually the song was conceived by Bharat Goel and Siddhant Kaushal , they were attending a wedding together and they had a concept, now we have Bharat right here to explain the story.: So Siddhant Kaushal writer of the song, Siddhant and I were at this wedding and the couple was really sweet so we looked at the couple and you know and we had that feeling you know ‘’, that’s when we decided it’s funny there’s no song on that so there must be a song and that’s how the song was born. And then of course we jammed in the studio, came up with the idea, brainstorm in the studio and of course when we were deciding who should sing the song we unanimously agreed on Ash, of course we didn’t have the budget for Arijit Singh (laughs), so that’s when we got in touch with Ash and Ash did a phenomenal job, really happy with how it’s sounding now.: I would love to work with different kind of genres but, for me I know people expect me to dance whichever music video I come, so I mean for me it was very different. It had a romantic vibe something even which I like to that like a Hero. The composition was such that I fell in love with the song when I did when I heard it for the first time; Ash had sung this song so I was like ‘Wow’, so it just happened, not like we wanted it, but not like we have a problem with it (laughs). I got an offer so I was like why not. The vibe of the song is so cool.So I mean Reecha is the one who’s playing the female lead. There’s no ‘preparation’ that I had to do but I mean just to make each other comfortable so that we can react in a proper manner. We started meeting before to rehearse a few initial choreographies so that we are comfortable with each other. In underwater especially there were intimate moments so that we had to be comfortable and then you have to control your breathing, you have to coordinate with each other.It was very challenging because to move underwater, choreographing becomes very difficult to coordinate with the DOP as well so that he gets the proper shots and breathing in the same time. So I mean it was difficult it was challenging but we knew that the director was pretty much sure about the sequence she wanted and I mean we had to do justice to the song.Yeah every actor does intent to work in movies.As I said it’s very challenging the whole thing toh,I can’t save someone else I can just save myself toh I mean it happened in the moment and I saved her.I think Ash has experienced that a lot(laughs): I didn’t make the song, I just sung the song. But the writer and the composer of the song are quiet romantic at heart. So I think Bharat can explain you further.Bharat: So ‘’ is a feeling you know could be triggered by anything when someone is sweet to you or you go through these sweet experiences. It doesn’t have to necessarily be relationships or love it could be for example a small child or someone in the family. Like when your mother makes some delicious food for you it can be ‘’. With this song the attempt was to capture that feeling. It’s not necessarily a romantic love story however in the video when I saw the video I was really impressed because here’s the thing it’s a big challenge to bring out and consistently without making it look forced and I think every aspect of the video, the story, the script, the writing and the beautiful locations and the way they executed it and the sheer passion I think the entire team had in this project, I mean they put Shantanu and Reecha underwater that tells you how passionate they were about the whole project.Shantanu: Also the fact that the when you listen to the song it’s very simple, it connects to you, seems like you feel very romantic. It has that vibe to it and to incorporate that old school vibe that’s what we were looking at in terms of the video and old school it’s like when you’re at weddings. I come from that old school thought that you know, so that kind of cuteness that lost feeling is what I feel is people do not experience that, I think that is the video that it shows like it’s still there.: I think Bharat has been a DJ so he should say this.: So the funny thing is as a DJ I used to do a lot of remixes, it’s funny I started my career with remixes and remakes.He has no issue with remixes.: No, not at all. I think as a producer when I hear timeless melodies that old songs they are beautiful melodies. Sometimes I wonder if they had technology that we have today, so it’s an opportunity for us modern music producers to use the technology we have today and use those timeless melodies. I think there’s a lot of scope to show creativity even in recreations. So if you ask me choose one then, because I am a romantic song fan I would do I mean there’s a lot of scope with the song like ‘Pukarta chala hu main’ for example.: Hopefully, Times Music should decide that.: That’s a big suspense.: Right now we are focusing on this particular track and on the first part of it and maybe if you see the end, the love story is the beginning so it will continue from there.
